page.title: Abdullah bin Nasser bin Abdullah Al Ahmed Al Thani

revision.comment: Rescuing 1 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v2.0beta9)
revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=June 2014}} {{arabic name|Al Thani}} [[Sheikh]] '''Abdullah bin Nasser bin Abdullah Al Ahmed Al Thani''' ({{lang-ar|الشيخ عبد الله بن ناصر بن عبد الله الأحمد آل ثاني}}) is a Qatari businessman. He was appointed a non-executive member of board of directors of [[Doha Bank]] on 3 June 1996 and is also a member of the board of Nasser Bin Abdulla & Sons Group.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dohabank.com.qa/1/LinkClick.aspx?fileticket=_3tPzYbByYI%3d&tabid=1151|title=Governance Report|accessdate=7 January 2012|work=Doha Bank}}</ref> '''Sheikh Abdullah''' is from the Qatari [[House of Thani|ruling family]] and a distant relative of Qatar's previous ruler [[Hamad bin Khalifa Al Thani|Sheikh Hamad]] and owns the Spanish [[La Liga|Segunda Division]] football club [[Málaga CF]] as well as several thoroughbred racing horses.
==Family== According to the Royal Ark website, he is the great-grandson of [[Ahmed bin Muhammed Al Thani]], the brother of later emir [[Jassim bin Mohammed Al Thani]] and son of [[Hakim (title)|Hakim]] [[Mohammed bin Thani]].<ref>[http://www.royalark.net/Qatar/qatar2.htm qatar2<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> His father, [[Nasser bin Abdullah bin Ahmed Al Thani]], was the chairman of [[Nasser bin Abdulla & Sons Group]] and after he died in 1990 chairmanship of the Group was bequeathed to his son Abdullah.
His namesake, [[Abdullah bin Nasser bin Khalifa Al Thani]], is his [[cousin|second cousin]]; the preceding [[emir]] of Qatar, [[Hamad bin Khalifa Al Thani]], is Abdullah's cousin once removed.
==Sports== In June 2010, Sheikh Abdullah bought [[Málaga CF]] from [[Lorenzo Sanz]], whose son [[Fernando Sanz]]<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.malagacf.com/noticias/la-llegada-de-shaikh-abdullah-abre-una-nueva-etapa-en-el-malaga-cf-2900.html|title=The arrival of H.H. Shaikh Abdullah Al-Thani opens a new and exciting stage for Málaga Club de Fútbol|date=25 June 2010|accessdate=18 July 2010|work=Málaga CF|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100629210510/http://www.malagacf.com/noticias/la-llegada-de-shaikh-abdullah-abre-una-nueva-etapa-en-el-malaga-cf-2900.html|archivedate=29 June 2010|deadurl=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref> and president of the club at the time, controlled with total management the acquisition. The reported price was €36 million.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/idUKLDE65P06420100626|title=Qatari Sheikh Al-Thani buys Malaga football club|date=26 June 2010|accessdate=18 July 2010|agency=Reuters}}</ref> Sheikh Abdullah has been quoted as saying, in anticipation of the [[2022 FIFA World Cup]] to be held in Qatar, he had hoped to have European clubs branch into the [[Persian Gulf]] market.
Sheikh Abdullah is currently a member of the board of directors of [[Qatar Equestrian Federation]].<ref>[http://www.qatarequestrian.org/index.php?view=content&itm=1024&itmid=2&local=0 Qatar Equestrian Federation – v1.0 «BETA PREVIEW»<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101225135216/http://www.qatarequestrian.org/index.php?view=content&itm=1024&itmid=2&local=0 |date=25 December 2010 }}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[https://twitter.com/ANAALthani Twitter : ANAALthani] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20140201170332/http://www.malagafootball.com/malaga-cf/the-board/sheikh-abdullah-al-thani/ Sheikh Al Thani profile at Malaga Football] *[http://www.ifahr.net/arabian-racehorse-owner.php?mt=7&nr=100854&ld=14 Horse data] *[http://www.puerto-althani.com Puerto Al-Thani.com – Marbella Port to be redeveloped and renamed Puerto Al-Thani] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20120712002136/http://www.althaniportmarbella.com/ (the project & news)]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Thani, Abdullah bin Nasser bin Abdullah Al Ahmed Al}} [[Category:Qatari businesspeople]] [[Category:Qatari expatriates in Spain]] [[Category:House of Thani|Abdullah bin Nasser]] [[Category:People from Doha]] [[Category:Málaga CF]] [[Category:Spanish football chairmen and investors]] [[Category:1969 births]] [[Category:Living people]]
{{Qatar-bio-stub}}

revision.comment: added [[Category:Textile organizations]] using [[WP:HC|HotCat]]
revision.text:
{{moresources|date=August 2018}} {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2018}} {{Use Indian English|date=August 2018}} {{Infobox university | name = Ahmedabad Textile Industry's Research Association | image = ATIRA logo.png | established = 1947 | type = [[Research]] [[Institution]] | campus = [[urban area|Urban]], {{convert|67.21|acre|m2}} | city = [[Ahmedabad]] | state = [[Gujarat]] | country = [[India]] | website = http://www.atira.in }} {{Coord|23|01|56|N|72|32|27|E|display=title}} The '''Ahmedabad Textile Industry's Research Association''' (commonly known as '''ATIRA''') is an [[autonomous]] [[non-profit]] association for [[Textile engineering|textile research]] located in the [[Navarangpura]] area of [[Ahmedabad]], [[India]]. It is the largest association for textile research & allied industries in India. Established on 13 December 1947, and started in 1949, ATIRA was recognized by the Council of Scientific and Industrial Research under the Ministry of Science and Technology, [[Government of India]]. It was later linked to the Ministry of Textiles.
==Establishment== [[File:Ahmedabad Textile Industry's Research Association building (15 05 2006).jpg|thumb|300px|The main ATIRA building]] The idea of ATIRA was conceived by [[Vikram Sarabhai]], [[Kasturbhai Lalbhai]] and [[Shanti Swaroop Bhatnagar]]. The foundation stone for the ATIRA complex was laid by [[Sardar Vallabhbhai Patel]] on 1 November 1950 which was inaugurated by the then [[Prime Minister of India]] [[Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru]] on completion on 10 April 1954. The [[architect]] of the ATIRA building is Achyut Kanvinde. Dr. Vikram Sarabhai served as its first honorary director.
==Membership and funding== Membership in ATIRA is voluntary. ATIRA has 146 member units in both India and abroad. Of these 93 are [[Ginning]], [[Spinning (textiles)|Spinning]], [[Weaving]], Process Houses and Composite Textile Units and 53 are manufacturers of fibres, dyes, chemicals, instruments, equipment and machinery.
ATIRA is financed by four sources – Annual Subscription from member units, income from the services it has rendered, sponsored research from the Industry, Ministry of Textiles, Ministry of Information Technology and other agencies like the [[Gujarat State, India#Government and politics|Gujarat State Government]]. [[Grant (money)|Grant aid]] is also provided by the Government of India.
==Administration== ATIRA's governing council consists of 17 members. It consists of 5 elected members from the industry, including the Chairman, 3 nominated members from various departments of Government of India and 3 scientists as designated members. In addition to these a representative from the associate members and the president of the Ahmedabad Textile Mills Association are also the members of the council. The 4 Directors of Cotton Textile Research Associations are [[ex-officio]] members including the Director of ATIRA.
At present the association has a total membership of 91 units spread all over India. This consists of 10 original or privileged members units and 81 Associate Members units.
Currently the Deputy Director of ATIRA, C. R. Prayag, is officiating as Director.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://atira.in/ContactUs.aspx|title=ATIRA|website=atira.in|access-date=2018-06-05}}</ref>
==Location== ATIRA is situated close to many prominent research and educational institutions like [[Indian Institute of Management Ahmedabad]], [[Physical Research Laboratory]] and [[Gujarat University]]. It has a 2,72,000-square-metre campus which has a plant coverage of over 1,000 trees. This has made it a popular spot for morning walks and jogging among local residents.
==External links== *{{Official website|http://www.atira.in/}} *[http://www.itcti.com/atira.htm Information Technology Centre for Textile Industry]
==References== {{reflist}}
{{Ahmedabad topics}}

{{Infobox person | image = | image_size = | name = Allan Kim Pedersen | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1962|2|7|df=y}} | birth_place = Veflinge, [[Søndersø Municipality|Søndersø]], [[Denmark]] | occupation = Businessman
Owner of:
 [[FC Nordsjælland|F.C. Nordsjælland]] | networth = | spouse = Bente Pedersen | children = Daniel and Carina }} '''Allan Kim Pedersen''' (born 7 February 1962) is a [[Denmark|Danish]] businessman and sports team owner. He holds a controlling stake in [[Danish Superliga]] team [[FC Nordsjælland|F.C. Nordsjælland]]. ==Biography== Allan K. Pedersen grew up on a small farm in Veflinge, a small [[parish]] in the [[Søndersø Municipality|Søndersø municipality]], with his two younger brothers. His mother died while he was of a young age. Pedersen went to high school in [[Middelfart]], before leaving for [[Military service#Denmark|military service]]. He would later leave to pursue a career in [[insurance]] and [[investment]].{{cite web |url=http://www.fyens.dk/article/710186:Navne--Millionaeren-fra-Paddesoe |title=Millionæren fra Paddesø |work=Fynske Medier |publisher=Fyens Stiftstidende & Svendborg Avis |accessdate=14 August 2011}} Currently lives in [[Farum]] with his family. Where his son is coaching the FCN under 17 squad. ==Business history== A one time chairman of [[Copenhagen Stock Exchange|Københavns Fondsbørs]] ([[English language|English]]: Copenhagen Stock Exchange), Pedersen was also involved with [[Akademisk Boldklub]], a [[Association football|football]] club based in [[Gladsaxe]], [[Copenhagen]], as vice-chairman. He was one of three major shareholders, before taking up the role in 2000. His involvement included, but not limited to, sponsorship agreements and contract negotiations.{{cite web |last=Ludvigsen |first=Jesper |date=5 November 2002 |url=http://www.bt.dk/sport/ab-det-foererloese-skib |title=AB - det førerløse skib |work=B.T. |publisher=Det Berlingske Officin |accessdate=14 August 2011}} Pedersen is involved with a diverse selection of Danish investments which include hotel services, industry, travel, sports, food and medicine, of which 10 or more he is chairman or a board member of. He is also vice-chairman of the Divisionsforeningen ([[English language|English]]: The Danish League), where he was on the board before taking over the role in 2008, replacing [[Niels-Christian Holmstrøm]].{{cite web |url=http://www.divisionsforeningen.dk/Bestyrelsesmedlemmer.htm |title=Divisionsforeningens bestyrelse sæson 2009-2010 |publisher=Divisionsforeningen |accessdate=14 August 2011}}{{cite web |last=Vendelboe |first=Pierre |url=http://www.bold.dk/nyt/FCN-boss-ny-naestformand |title=FCN-boss ny næstformand |publisher=Bold.dk |language=Danish |date=6 September 2008 |accessdate=14 August 2011}} ==Sports ownership== ===F.C. Nordsjælland=== Allan K. Pedersen started investing in FCN when the club was in financial difficulty, before buying further shares to gain ownership in the club with holding company AKP Holding with himself as director and his wife Bente Pedersen, as chairman. During his initial time as chairman of FCN, he would control many aspects of the club, including player purchases and sales, as well as scouting and talent development. Gradually delegating these responsibilities to then head coach [[Morten Wieghorst]] and sports director Jan Laursen.{{cite web |url=http://www.bold.dk/nyt/Wieghorst-faar-magten-i-FCN |title=Wieghorst får magten i FCN |publisher=Bold.dk |language=Danish |date=19 April 2006 |accessdate=14 August 2011}}{{cite web |url=http://www.bold.dk/nyt/Laursen-afloeser-Allan-K-Pedersen |title=Laursen afløser Allan K. Pedersen |publisher=Bold.dk |language=Danish |date=27 July 2006 |accessdate=14 August 2011}} {{Update|section|date=September 2015}} In October 2008, Allan K. Pedersen sold F.C. Nordsjælland from AKP Holding to himself for a reported 500,000 [[Danish kroner]], shortly before his holding company went bankrupt. A price Pedersen denies. Following an investigation from his creditors, it was found the sale was forced through without the bank's consent, and that the value for which the club was sold was too low, which ultimately reduced the finances the creators received for the sale. FCN was reevaluated to be worth 35 million kroner at the time of sale.{{cite web |last=Horn |first=Jakob |url=http://www.bold.dk/nyt/Allan-K-Pedersen-solgte-FCN-til-sig-selv |title=Allan K. Pedersen solgte FCN til sig selv |publisher=Bold.dk |language=Danish |date=20 February 2009 |accessdate=14 August 2011}}{{cite web |last=Horn |first=Jakob |url=http://www.bold.dk/nyt/Kurator-FCN-kostede-en-halv-million |title=Kurator: FCN kostede en halv million |publisher=Bold.dk |language=Danish |date=5 March 2009 |accessdate=14 August 2011}}{{cite web |last=Horn |first=Jakob |url=http://www.bold.dk/nyt/Kurator-Allan-K-gav-35-millioner-for-lidt |title=Kurator: Allan K gav 35 millioner for lidt |publisher=Bold.dk |language=Danish |date=21 April 2009 |accessdate=14 August 2011}} The case has gone to [[supreme court]], but it could still take 1-4 years to resolve.{{cite web |last=Houlind |first=Søren |url=http://www.bold.dk/nyt/FCN-ejer-i-landsretten |title=FCN-ejer i landsretten |publisher=Bold.dk |language=Danish |date=12 January 2011 |accessdate=14 August 2011}} ==References== {{Reflist|2}} ==External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20120317173042/http://www.fcn.dk/om-fcn/kontakt/cetest-firstpage111/ Profile] at FCN.dk {{dk icon}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Pedersen, Allan K}} [[Category:1962 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:FC Nordsjælland]] [[Category:Danish businesspeople]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox person | name = Anna Gould | image = Anna Gould.jpg | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = {{Birth date|1875|6|5}} | death_date = {{Death date and age|1961|11|30|1875|6|5}} | death_place = | spouse = {{marriage|[[Paul Ernest Boniface de Castellane|Boni de Castellane]]
|March 14, 1895|1906|reason=div}}
{{marriage|[[Hélie de Talleyrand-Périgord, Duc de Sagan|Hélie de Talleyrand-Périgord]]
|1908|1937|reason=his death}} | parents = [[Jay Gould]] | children = 7 | relatives = [[George Jay Gould I]] (brother)
[[Edwin Gould I]] (brother)
[[Helen Miller Gould]] (sister)
[[Frank Jay Gould]] (brother) }} '''Anna Gould''' (June 5, 1875 – November 30, 1961) was an American [[heir]]ess and [[socialite]], the daughter of [[financier]] [[Jay Gould]]. ==Early life== Anna Gould was born on June 5, 1875 in New York City. She was the daughter of [[Jay Gould]] (1836–1892) and Helen Day Miller (1838–1889). Her siblings included [[George Jay Gould I]], [[Edwin Gould I]], [[Helen Miller Gould]], and [[Frank Jay Gould]]. ==Personal life== {{CSS image crop|Image = Samuel D. Ehrhart - An International High Noon Divorce (1906).jpg|bSize = 300|cWidth= 288|cHeight = |oTop = 4|oLeft = 6|Location= right|Description = A parody of the circus-like atmosphere of the divorce proceedings of Anna Gould, shown holding a bouquet made of indictments against her husband, [[Boni de Castellane]].|Alt = Samuel D. Ehrhart's "An International High Noon Divorce"}}[[File:Gould-Anna 01.jpg|thumb|Anna Gould (1875-1961)]] On March 14, 1895, she married [[Paul Ernest Boniface de Castellane]] (1867–1932), elder son and heir apparent of the Marquis of Castellane, in [[Manhattan, New York]]. He was commonly referred to as ''Boniface de Castellane'' with the nickname "Boni" and used the courtesy title of Count of Castellane (''Comte de Castellane''). Before their divorce, Boni and Anna had five children together: * Marie Louise de Castellane (b. 1896) * Boniface, Marquis de Castellane (1896–1946), who married Yvonne Patenôtre, a daughter of [[Jules Patenotre des Noyers|Jules Patenôtre]] and Eleanor Elverson, a relative of the owners of ''[[The Philadelphia Inquirer]]'' * Georges Paul Ernest de Castellane (1897/9–1944), who married Florinda Fernández y Anchorena (b. 1901) * Georges Gustave de Castellane (c. 1898-1946) * Jay (Jason) de Castellane (1902-1956) They divorced in 1906, after Boniface had spent about $10 million of her family's money. Boniface then sought an annulment from the [[Holy See|Vatican]] in 1924.{{cite news |first= |last= |authorlink= |coauthors= |title=Marriage annulled |url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,880723,00.html |quote=The religious marriage of Boniface, comte de Castellane, to Anna Gould (daughter of the late Jay Gould), in 1895; at the Vatican, by Pope Pius XI. She divorced Boniface in Paris in 1906, in 1908 married (in London) Hélie de Talleyrand-Périgord, later the fifth Duke de Talleyrand. |work=[[Time magazine]] |accessdate=2008-08-04 | date=July 21, 1924}} After several appeals the validity of the marriage was upheld. On April 13, 1925, ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'' magazine wrote: "Probably not since [[Henry VIII of England|Henry VIII]] tried in vain to get an annulment of his marriage with [[Catherine of Aragon]] has a matrimonial case been so long in the courts of the [[Roman Catholic Church]] as that on which nine Cardinals have just handed down a final decision."{{cite news |first= |last= |authorlink= |coauthors= |title=Courts |url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,720221,00.html |quote= |publisher=[[Time (magazine)|Time]] |date=April 13, 1925 |accessdate=2007-07-21 }} In 1908, she married Boni's cousin, [[Hélie de Talleyrand-Périgord, Duc de Sagan]] (1859–1937), son of the dandy [[Boson de Talleyrand-Périgord]]. As eldest son and heir to the Duke of Talleyrand, he was styled Marquis of Talleyrand-Périgord and Duke of Sagan.{{cite news |first= |last= |authorlink= |coauthors= |title=Died. |url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,771005,00.html |quote= Marie Pierre Louis Hélie de Talleyrand-Périgord, Prince de Sagan, fifth Duke of Talleyrand, 78, husband of Railway Heiress Anna Gould; of a heart attack; in Paris. The Duke married Heiress Gould in 1908 after she had been divorced from his cousin, Count Boni de Castellane. Her father, Jay Gould, who bequeathed her $80,000,000, opposed their marriage." |publisher=[[Time magazine]] |date=November 8, 1937 |accessdate=2007-07-21 }} With Talleyrand, Anna had the following two children: * Howard de Talleyrand-Périgord, Duc de Sagan (1909-1929), who took his own life when his parents refused him permission to marry until he was 21.{{cite news |first= |last= |authorlink= |coauthors= |title=Talleyrand Model |url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,732494,00.html |quote=Prince of Sagan, son of the Duchess de Talleyrand, who was Anna, the daughter of the late wealthy Jay Gould, shot himself on purpose in his mother's Paris home. The press did not get wind of the story until last week. When the press came, the Duchess was ready with a frank, detailed and—most important of all—entirely literate statement; one that prevented garbling by scandal-monging journals. The statement said: "The Duke and Duchess de Talleyrand regret keenly to announce the critical illness of their son, Howard. ... He shot himself because we refused him permission to marry until he was 21. ... The shooting took place in our home and our son was taken to a hospital in the Rue Puccini. ... Our son is now in an extremely grave condition. We wish to emphasize that we had no objection to the girl, but only opposed the marriage because of our son's age." |publisher=[[Time magazine]] |date=June 3, 1929 |accessdate=2007-07-21 }}{{cite news |first= |last= |authorlink= |coauthors= |title=Anna Gould's son, self-wounded, dies. Howard de Talleyrand, Prince de Sagan, 19, Succumbs in Paris After 11 Days. Parent's at his Bedside. |quote=Paris, May 28, 1929. Howard de Talleyrand, Prince de Sagan, 19-year-old son of the Duc de Talleyrand and the former Anna Gould, died early this morning following a self-inflicted wound on May 17 after his parents had refused him immediate permission to marry. |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=May 29, 1929 }} * Helene Violette de Talleyrand-Périgord (1915-2003), who married Comte James Robert de Pourtalès on March 29, 1937 in [[Le Val-Saint-Germain]]. They divorced in 1969 and on March 20, 1969, she married [[Gaston Palewski]] (1901–1984), former Minister of Scientific Research, Atomic Energy and Space Questions. She returned to the United States four months before her death and died on December 8, 1961, in Paris.{{cite news |first= |last= |authorlink= |coauthors= |title=Died. |url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,895802,00.html |quote= Anna Gould, Duchess of Talleyrand, 83, daughter of Rail Tycoon Jay Gould and one of the first of the American heiresses whose marriages infused new blood—and new money—into Europe's sagging aristocracy; of a heart attack; in Paris. Wed to Count Boniface de Castellane in 1895, Anna Gould divorced him after an 11-year phantasmagoria of pink marble palaces and $150,000 parties during which the Parisian gay blade skated through more than half of her $13.5 million inheritance. Two years later, she wed the fifth Duke of Talleyrand, a descendant of the wily French diplomatist whose machinations shaped post-Napoleonic Europe, lived with him for 29 years until his death in 1937. |publisher=[[Time magazine]] |date=December 8, 1961 |accessdate=2007-07-21 }}{{cite news |first= |last= |authorlink= |coauthors= |title=Duchesse de Talleyrand Is Dead. Youngest daughter of Jay Gould |url=https://select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=FB0A14F6355912738DDDA90B94D9415B818AF1D3 |quote=The Duchesse de Talleyrand-Périgord, daughter of the late Jay Gould, American railroad financier, died today in Paris where she passed most of her life. |work=The New York Times |date=November 30, 1961 |accessdate=2008-08-06 }} She is entombed in [[Passy Cemetery]] in Paris. ===Descendants=== Anna was a grandmother to Elisabeth de Castellane (1928-1991), who married Jean Bertrand Jacques Adrien Nompar Comte de Caumont La Force (1920-1986) in [[Paris]] on December 7, 1948. She was also a grandmother to Diane Rose Anne Marie de Castellane (b. 1927), who married [[Philippe François Armand Marie de Noailles|Philippe François Armand Marie Duc de Mouchy Prince-Duc de Poix]] (1922-2011) in Paris (civil ceremony) on April 14, 1948 (religious ceremony) on April 20, 1948. After having children, they divorced on March 13, 1974. She was also grandmother to Comte Hélie de Pourtalès who married, as her second husband, the eldest daughter of Princess [[Marie Clotilde Bonaparte]]. ==Timeline== *1875 Birth of Anna Gould *1895 Marriage to Paul Ernest Boniface comte de Castellane (1867–1932), on March 14 *1908 Marriage to Hélie de Talleyrand-Périgord *1929 Suicide of Howard de Talleyrand-Périgord, her son *1932 Death of Boniface de Castellane, her first husband *1932 Awarded the Cross of the French Legion of Honor *1937 Death of Hélie de Talleyrand-Périgord, her second husband *1939 Returns to the US and lives in [[Lyndhurst (mansion)|Lyndhurst]] at her father's estate *1961 Death of Anna Gould ==See also== *[[Jenny Jerome]], an American who married the [[Lord Randolph Churchill]] ==References== {{reflist|2}} ==External links== *[http://richard.arthur.norton.googlepages.com/annagouldbibliography Anna Gould bibliography] ==Further reading== {{refbegin|2}} *New York Times; February 9, 1895; pg. 5; Count Castellane's lineage. His ancestors date from the Crusades and his father is wealthy. *New York Times; February 10, 1895; pg. 11; World of society: Engagement of Miss Anna Gould and Count Castellane. It is probable that the public, if not society, breathed a sigh of relief last week when it was finally, definitely, and conclusively announced that Miss Anna Gould, daughter of the late Jay Gould, was actually engaged to be married. *New York Times; March 5, 1895; pg. 1; Now a French Countess. *New York Times; January 19, 1897; pg. 7; Count Castellane's heir. A son born to the Countess early yesterday morning. *Covington Sun; April 16, 1908; [[Media:Gould-Anna 05.jpg|Gould to Wed]] *New York Times; July 12, 1908; pg. SM1; The family in which Ann Gould married; Three French Dukedoms and a Prussian Principality belong to the Talleyrand-Périgords, Historic house which has already formed three American alliances. Jay Gould's youngest daughter, Anna, is the fourth American woman to marry into the historic house of Talleyrand-Périgord, one of the most ancient and illustrious families of the Old World, yet relatively little is known about it on this side of the Atlantic. *Time; April 13, 1925; Divorce *Time; December 12, 1932; Cross of the French Legion of Honor. *New York Times; October 27, 1937; pg. 31; Talleyrand dead; wed Anna Gould; Duke Was known as Prince of Sagan at time of courtship in first of century. Marie Pierre Camille Louis Hélie de Talleyrand-Périgord, Prince of Sagan and fifth Duke of Talleyrand, was a principal in one of the international marriage of the first decade of this century. He married Anna Gould, heir to more than $80,000,000 of the fortune of her father, the late Jay Gould, after she had divorced his cousin, Count Boni de Castellane. *Time; March 26, 1945; The Duchess de Talleyrand, 70, chic, spry daughter of the late financier Jay Gould, and a longtime (40 years) resident of prewar France, announced that she would auction off her famed collection of orchid plants—more than 5,000, valued at about $75,000—for the benefit of the Red Cross. In giving up the collection, which blooms in a two-block-long greenhouse on the Gould estate in Tarrytown, N.Y., the Duchess will save some 75 tons of coal for spring heating, can free nine gardeners for other work. *New York Times; November 30, 1961; pg. 37; Duchesse de Talleyrand Is Dead; youngest daughter of Jay Gould {{refend}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Gould, Anna}} [[Category:1878 births]] [[Category:1961 deaths]] [[Category:American socialites]] [[Category:Annulment]] [[Category:Gould family|Anna]] [[Category:House of Talleyrand-Périgord]] [[Category:Burials at Passy Cemetery]] [[Category:Chevaliers of the Légion d'honneur]] [[Category:People included in New York Society's Four Hundred]]

revision.comment: updated infobox, minor style changes
revision.text:
{{EngvarB|date=September 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2014}} {{Infobox person | name = Arthur K. Bell <!-- include middle initial, if not specified in birth_name --> | image = <!-- just the filename, without the File: or Image: prefix or enclosing [[brackets]] --> | alt = | caption = | birth_name = <!-- only use if different from name --> | birth_date = {{Birth date|df=yes|1868|10|04}} | birth_place = Craigie, Perth | death_date = {{Death date and age|df=yes|1942|04|26|1868|10|04}} | death_place = Campsie Hill, Perth | residence = Kincarrathie House, Perth | nationality = [[United Kingdom|Scottish]] | other_names = AK Bell | parents = Arthur Bell | occupation = [[distillation|distiller]] | years_active = 1895–1942 | spouse = Cammilla Bruce (married 1899–1942) | known_for = Former owner of Arthur Bell & Sons Ltd, and founder of the Gannochy Trust. }}
'''Arthur Kinmond Bell''', also known as '''AK Bell''', (4 October 1868–16 April 1942) was a Scottish distiller, working as a partner of [[Arthur Bell & Sons Ltd]], and as a philanthropist, founding the [[Gannochy Trust]] to help support the people of his home city of [[Perth, Scotland|Perth]].
==Birth and family life== Throughout much of his life Bell resided in [[Perth, Scotland|Perth]], born on 4 October 1868 at Moncreife Terrace, Craigie, Perth. Educated first at [[Perth Academy]] he later moved to [[Edinburgh]] continuing his studies at [[Craigmount School]].<ref name=Oxford_DNB>{{cite web|last1=Weir|first1=Ronald B.|title=Bell, Arthur|url=http://www.oxforddnb.com/templates/article.jsp?articleid=50406&back=|website=Oxford DNB|publisher=Oxford University Press|accessdate=13 July 2014}}</ref>
In 1899 Bell married Miss Cammilla Bruce.<ref name=Chronology>{{cite web|title=Arthur Kinmond Bell – Chronology|url=http://www.gannochytrust.org.uk/community/arthur-kinmond-bell-chronology|website=Gannochy Trust|accessdate=12 July 2014}}</ref> The ceremony was conducted in her native city of Edinburgh, but with both in their late 30s at the time of the marriage, a life without children seemed probable. It has been speculated that this contributed to his desire to make a lasting mark, leading to his [[philanthropy]].<ref name=Duncan_2012>{{cite book|last1=Duncan|first1=Jeremy|title=A Roof Over One's Head|date=2012|publisher=Farquhar and Son Ltd|location=Perth|isbn=978-0-9560620-7-9|pages=16–33}}</ref>
==Career== Bell joined the family business as a partner in 1895, following in the path of his father and grandfather.<ref name=Bells_History>{{cite web|last1=Nielson|first1=AC|title=Our History|url=http://www.bells.co.uk/?History|website=Bell's|publisher=Bell's|accessdate=10 July 2014}}</ref> He quickly made his mark, and along with his brother, Robert, succeeded in doubling the company's profits before his father's death in 1900.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Duncan|first1=Jeremy|title=A Roof Over One's Head|date=2012|publisher=Farquhar and Son Ltd|location=Perth|isbn=978-0-9560620-7-9|page=14}}</ref> At this time Bell, as the eldest son, became managing director, and continued to expand the business despite the setbacks of the [[Great Depression]] and [[Prohibition in the United States]], becoming governor director in 1921 when the company became a limited company.<ref name="Courier at RootWeb">{{cite news|title=Perth's Tribute to A. K. Bell extract available at RootsWeb|url=http://archiver.rootsweb.ancestry.com/th/read/SANDEMAN/2004-10/1097742672|accessdate=13 July 2014|work=The Courier and Advertiser|date=4 July 1994|ref=The Courier and Advertiser}}</ref> This expansion was achieved in large part through the use of advertising and agents, many of whom were members of his extended family living throughout the empire, and included the friendly takeover of three distilleries between 1933–1936. By the time of Bell's death in 1942, the company's profits were in excess of £100,000 per annum.<ref>{{cite book|title=Chambers Scottish Biographical Dictionary|date=1992|publisher=Chambers Ltd|location=Edinburgh and New York|isbn=0-550-16043-4}}</ref>
Later in his life, Bell saved the Perth linen industry by financially backing the one remaining company, John Shields and Co. intervening at the request of the [[Lord Provost]] Robert Nimmo.<ref>{{cite news|title=A Perth Authority on Linen Manufacture|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=2507&dat=19390626&id=y0VAAAAAIBAJ&sjid=kYUMAAAAIBAJ&pg=3825,4070184|accessdate=12 July 2014|agency=Glasgow Herald|publisher=Herald and Times Group|date=26 June 1939}}</ref> The apparent and imminent closure of this company came as a shock to the [[Perth and Kinross Council|local council]], and the loss of 300 jobs would have been a blow to the city,. For his contribution Bell receiving the Freedom of Perth, and the workers of the company presented him with a parchment tribute as a thanks for his part in turning the company into a successful and growing enterprise.<ref name=Duncan_2012 /> Following his purchase of the company, Bell reconstructed the firm and re-equipped it for artificial fibre production, helping to secure the business into the future.<ref name=Oxford_DNB />
==Philanthropic activities== :"After a man has a roof over his head and his bread and butter is fairly well assured and has a surplus, I think you will agree with me that it is only common sense that he should spend part of that surplus for the benefit of his native city."<ref name=75_Celebration>{{cite news|title=Perth-born distiller Arthur Kinmond remembered|url=http://www.dailyrecord.co.uk/news/local-news/perth-born-distiller-arthur-kinmond-remembered-2731937|accessdate=10 July 2014|work=Daily Record|date=14 February 2012}}</ref>
This quotation from Bell's acceptance of the Freedom of Perth sums up his approach to philanthropy, and how as a beneficiary of the then booming [[Scotch whisky]] trade, Bell prospered and was able to look to benefit his home city. His first major project in this direction was the building of the Gannochy Housing Estate between 1924 and 1932.<ref name="Bell and Trust">{{cite web|title=A K Bell and the Gannochy Trust|url=http://www.gannochytrust.org.uk/index.php?page=a-k-bell|website=Gannochy Trust|accessdate=10 July 2014}}</ref> This model housing scheme was intended to benefit the hardworking of a younger generation, who had survived the harshness of war and were now looking to better themselves, with many of the original tenancies being granted to workers of Bell & Sons.<ref name=Duncan_2012 />
His next major project was the establishment of the [[Gannochy Trust]] in 1937,<ref name=Chronology /> founded partly to maintain the Gannochy estate and partly to ensure the continuing improvement of his native city into the future, even after his death.<ref name="Bell and Trust" />
After housing, the other major concern for post-war Perth was the supply of clean water, with the [[River Tay]] becoming increasingly polluted. In answer to this problem Bell provided shares in Bell's Whisky to the Gannochy Trust for the purpose of establishing Sewage treatment works for Perth and the surrounding villages, having previously commissioned a survey of what needed to be done to improve the situation in 1925. In total the trust was able to provide £640,000 towards the projects, with the one in Perth being completed in 1971.<ref name="Bell and Trust" />
==Recognition== In contrast to many of his local contemporaries, such as [[John Dewar, 1st Baron Forteviot]] and [[Robert Pullar]], Bell received comparatively few public honours for his philanthropic activities during his life.<ref name=Duncan_2012 /> One distinction he did receive, on 18 March 1938, was the Freedom of Perth,<ref name=Chronology /> which he described as his greatest honour. This honour was granted primarily for his role in saving John Shields and Co. rather than for any of his philanthropic activities, which appear to have been done quietly and gone without any major public awareness during his life, a fact he would likely have been grateful for.<ref name=Duncan_2012 />
In 1994, the decision was taken to name Perth's new multi-million-pound library the A. K. Bell library in honour of the man who had played such a large part in the city's history and whose legacy has had such a large impact on the city.<ref name="Courier at RootWeb" /> The library officially opened in 1995.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Lambert|first1=Tim|title=A Brief History of Perth|url=http://www.localhistories.org/perth.html|website=localhistories.org|accessdate=31 July 2014}}</ref>
==Death== Arthur Kinmond Bell died unexpectedly of illness on 26 April 1942.<ref name=Duncan_2012 /> His will, though, proved him to be as generous in death as he was in life, gifting to 3 senior employees of Arthur Bell and Sons the sum of £5000, to all staff with 10 years experience in the company, £500, and to his gardeners, chauffeurs, and servants in his employ for 10 years or more, £200, all significant amounts for those who benefitted.<ref name="Courier at RootWeb" />
At the time of his death Bell was living in Kincarrathie House, Perth, with his wife. Camilla later donated the house to the Kincarrathie Trust, who now run the house as a retirement home.<ref>{{cite web|title=Kincarrathie House|url=http://www.scottish-places.info/features/featurefirst89862.html|publisher=Gazetteer for Scotland|accessdate=13 July 2014}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [https://www.bbc.co.uk/arts/yourpaintings/paintings/arthur-kinmond-bell-18681942-philanthropist-212323 Portrait of Arthur Kinmond Bell on BBC – Your Paintings site]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Bell, Arthur Kinmond}} [[Category:Scottish businesspeople]] [[Category:People from Perth, Scotland]] [[Category:People educated at Perth Academy]] [[Category:1868 births]] [[Category:1942 deaths]] [[Category:Scottish philanthropists]]

revision.comment: "Articles of incorporation" is a plural noun.
revision.text:
[[File:Standard Oil Articles of Incorporation - 1870.png|thumb|right|The 1870 articles of incorporation for the [[Standard Oil]] Company]] '''Articles of incorporation''', also referred to as the '''certificate of incorporation''' or the '''corporate charter''', are a document or charter that establishes the existence of a corporation in the [[United States]] and [[Canada]]. They generally are filed with the Secretary of State or other [[list of company registers|company registrar]].
An equivalent term for [[limited liability companies]] (LLCs) in the United States is [[articles of organization]]. For terms with similar meaning in other countries, see [[articles of association]].
== United States == The articles of incorporation outline the governance of a corporation along with the [[bylaw|corporate bylaws]] and the corporate statutes in the state where articles of incorporation are filed.
The articles of incorporation typically include the name of the corporation, the type of corporate structure (e.g. profit corporation, nonprofit corporation, benefit corporation, professional corporation), the [[registered agent]], the number of authorized shares, the effective date, the duration (perpetual by default), and the names and signatures of the incorporators.
The state fee to file articles of incorporation to incorporate a profit corporation range from $50 - $300, and to incorporate a nonprofit corporation range from $0 -$125.<ref>Entity formation fees [https://www.harborcompliance.com/information/entity-formation-fees].</ref>
==See also== * [[Articles of association]] ** [[The Companies (Model Articles) Regulations 2008]] * [[Articles of organization]] * [[Certificate of incorporation]] * [[Charter]] * [[Bylaw|Bylaws]] * [[Mission statement]] * [[Operating agreement]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
[[Category:Corporate law]] [[Category:Organizational documents]]

{{BLP sources|date=December 2016}} {{Use dmy dates|date=December 2015}} {{Infobox writer <!-- For more information see [[:Template:Infobox Writer/doc]]. --> | name = Bilal Abdallah Alayli | image = | image_size = | alt = | caption = | pseudonym = | birth_name = | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|df=yes|1949|04|10}} | birth_place = [[Beirut]], Lebanon | death_date = | death_place = | resting_place = | occupation = academic and scholar | language = | nationality = [[Lebanese nationality law|Lebanese]] | ethnicity = | education = | alma_mater = | period = | genre = | subject = | movement = | notableworks = | spouse = | partner = | children = | relatives = | influences = | influenced = | awards = | signature = | signature_alt = | website = | portaldisp = }}
'''Bilal Abdallah Alayli''' is a Lebanese academic and scholar.
==Early life== Bilal Alayli Or Alayeli ([[:ar: بلال عبد الله العلايلي]]) was born in [[Beirut]], [[Lebanon]] in 1949. He was raised in a [[Sunni Islam in Lebanon|Sunni Muslim]] family.
==Educational background==
===Undergraduate studies=== He joined the Lebanese University to graduate in 1973 earning a bachelor's degree in physics. His highest honors qualified him to earn the scholarship of the Lebanese University to travel to France for further academic formation.
===Graduate studies=== In France, he obtained a PhD in [[nuclear physics]] from the [[University of Lyon]] in 1976 and received his diploma in civil engineering from ([[École centrale de Lyon]]).
==Academic Work== He joined the University of [[Oran]] ([[Algeria]]) from the year of 1976 until the year of 1979. He founded with Dr. [[Jack Nasr]] Faculty of Engineering at the [[Lebanese University]] in 1981.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ul.edu.lb/|title=The Lebanese University|work=ul.edu.lb}}</ref> He was appointed Director of the Faculty of Engineering at the Lebanese University -section III through the years of 1982 and 1992. He remained a Professor in that university until the year of 2007.
==Professional experience== *He worked as an Assistant Director of Oger from 1982 until 1984 *He was appointed Assistant Director of the [[Rafic Hariri|Hariri]] Foundation from 1984 until 1986 *Co- founder of laceco
==In the Order of Engineers and Architects – Beirut== Elected as the president of the Order of Engineers and Architects in April 2008 supported by the [[Future Movement]] (almustaqbal) and 14 March.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.oea.org.lb/Arabic/Default.aspx?pageid=7|title=نقابة المهندسين بيروت|work=oea.org.lb}} ''The Order of Engineers and Architects – Beirut''</ref>'' His number at The Order of Engineers and Architects – Beirut is 4173''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.oea.org.lb/arabic/memberssearch.aspx?pageid=112|title=بحث عن مهندس – نقابة المهندسين بيروت|work=oea.org.lb}} ''Search for Engineer''</ref>
==External links== * [http://www.laceco.net/aboutus.php Laceco ''The Team''] * [http://www.universite-lyon.fr/ universite of lyon] *[http://www.adgeco.com/bilal-alaily-ghassa-khatib-mohamed-dekkak visit of Bilal Alaily Director of Operations, Ghassan Khatib Director of LACECO to Chairman and Founder of Adgeco Group Mohamed Dekkak] *[http://www.usek.edu.lb/en/News/Visit-of-a-delegation-from-the-FSCE-to-the-President-of-the-Order-of-Engineers-of-Beirut Visit of a delegation from the FSCE to the President of the Order of Engineers of Beirut]
==References== <references/>

Racing colors: Black, cherry cap. | trainer = [[William C. Winfrey]]
[[Edward A. Neloy]] | record = 31: 25-4-1 | earnings= $1,462,014 | race = [[Champagne Stakes (United States)|Champagne Stakes]] (1965)

(1983, 1984, 1989) | honours = [[National Museum of Racing and Hall of Fame|U.S. Racing Hall of Fame]] (1970)
[[Blood-Horse magazine List of the Top 100 Racehorses of the 20th Century|#14 - Top 100 U.S. Racehorses of the 20th Century]] | updated= 28 September 2010 }} '''Buckpasser''' (1963–1978) was an American-bred [[Thoroughbred]] [[racehorse]] that won 9 of his 11 race starts for international record winnings for a two-year-old of $586,090. He was a leading broodmare sire in 1983, 1984, and 1989. Buckpasser was a [[Bay (color)|bay]] colt that was bred and owned by [[Ogden Phipps]] and foaled at [[Claiborne Farm]] in [[Paris, Kentucky]]. He was by the [[Eclipse Award for Horse of the Year|Horse of the Year]]-winner [[Tom Fool]], and his dam was the stakes-winning mare Busanda, by the [[United States Triple Crown of Thoroughbred Racing|Triple Crown]]-winner [[War Admiral]]. Busanda’s second dam was the Blue Hen broodmare [[La Troienne]] (FR). He was a half-brother to several other horses that included the stakes-winners Bupers (won $221,688) and Bureaucracy ($156,635). Buckpasser was inbred in the fourth generation (4m x 4f) to the French racehorse and influential sire [[Teddy (horse)|Teddy]].Craig, Dennis, ''Breeding Racehorses from Cluster Mares'', J A Allen, London, 1964 Racing official Dr. Manual Gilman said of him, "Generally, every horse has about a hundred faults of conformation. I would defy anybody to pick a flaw in Buckpasser." Renowned horse painter [[Richard Stone Reeves]] said, "Buckpasser was the most perfectly proportioned Thoroughbred I have ever seen." Only two horses, [[Secretariat (horse)|Secretariat]] and [[Affirmed]], have since been "in a class with Buckpasser".{{Cite web |url=http://www.thoroughbredchampions.com/biographies/buckpasser.htm# |title=Thoroughbred champions |access-date=2006-09-07 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060909184327/http://www.thoroughbredchampions.com/biographies/buckpasser.htm# |archive-date=2006-09-09 |dead-url=yes |df= }} ==Racing record== Buckpasser had two trainers, both since elected to the [[National Museum of Racing and Hall of Fame|U.S. Racing Hall of Fame]]. [[William C. Winfrey|Bill Winfrey]] began his training, and when he retired, [[Edward A. Neloy|Eddie Neloy]] took over and prepared Buckpasser for his three-year-old season. Buckpasser's first race start was on May 13, 1965, in which he ran a poor fourth. It was the only time he did not place. When Buckpasser ran in the [[Flamingo Stakes]], the race was declared a nonwagering event, forever after called the "Chicken" Flamingo.http://www.spiletta.com/UTHOF/buckpasser.html After his two-year-old season and spring, he was placed at the top of the Experimental Free Handicap with 126 pounds. Buckpasser developed a quarter crack that kept him out of the 1966 [[Kentucky Derby]], as well as the [[Preakness Stakes|Preakness]] and Belmont Stakes. It took almost three months for the crack to heal. In [[Chicago]]'s [[Arlington Classic]], [[Kauai King]] ran against the strenuous protests of his trainer. He broke down and was retired, while Buckpasser won the race, setting a new world record for a mile with a time of 1:32 3/5. This record stood for two years until [[Dr. Fager]] broke it in 1968, running 1:32 1/5. In 1989, Buckpasser's grandson, Hall of Fame Champion [[Easy Goer]], ran a mile in 1:32 2/5. Buckpasser won 15 consecutive races that included the [[American Derby]] (breaking the track record), the Chicago Stakes, the Brooklyn Derby, the [[Woodward Stakes]], the [[Travers Stakes]], the [[Malibu Stakes]], the [[Brooklyn Handicap]], the [[Lawrence Realization Stakes]], and the two-mile-long [[Jockey Club Gold Cup]]. With 13 victories as a three-year-old, Buckpasser became the first horse to earn more than $1 million before the age of four. He was named the 1966 [[Eclipse Award for Horse of the Year|American Horse of the Year]].{{cite news|author=|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1966/11/23/archives/horseofyear-honors-gained-by-buckpasser.html |title=Horse-of-Year Honors Gained by Buckpasser |publisher=New York Times |date=1966-11-23 |accessdate=2012-02-27}}{{cite news|author=|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1966/12/06/archives/racing-magazine-names-buckpasser-horse-of-year.html |title=Racing Magazine Names Buckpasser Horse of Year |publisher=New York Times |date=1966-12-06 |accessdate=2012-02-27}} His four-year-old season commenced with a win in the San Fernando Stakes. Another quarter crack developed in Buckpasser’s off (right) fore hoof, and he did not race for 4½ months. When he returned, he scored his 15th consecutive victory in the Metropolitan Mile. On June 17, 1967, Buckpasser's winning streak ended with his first and only attempt at racing on grass. He finished third to stablemate Poker in the [[Bowling Green Handicap]] at [[Aqueduct Racetrack]]. [[Assagai (horse)|Assagai]], the 1966 turf-course champion, finished second. As ''[[The Blood-Horse]]'' said in its July 24, 1967, issue: "Never had so many people had so many immunization shots in order to stay home and watch the [[Suburban Handicap]] on Independence Day." Three reasons were advanced for his defeat: turf, shoes, and weight. Buckpasser also ran that day with his head held in an uncommon way, slightly sideways. No one has ever understood why. He won 25 of his 31 races, including a 15-race winning streak, earned five [[Eclipse Awards]] between 1965 and 1967, and was inducted to the [[National Museum of Racing and Hall of Fame#Horses in the Hall of Fame|Horse Racing Hall of Fame]] in 1970.{{cite web|title=Buckpasser|url=http://www.equibase.com/profiles/Results.cfm?type=Horse&refno=66037®istry=T |publisher=Equibase |accessdate=May 7, 2014}} ==Stud record== When he retired, Buckpasser was syndicated for $4,800,000: a record $150,000 a share. He stood at stud at the farm where he was born. In 11 years, he sired 313 foals, of which 35 won stakes races. Included in his get were: * [[La Prevoyante]] ([[Sovereign Award for Horse of the Year]] in [[Canada]], [[Eclipse Award]] Champion two-year-old filly in the [[United States]], Champion Older Female in Canada), * [[L'Enjoleur]] (CAN) (won [[Manitoba Derby]], [[Quebec Derby]], etc.) * [[Numbered Account (horse)|Numbered Account]], (Champion two-year-old filly, dam of Private Account, sire of undefeated Personal Ensign) * [[Paristo]] ([[Illinois Derby]]) * [[Quick As Lightning]] ([[1,000 Guineas]]) * [[Relaxing (horse)|Relaxing]] (Champion Older Female, Broodmare of the Year, dam of Belmont Stakes-winner [[Easy Goer]]), * [[Silver Buck]] ([[Whitney Handicap]], [[Suburban Handicap]], sire of Kentucky Derby-winner [[Silver Charm]]) * [[State Dinner]] ([[Century Handicap]], etc.) * [[Toll Booth (horse)|Toll Booth]] (Broodmare of the Year). Though he had three tail-male Kentucky Derby (G1) winners ([[Spend a Buck]]-1985, [[Lil E. Tee]]-1992 and [[Silver Charm]]-1997), his record as a damsire stands out. Buckpasser was a leading broodmare sire in 1983, 1984, and 1989. His daughters have produced Champions and Classic Winners: They are led by Hall of Famers [[Easy Goer]] and [[Slew o' Gold]], [[Belmont Stakes]] winners [[Coastal (horse)|Coastal]] and [[Touch Gold]], and [[With Approval]], as well as [[El Gran Senor]] among a number of other influential stallions such as [[Seeking The Gold]], [[Miswaki]], and [[Woodman (horse)|Woodman]]. ==Honors== In ''The Blood-Horse'' magazine ranking of the [[Blood-Horse magazine List of Top 100 Racehorses of the 20th Century|top 100 U.S. thoroughbred champions of the 20th Century]], Buckpasser is #14. Buckpasser died in 1978 at age 15 and is buried at [[Claiborne Farm]]. ==Pedigree== {{Pedigree |name = Buckpasser, bay horse, 1963 |f = [[Tom Fool]]
B. 1949 |m = [[Busanda]]
Blk. 1947 |ff = [[Menow]]

Br. 1925 |ffm = [[Alcibiades (horse)|Alcibiades]]

B. 1927 |fmm = Alpoise
B. 1937 |mff = [[Man o' War]]
Ch. 1917 |mfm = Brushup
B. 1929 |mmf = [[Blue Larkspur]]
B. 1926 |mmm = [[La Troienne]] (FR)
B. 1926 |ffff = [[Phalaris (horse)|Phalaris]] |fffm = Selene |ffmf = Supremus |ffmm = Regal Roman (GB) |fmff = '''[[Teddy (horse)|Teddy]]''' |fmfm = [[Plucky Liege]] |fmmf = [[Equipoise (horse)|Equipoise]] |fmmm = Laughing Queen |mfff = [[Fair Play (horse)|Fair Play]] |mffm = [[Mahubah]] |mfmf = [[Sweep (horse)|Sweep]] |mfmm = Annette K |mmff = Black Servant |mmfm = Blossom Time |mmmf = '''[[Teddy (horse)|Teddy]]''' |mmmm = Helene de Troie (family: 1x) |}} ==See also== *[[List of leading Thoroughbred racehorses]] ==References== {{Reflist}} * [http://www.racingmuseum.org/hall/horse.asp?ID=38 Buckpasser's page in the Hall of Fame, includes a video of the "Chicken" Flamingo] [[Category:1963 racehorse births]] [[Category:1978 racehorse deaths]] [[Category:Racehorses trained in the United States]] [[Category:American Thoroughbred Horse of the Year]] [[Category:United States Thoroughbred Racing Hall of Fame inductees]] [[Category:Racehorses bred in Kentucky]] [[Category:Phipps family]] [[Category:United States Champion Thoroughbred Sires]] [[Category:American Champion racehorses]] [[Category:American Champion Thoroughbred broodmare sires]] [[Category:Thoroughbred family 1-x]] [[Category:Chefs-de-Race]]

revision.text:
{{more footnotes|date=June 2013}} '''Capacity utilization''' or '''capacity utilisation''' is the extent to which an enterprise or a nation uses its installed [[productive capacity]]. It is the relationship between [[output (economics)|output]] that ''is'' produced with the installed equipment, and the potential output which ''could'' be produced with it, if capacity was fully used.
==Engineering and economic measures== One of the most used definitions of the "capacity utilization rate" is the ratio of actual output to the [[potential output]]. But potential output can be defined in at least two different ways.
===Engineering definition=== One is the "engineering" or "technical" definition, according to which potential output represents the maximum amount of output that can be produced in the short-run with the existent stock of capital. Thus, a standard definition of capacity utilization is the (weighted) average of the ratios between the actual output of firms to the maximum that could be produced per unit of time, with existing plant and equipment (see Johanson 1968). Obviously, "output" could be measured in physical units or in market values, but normally it is measured in market values.
However, as output increases and well before the absolute physical limit of production is reached, most firms might well experience an increase in the average cost of production—even if there is no change in the level of plant & equipment used. For example, higher average costs can arise, because of the need to operate extra shifts, to undertake additional plant maintenance, and so on.
===Economic definition=== An alternative approach, sometimes called the "economic" utilization rate, is, therefore, to measure the ratio of actual output to the level of output ''beyond which the average cost of production begins to rise''. In this case, surveyed firms are asked by how much it would be practicable for them to raise production from existing plant and equipment, ''without raising unit costs'' (see Berndt & Morrison 1981). Typically, this measure will yield a rate around 10 percentage points higher than the "engineering" measure, but time series show the same movement over time.
===Measurement=== [[File:Harddatafredgraph.png|thumb|Capacity utilization (black line) in manufacture in the United States, [[unemployment rate]] (red line, upside down, scale on the right), [[employment rate]] (dotted line)]] [[File:KapaAuslUSABRDEngl.png|thumb|Capacity utilization in [[manufacturing]] in the [[Germany|FRG]] and in the USA]] In [[economic statistics]], capacity utilization is normally surveyed for goods-producing industries at plant level. The results are presented as an average percentage rate by industry and economy-wide, where 100% denotes full capacity. This rate is also sometimes called the "operating rate". If the operating rate is high, this is called "full capacity", while if the operating rate is low, a situation of "excess capacity" or "surplus capacity" exists. The observed rates are often turned into indices. Capacity utilization is much more difficult to measure for service industries.
There has been some debate among economists about the validity of statistical measures of capacity utilization, because much depends on the survey questions asked, and on the valuation principles used to measure output. Also, the efficiency of production may change over time, due to new technologies.
For example, [[Michael Perelman]] has argued in his 1989 book ''[[John Maynard Keynes|Keynes]], Investment Theory and the Economic Slowdown: The Role of Replacement Investment and q-Ratios'' that the US [[Federal Reserve Board]] measure is just not very revealing. Prior to the early 1980s, he argues, American business carried a great deal of extra capacity. At that time, running close to 80% would indicate that a plant was approaching capacity restraints. Since that time, however, firms scrapped much of their most inefficient capacity. As a result, a modern 77% capacity utilization now would be equivalent to a historical level of 70%.
==Economic significance== If market demand grows, capacity utilization will rise. If demand weakens, capacity utilization will slacken. Economists and bankers often watch capacity utilization indicators for signs of inflation pressures.
It is often believed that when the utilization rate rises above somewhere between 82% and 85%, price inflation will increase. Excess capacity means that insufficient demand exists to warrant expansion of output.
All else constant, the lower capacity utilization falls (relative to the trend capacity utilization rate), the better the [[bond market]] likes it. Bondholders view strong capacity utilization (above the trend rate) as a leading indicator of higher [[inflation]]. Higher inflation—or the expectation of higher inflation—decreases bond prices, often prompting a higher yield to compensate for the higher expected rate of inflation.
Implicitly, the capacity utilization rate is also an indicator of how efficiently the [[factors of production]] are being used. Much statistical and anecdotal evidence shows that many industries in the developed capitalist economies suffer from ''chronic'' excess capacity. Critics of market [[capitalism]], therefore, argue the system is not as efficient as it may seem, since at least 1/5 more output could be produced and sold, if buying power was better distributed. However, a level of utilization somewhat below the maximum typically prevails, regardless of economic conditions.
===Modern business cycle theory=== The notion of capacity utilization was introduced into modern [[business cycle]] theory by Greenwood, [[Hercowitz]], and Huffman (1988). They illustrated how capacity utilization is important for getting business cycle correlations in economic models to match the data when there are shocks to [[investment spending]].
==Output gap percentage formula== As a derivative indicator, the "output gap percentage" (%OG) can be measured as the gap between actual output (AO) and potential output (PO) ''divided'' by potential output and ''multiplied'' by 100%:
:%OG = [(AO – PO)/PO] × 100%.
==FRB and ISM utilization indexes== In the survey of plant capacity used by the US [[Federal Reserve Board]] for the FRB capacity utilization index, firms are asked about "the maximum level of production that this establishment could reasonably expect to attain under normal and realistic operating conditions, fully utilizing the machinery and equipment in place."
By contrast, the [[Institute of Supply Management]] (ISM) index asks respondents to measure their current output relative to "normal capacity", and this yields a utilization rate, which is between 4 and 10 percentage points higher than the FRB measure. Again, the time series show more or less the same historical movement.
See: [[Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System]]: Industrial Production and Capacity Utilization<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.federalreserve.gov/releases/g17/current/|title=The Fed - Industrial Production and Capacity Utilization - G.17|author=|date=|website=federalreserve.gov|accessdate=14 April 2018}}</ref>
==Data== The average economy-wide capacity utilization rate in the US since 1967 was about 81.6%, according to the Federal Reserve measure. The figure for Europe is not much different, for Japan being only slightly higher.
The average utilization rate of installed productive capacity in industry, in some major areas of the world, was estimated in 2003/2004 to be as follows (rounded figures):
===Average utilization rate=== * United States 79.5% (April 2008 — Federal Reserve measure) * Japan 83–86% (Bank of Japan) * European Union 82% (Bank of Spain estimate) * Australia 80% (National Bank estimate) * Brazil 60–80% (various sources) * India 70% (Hindu business line) * China perhaps 60% (various sources) * Turkey 79.8% (September 2008 — [[Turkish Statistical Institute]])<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.turkstat.gov.tr/PreHaberBultenleri.do?id=2051 |title=Turkish Statistical Institute |publisher=Turkstat.gov.tr |date=2009-04-09 |accessdate=2013-09-27}}</ref> * Canada 87% (Statistics Canada)
==Notes== {{reflist}}
==References== * E. Berndt & J. Morrison, "Capacity utilization measures: Underlying Economic Theory and an Alternative Approach", American Economic Review, 71, 1981, pp. 48–52 * I. Johanson, Production functions and the concept of capacity", Collection Economie et Mathematique et Econometrie, 2, 1968, pp. 46–72 * [[Michael Perelman]], ''Keynes, Investment Theory and the Economic Slowdown'' * [[Susan Strange]] and Roger Tooze, ''The International Politics of Surplus Capacity: Competition for Market Shares in the World Recession'' (London: Allen & Unwin, 1981). * [[James Crotty (economist)|James Crotty]], "Why there is chronic excess capacity - The Market Failures Issue", in: ''Challenge'', Nov-Dec, 2002 [http://www.findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_m1093/is_6_45/ai_95629325] * Jeremy Greenwood, [[Zvi Hercowitz]], and Gregory W. Huffman, "Investment, Capacity Utilization and the Real Business Cycle," ''American Economic Review'', 1988. * Thomas G. Rawski, "The Political Economy of China's Declining Growth", University of Pittsburgh. [https://web.archive.org/web/20060108092613/http://www.pitt.edu/~tgrawski/paper99/rawski-melbourne.htm] * [[Anwar Shaikh (Economist)|Anwar Shaikh]] and Jamee Moudud, ''Measuring Capacity Utilization in OECD Countries: A Cointegration Method''(2004), Working Paper No. 415, The Jerome Levy Economics Institute of Bard College. [https://web.archive.org/web/20060315003307/http://homepage.newschool.edu/~AShaikh/measuring%20capacity.pdf] * Annys Shin, "Economy Strains Under Weight of Unsold Items", ''Washington Post'', February 17, 2009, A01.
==External links== * [https://bhs.econ.census.gov/bhs/pcu/index.html US survey of plant capacity utilisation] * [http://www.federalreserve.gov/releases/g17/current/ipg1.gif Capacity utilisation of US industry] * [http://www.federalreserve.gov/releases/G17/ Federal Reserve Statistics] * [http://www.fao.org/DOCREP/003/X2250E/x2250e07.htm FAO discussion of concepts and measures] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20060315003307/http://homepage.newschool.edu/~AShaikh/measuring%20capacity.pdf Measuring capacity utilization in OECD countries] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20060913092707/http://cds.edu/download_files/334.pdf Economic Reforms and Industrial Performance: An analysis of Capacity Utilization in Indian Manufacturing]
{{economics}}
[[Category:Production economics]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=December 2017}} [[File:WIBA Brisbane Winner 2016-Dimity-Dornan.jpg|thumb|Dr Dimity Dornan AO]]'''Dimity Dornan''' AO is a speech pathologist, author, and businesswoman in [[Brisbane]], [[Queensland]], Australia. She is the founder of the Hear and Say Centre for Deaf Children in 6 July 1992 and helped initiate newborn hearing screening in Queensland hospitals, the first such program in Australia. She has received [[Australian of the Year]] for Queensland in 2003, and the Suncorp [[Queensland Day|Queenslander of the Year]] in 2010.<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=http://www.couriermail.com.au/news/queensland/dimity-dornan-awarded-queenslander-of-the-year/news-story/0186e0e55a77829692eb2b4a3a2d8158?sv=872e7caa2fd36c93485f88a93daf5615|title=Dimity Dornan awarded Queenslander of the Year|last=|first=|date=1 June 2010|website=Courier Mail|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=7 August 2017}}</ref><ref name=":2">{{Cite web|url=http://www.abc.net.au/radionational/programs/breakfast/in-conversation-with-dimity-dornan/3437430|title=In Conversation with Dimity Dornan|last=Kelly|first=Fran|date=6 January 2005|website=ABC Radio National|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171222194326/http://www.abc.net.au/radionational/programs/breakfast/in-conversation-with-dimity-dornan/3437430|archive-date=22 December 2017|dead-url=no|access-date=7 August 2017|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
== Career == Dornan has been attributed for her ground-breaking auditory verbal work which has assisted families and hearing-impaired children throughout Queensland. The Hear and Say Centre is now a global Hearing Health Education and Development Program with six centres across Queensland, including a telepractice for remote regions of Queensland.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://jvtrust.org.au/case-studies/|title=Family training sessions in listening and spoken language therapy|last=|first=|date=|website=John Villiers Trust|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170808153810/http://jvtrust.org.au/case-studies/|archive-date=8 August 2017|dead-url=no|access-date=8 August 2017|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
Dornan is the founder of Bionics Queensland (BioniQ) which was established to promote the development of the human bionic industry in Queensland.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://www.bionicsqueensland.com.au/meet-dr-dimity-dornan/|title=Meet Dr Dimity Dornan|last=|first=|date=|website=Bionics Queensland|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170807152947/http://www.bionicsqueensland.com.au/meet-dr-dimity-dornan/|archive-date=7 August 2017|dead-url=no|access-date=7 August 2017|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
Dornan is also the founder of Human Bionics Interface, which an international network of bionics researchers, clinicians, businesses that share projects to delivery [[bionics]] solutions.<ref name=":0" />
== Achievements == In 2017, Dornan was inducted into the [[Queensland Business Leaders Hall of Fame]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://leaders.slq.qld.gov.au/inductees/dr-dimity-dornan-ao/|title=Dr Dimity Dornan AO|last=|first=|date=|website=[[Queensland Business Leaders Hall of Fame]]|publisher=[[State Library of Queensland]]|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170807112255/http://leaders.slq.qld.gov.au/inductees/dr-dimity-dornan-ao/|archive-date=7 August 2017|dead-url=no|access-date=7 August 2017}}</ref>
In October 2017, Dornan was elected to the [[University of Queensland]] Senate by the graduates of the university.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://senate.uq.edu.au/elections|title=Elected positions to the 34th Senate (2018-2021)|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=[[University of Queensland]]|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171107081703/https://senate.uq.edu.au/elections|archive-date=7 November 2017|dead-url=no|access-date=7 November 2017}}</ref>
In 2003 she received [[Australian of the Year]] for Queensland, and in 2010 the Suncorp [[Queensland Day|Queenslander of the Year]].<ref name=":1" /><ref name=":2" />
== Awards == * Churchill Fellowship 1992 * Member of the Order of Australia 1998 * Fellow of Speech Pathology Australia 1999 * Australian Medical Association (AMA) Award for Distinction for Services to Medicine 1999 * Australian of the Year for Queensland 2003 * Ernst & Young Australian Social Entrepreneur of the Year 2005 * Suncorp Queenslander of the Year 2010 * University of Queensland Alumnus of the Year 2011 * [[Queensland Greats Awards|Queensland Greats]] 2013 * Dame of Honour 2013 * Order of St John 2013 * Officer of the Order of Australia 2014 * Lord Mayor's Business Awards, Lifetime Achievement Award 2014 * McCullough Robertson Life Sciences Queensland Industry Excellence Award 2015 * Women in Technology Life Sciences Award 2016 * Brisbane Women in Business Award (Innovation and Technology) 2016 * Women in Technology Life Sciences Outstanding Achievement Award 2016 * Women in Business Innovation and Technology Award 2016 <ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.australiaday.org.au/ambassadors/view/?id=330|title=Ambassadors - Australia Day|website=Australia Day|access-date=7 August 2017|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170807153704/https://www.australiaday.org.au/ambassadors/view/?id=330|archivedate=7 August 2017|df=dmy-all}}</ref> * [[Queensland Business Leaders Hall of Fame]] 2017 * Queensland Senior Australian of the Year 2018 <ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.australianoftheyear.org.au/news-and-media/tour-of-honour-2013/news-and-media/news/article/?id=2018-queensland-australian-of-the-year-awards-recipients-announced |title=Australian of the Year Awards |website=National Australia Day Council |date=8 November 2017 |access-date=21 December 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171222194326/https://www.australianoftheyear.org.au/news-and-media/tour-of-honour-2013/news-and-media/news/article/?id=2018-queensland-australian-of-the-year-awards-recipients-announced |archivedate=22 December 2017 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
== References == <references />
== External links == * [http://leaders.slq.qld.gov.au/inductees/dr-dimity-dornan-ao/ Queensland Business Leaders Hall of Fame] * [http://www.wit.org.au/ Women in Technology] * [https://www.dss.gov.au/our-responsibilities/disability-and-carers/program-services/for-people-with-disability/better-start-for-children-with-disability-initiative/service-providers/hear-and-say-centre-for-deaf/hearing-impaired-children-and-their-families Disability and carers] * [http://onesearch.slq.qld.gov.au/SLQ:SLQ_PCI_EBSCO:slq_alma21125590700002061 State Library of Queensland - The Petrie Family] * [http://onesearch.slq.qld.gov.au/SLQ:SLQ_PCI_EBSCO:slq_alma21120984590002061 State Library of Queensland - Alice with eyes a-shine] * [http://onesearch.slq.qld.gov.au/SLQ:SLQ_PCI_EBSCO:TN_proquest1883216607 State Library of Queensland - Proquest - Social inclusion for children with hearing loss in listening and spoken Language early intervention: an exploratory study] * [http://onesearch.slq.qld.gov.au/SLQ:SLQ_PCI_EBSCO:TN_proquest1808851048 State Library of Queensland - Proquest - Exploring the impact of spoken language on social inclusion for children with hearing loss ...] * [https://www.hearandsay.com.au/ Hear and Say] * [http://www.bionicsqueensland.com.au/Bionics Queensland] * [https://www.australianoftheyear.org.au/the-awards/award-categories/senior-australian-of-the-year/ Senior Australian of the Year Awards]
{{authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Dornan, Dimity}} [[Category:Speech and language pathologists]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Officers of the Order of Australia]] [[Category:Australian businesspeople]] [[Category:Australian of the Year Award winners]] [[Category:Fellows of the Australian Academy of Technological Sciences and Engineering]] [[Category:Queensland Business Leaders Hall of Fame inductees]]
