revision.text:
{{Infobox person | name = Jaime Chicharro Sánchez-Guió | image = Jaime Chicharro.JPG | image_size = | alt = | caption = | birth_name = Jaime Chicharro Sánchez-Guió | birth_date = 1889 | birth_place = [[Torralba de Calatrava]], Spain | death_date = 1934 | death_place = [[Guadarrama]], Spain | body_discovered = | death_cause = | resting_place = | resting_place_coordinates = <!-- {{coord|LAT|LONG|display=inline,title}} --> | residence = | nationality = [[Spain|Spanish]] | citizenship = | other_names = | known_for = Politician | education = | alma_mater = | employer = | notable works = | occupation = lawyer, landowner | years_active = | home_town = | salary = | networth = | height = | weight = | title = | term = | predecessor = | successor = | party = [[:es:Comunión Católico-Monárquica|Comunión Católico-Monárquica]], [[Liberal-Conservative Party (Spain)|Conservative Party]], [[:es:Partido Católico Nacional|Partido Católico Nacional]], [[Spanish Patriotic Union|Union Patriotica]], [[Comunión Tradicionalista]] | opponents = | boards = | spouse = | partner = | children = | parents = | relations = | callsign = | awards = | signature = | signature_alt = | website = | footnotes = | box_width = | misc = }} '''Jaime Chicharro Sánchez-Guió''' (1889 - 1934) was a Spanish [[Liberal-Conservative Party (Spain)|Conservative]] and [[Carlism|Carlist]] politician. He is known mostly as the moving spirit behind turning a fishing bay in [[Burriana]] into a modern port, facilitating export of oranges grown in the area. As a politician he is recognized as representative of large proprietors within the Carlist movement.
==Family and youth== [[File:Ermitacristo.JPG|thumbnail|left|[[Torralba de Calatrava]]]] Jaime Chicharro Sánchez-Guió was born to a family of [[Castile (historical region)|Castilian]] landowners. His paternal ancestors originated from [[Names of the Basque Country (in Spanish)|Vascongadas]]; his grandfather, [[Jesús Chicharro de la Torre]], was a military engineer and settled in the [[province of Ciudad Real]] following railway construction works.<ref>''Biografia sucinta de D. Jaime Chicharro'', [in:] ''Buris-Ana. Boletín de la Agrupación Burrianense de Cultura'' 77 (1958), p. 2</ref> Jaime’s father, [[José Chicharro Martín del Moral]] (1856-1905),<ref>José Chicharro Martín del Moral entry at Geneanet genealogical service, available [http://gw.geneanet.org/sanchiz?lang=en&p=jose&n=chicharro+martin+del+moral here]</ref> sided with the legitimists during the [[Third Carlist War]].<ref>''Nota biográfica sobre Jaime Chicharro y Sánchez-Guio (1889-1934)'', [in:] ''CED Borriana'', 08.03.2014, available [https://cedborriana.wordpress.com/2014/03/08/nota-biografica-sobre-jaime-chicharro-y-sanchez-guio-1889-1934/ here]; the same source claims, probably after ''Biografia sucinta de D. Jaime Chicharro'', that he reached the rank of a general, though it is not clear how and when he could have reached this honor</ref> He married Soledad Sánchez-Guió Ruiz-Hidalgo (1860-1912).<ref>Soledad Sánchez-Guio Ruiz-Hidalgo entry at ''Geneanet'' genealogical service, available [http://gw.geneanet.org/sanchiz?lang=en&p=jose&n=chicharro+martin+del+moral here]</ref> The couple had 4 children, apart from Jaime also three daughters,<ref>''Biografia sucinta de D. Jaime Chicharro'', p. 2; some sources indicate 2 sisters, see ''Geneanet'' service available [http://gw.geneanet.org/sanchiz?lang=en&p=jose&n=chicharro+martin+del+moral here]</ref> all raised in a fervently Catholic ambience.
In 1897 the young Jaime entered the [[Jesuit]] Colegio Nuestra Señora del Recuerdo in the [[Madrid]] district of [[Chamartín (Madrid)|Chamartín de la Rosa]].<ref>''ABC'' 14.01.34 available [http://hemeroteca.abc.es/nav/Navigate.exe/hemeroteca/madrid/abc/1934/01/14/046.html here], ''Biografia sucinta de D. Jaime Chicharro''</ref> Having completed secondary education he moved to [[Biscay]] commencing law studies in the Jesuit [[University of Deusto|Deusto College]].<ref>Guillem Rios, ''Un paseo por el cemeterio (parte I)'', [in:] ''elperiodic.com'' 01.11.07, available [http://www.elperiodic.com/burriana/reportajes/4613_paseo-cementerio-parte.html here], ''Biografia sucinta de D. Jaime Chicharro'', p. 2</ref> Following graduation he completed his education obtaining diploma in Philosophy and Letters from the [[:es:Universidad de Madrid|Universidad Central]] (later [[Universidad Complutense]]) in Madrid.<ref>''ABC'' 14.01.34, ''Biografia sucinta de D. Jaime Chicharro'', p. 2</ref> Holding two diplomas he settled in Madrid and assumed the chair of History in same Jesuit college he had attended earlier.<ref>''Nota biográfica sobre Jaime Chicharro y Sánchez-Guio (1889-1934)''</ref>
In 1912 Chicharro married Dolores Lamamié de Clairac Romero y Bermúdez de Castro (1890-1974),<ref>''Dolores Lamamie de Clairac Romero'' entry at ''Geni'' genealogical service, available [http://www.geni.com/people/Dolores-Lamamie-de-Clairac-Romero/6000000024129494509 here]</ref> sister of the [[Salamanca province|Salamanca]] landowner and later a well-known Carlist politician, [[José María Lamamié de Clairac|José María Lamamié de Clairac y de la Colina]]. As she inherited some 300 hectares<ref>''Biografia sucinta de D. Jaime Chicharro'', p. 2</ref> around [[Villarreal]] and [[Nules]], the family moved to the spouse's La Salmantina estate, now located in the municipality of [[Les Alqueries]] ([[Castellón province]]).<ref>''Nota biográfica sobre Jaime Chicharro y Sánchez-Guio (1889-1934)'', ''Biografia sucinta de D. Jaime Chicharro'', p. 2</ref> The couple had 13 children,<ref>''CHICHARRO LAMAMIÉ DE CLAIRAC, Antonio'' thread at ''Memoriablau'' service, available [http://memoriablau.foros.ws/t1881/chicharro-lamamie-de-clairac-antonio-caido/ here]</ref> born between 1914 and 1932. During early months of the [[Spanish Civil War|Civil War]] the oldest daughter was tortured and killed by the [[Republican faction (Spanish Civil War)|Republican]] militia in Madrid.<ref>in 1936 or 1937, dates given differ; ''Hércules Cortez'', [in:] ''Club de Boxeo Paulino Uzcudun'' service 03.11.11, available [http://clubdeboxeopaulinouzcudun.blogspot.com/2011/11/hercules-cortez.html here]</ref> Five sons volunteered to the Carlist [[Requeté]];<ref>''Hércules Cortez'', [in:] ''Club de Boxeo Paulino Uzcudun'' service 03.11.11</ref> one of them died in 1939 due to tortures suffered as the Republican [[Prisoner of war|POW]].<ref>''CHICHARRO LAMAMIÉ DE CLAIRAC, Antonio'' thread at ''Memoriablau'' service; other version is that he suffered fatal cardial breakdown having the learnt the fate of his sister Maria Dolores, see ''Nota biográfica sobre Jaime Chicharro y Sánchez-Guio (1889-1934)''</ref> Four sons joined [[División Azul]]; two of them died in combat in [[Russia]], the two who survived grew to [[Francoist]] generals.<ref>Juan Chicharro Ortega, ''La división española de voluntarios en Rusia'', [in:] ''ABC'' 17.07.10, available [http://www.abc.es/20100717/latercera/division-espanola-voluntarios-rusia-20100717.html herel]</ref> His second youngest son served as a diplomat and subgobernador in the [[History of Equatorial Guinea|Spanish Equatorial Guinea]].<ref>Rios 2008</ref> The youngest son became sort of celebrity as a [[wrestling]] champion in the 1950s.<ref>''Hércules Cortez'', [in:] ''Club de Boxeo Paulino Uzcudun'' service 03.11.11, ''Hércules Cortez: el mejor wrestler español de la historia'', [in:] ''Se-Puto-Acabó'' service available [http://seputoacabo.blogspot.com/2010/11/el-mejor-wrestler-de-la-historia-de.html here]</ref> Some of Jaime's grandchildren became public figures and stirred political controversy as late as in 2013.<ref>see ''El Pais'' 27.02.13, available [http://politica.elpais.com/politica/2013/02/27/actualidad/1361994938_586044.html here] and ''alertadigital'' service 27.02.13, available [http://www.alertadigital.com/2013/02/28/juan-antonio-chicharro-general-de-division-la-patria-vale-mas-que-la-democracia/ here]</ref>
==Young Carlist== [[File:Juan Vazquez de Mella 1906.JPG|thumbnail|160px|left|[[Juan Vazquez de Mella]]]] Chicharro inherited his militant ultraconservative outlook after his father, who following the Carlist war service contributed belligerent pieces to the Carlist [[Ciudad Real]] based ''El Manchego'' weekly in the 1880s.<ref>he contributed under the pen-name “K. Tite” and his article prompted penalty action against the review, see José Narvaez Fernández ''“El Manchego” (1886-1888). La prensa carlista a traves de un periodico regional'', [in:] ''Cuadernos de estudios manchegos'' 8 (1978), p. 101</ref> The leaning was further reinforced when during his Madrid academic years Chicharro met and got fascinated by [[Juan Vázquez de Mella]], the top Carlist theorist.<ref>''Emotivo homenaje a D. Jaime Chicharro en su pueblo natal, Torralba de Calatrava'', [in:] ''Buris-Ana'' 145 (1976), p. 2</ref> In 1909 he co-founded the local Centro Tradicionalista<ref>''Biografia sucinta de D. Jaime Chicharro'', p. 2</ref> and together with other young Carlists he set up ''El Combate'',<ref>''Emotivo homenaje a D. Jaime Chicharro en su pueblo natal, Torralba de Calatrava'', [in:] ''Buris-Ana'' 145 (1976), p. 2</ref> a review later renamed to ''Juventud Tradicionalista''.<ref>''Nota biográfica sobre Jaime Chicharro y Sánchez-Guio (1889-1934)''</ref> Active in Catholic organizations, he started to appear on public meetings, like those confronting the idea of secular education.<ref>''El Siglo Futuro'' 19.04.10, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000288832&page=1 here]</ref> In 1911 he engaged in launching Congreso Eucaristico and later joined [[:es:Asociación Católica de Propagandistas|Junta Nacional de Propagandistas de Acción Católica]].<ref>''Nota biográfica sobre Jaime Chicharro y Sánchez-Guio (1889-1934)''; the organization is also referred to as Asociación católioo-nacional de jóvenes propagandistas, see ''El Siglo Futuro'' 09.06.10, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000289855&page=1 here]</ref> Also in 1911 Chicharro joined the Madrid Junta Católica, part of a national electoral effort engineered by the Church and intended to produce a grand Catholic political alliance.<ref>''El Siglo Futuro'' 07.01.11, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000294472&page=1 here]</ref> At that time he was already a Carlist activist recognized nationally.<ref>the newly created Juventud Carlista in Plasencia, a town in Northern Extremadura, asked Chicharro to be – along the likes of Esteban Bilbao or Rafael Pérez Aguago – its honorary president, Rodolfo Orantos Martín, ''El desconocido carlismo placentino. Represión, Exilio y Memoria Histórica'', [in:] ''Memoria histórica de Plasencia y las comarcas'', Plasencia 2014, {{ISBN|9788469708583}}, p. 99</ref>
When following his marriage Chicharro moved to Castellón province he remained in the same political ambience, becoming president of the local Juventud Jaimista<ref>in 1914 he was already reported as former president, ''El Liberal'' 14.10.14, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0001710444&page=3 here]</ref> and in 1915 growing to jefe of the Villareal Jaimistas.<ref>reported as hosting Cerralbo during his tours across the country, ''El Liberal'' 14.10.14, also ''La Correspondencia de España'' 01.11.15, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000704387&page=7 here]</ref> In 1916 he entered the Castellón Junta Provincial and became its vice-president, going on with his Villarreal jefatura duties.<ref>Gerard Llansola, ''Estructura organizativa i participació electoral del carlisme castellonenc en la decadéncia de la Restauració (1914-1918)'', [in:] Rosa Monlleó Peris, ''Castelló al segle XX'', Valencia 2006, {{ISBN|848021564X}}, 9788480215640, p. 212</ref> The same year for the first time he launched his bid for the [[Cortes Generales|Cortes]] standing in the Nules district. At that time Valencian Carlism was divided between the mainstream purs and the dissident paquistes,<ref>Llansola 2006, p. 221</ref> followers of [[Francisco Giner Lila]];<ref>''Nota biográfica sobre Jaime Chicharro y Sánchez-Guio (1889-1934)''</ref> Chicharro seemed to have allied with none and unsuccessfully ran a broad conservative ticket, forming part of the contenders loyal to the [[Murcia]]n party leader, [[Juan de la Cierva y Peñafiel]].<ref>''Nota biográfica sobre Jaime Chicharro y Sánchez-Guio (1889-1934)''; overview of electoral results in Castellon in 1913-1916 in Gerard Llansola Gil, ''Republicanisme, identitat popular i hegemonia municipal: Castelló de la Plana, 1913-1917'', Castellon 2006, {{ISBN|8480215690}}, 9788480215695, p. 89</ref> [[File:Juan de la Cierva Peñafiel.jpg|160px|thumbnail|[[Juan de la Cierva y Peñafiel|Juan de la Cierva]]]] He tried his luck again in Nules in the subsequent [[Spanish general election, 1918|campaign of 1918]], though political configuration of the time seems particularly obscure and illegible. According to some, he represented the purs faction and was supported by a partially controlled newspaper, ''La Gaceta de Levante'',<ref>Llansola 2006, p. 228, also ''El Sol'' 06.02.18, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000184427&page=4 here]</ref> opposed by the competing paquistes fraction and the conservative [[Antonio Maura|mauristas]].<ref>Llansola 2006, p. 228</ref> According to another scholar, Chicharro was criticized by orthodox Carlists for his strong predilection for broad Right-wing alliances, blurring the [[Traditionalism (Spain)|Traditionalist]] political identity.<ref>Juan Ramón de Andrés Martín, ''El cisma mellista. Historia de una ambición política'', Madrid 2000, {{ISBN|9788487863820}}, p. 134</ref> He lost again, failing to get the ticket also in by-elections staged later that year as the victorious candidate died soon after having been elected.<ref>''Nota biográfica sobre Jaime Chicharro y Sánchez-Guio (1889-1934)'', Llansola 2006, p. 228; many picturesque details available [http://vicentesgrangel.blogspot.com/2013/06/elecciones-en-el-distrito-de-llucena-ii.html here]</ref>
==''Mellista''== [[File:Jaime de Borbón y Borbón-Parma.png|thumbnail|left|''S. M. Jaime III'', 1912]] In the 1910s Carlism was increasingly divided between its top theorist Juan Vazquez de Mella and the claimant, [[Jaime, Duke of Madrid|Jaime III]]; the former tended to downplay dynastical issues for the sake of advancing a grand Right-wing formation, united by Traditionalist values. Chicharro sympathised with his former Madrid master and emerged as one of the most vehement Mella supporters;<ref>along Pradera, Garcia Guijarro, Careaga, Iglesias and [[José Pascual de Liñán y Eguizábal|conde Doña Marina]], Andrés Martín 2000, pp. 146-7</ref> when in 1919 the crisis exploded and the Carlists were forced to take sides, he left the claimant and joined the rebels.<ref>Andrés Martín 2000, p. 146</ref> In the [[Spanish general election, 1919|1919 electoral campaign]] he already represented a broad and somewhat vague conservative platform, advocating a broad Catholic national party of the Right.<ref>''La Epoca'' 11.08.19, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000918904&page=1 here]</ref> Some sources claim he counted among governmental [[maurista]] candidates,<ref>Andrés Martín 2000, p. 171, this version confirmed also in ''El Sol'' 03.06.19, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000209693&page=4 here]</ref> some present him as a catholic-monarchist, a ciervista<ref>''La Epoca'' 24.05.19, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000913866&page=3 here]</ref> or a Carlist.<ref>''La Correspondencia de España'' 25.05.19, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000791838&page=6 here]</ref> Finally successful,<ref>see the official Cortes service available [http://www.congreso.es/portal/page/portal/Congreso/Congreso/Iniciativas?_piref73_2148295_73_1335437_1335437.next_page=/wc/servidorCGI&CMD=VERLST&BASE=DIPH&FMT=DIPHXD1S.fmt&DOCS=1-1&DOCORDER=FIFO&OPDEF=Y&NUM1=&DES1=&QUERY=%2825840%29.NDIP. here]</ref> when in the Cortes he sided with the ciervistas.<ref>Andrés Martín 2000, p. 175</ref> In [[Spanish general election, 1920|1920 re-election campaign]] Chicharro had the loyal Carlists pitted against him,<ref>''ABC'' 17.11.20, available [http://hemeroteca.abc.es/nav/Navigate.exe/hemeroteca/madrid/abc/1920/11/17/009.html here]</ref> but he managed to renew his ticket<ref>as a ciervista, see ''La Acción'' 10.11.20, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0003573379&page=3 here]</ref> and served in the diet until 1923.<ref>see the official Cortes service, available [http://www.congreso.es/portal/page/portal/Congreso/Congreso/Iniciativas?_piref73_2148295_73_1335437_1335437.next_page=/wc/servidorCGI&CMD=VERLST&BASE=DIPH&FMT=DIPHXD1S.fmt&DOCS=2-2&DOCORDER=FIFO&OPDEF=Y&NUM1=&DES1=&QUERY=%2825840%29.NDIP. here]</ref>
In the parliament, at that time dominated by the Conservatives of [[Eduardo Dato]], Chicharro remained a rather restless and turbulent deputy, occasionally sliding to opposition. Apart from the customary anti-liberal diatribes, he was particularly vocal on financial issues, entering into taxation and budgetary disputes with the Minister of Economy.<ref>''La Correspondencia de España'' 19.03.20, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000805923&page=1 here]</ref> His most lasting achievement is a Royal Order, which marked significant state resources for development of the local [[Burriana]] harbor.<ref>''Nota biográfica sobre Jaime Chicharro y Sánchez-Guio (1889-1934)'', Rios 2008</ref> The design, apart from massive upgrade of the facilities, envisaged also major investments which connected the port with the national railroad network.<ref>''La familia Chicharro dona a Burriana un plano del proyecto del ferrocarril de la Vilavella al Puerto'' [in:] ''buriana.es'' service 02.03.11, available [http://www.burriana.es/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=663:la-familia-chicharro-dona-a-burriana-un-plano-del-proyecto-del-ferrocarril-de-la-vilavella-al-puerto&catid=1:actualidad&Itemid=180 here]</ref> The work was carried out until the early 1930s and transformed what used to be chiefly a simple fishing bay<ref>compare ''Naranjas: cuando no existía el puerto en Burriana'' [in:] ''wikisenior'' service, available [http://mayores.uji.es/wiki/index.php?title=Naranjas:_cuando_no_exist%C3%ADa_el_puerto_en_Burriana here]</ref> into a small but modern commercial transport hub.<ref>''Nota biográfica sobre Jaime Chicharro y Sánchez-Guio (1889-1934)'', Rios 2008</ref> Key beneficiaries of the project were the local Levantine landowners, who gained a gateway for the export of their orange production;<ref>Chicharro was himself member of the local Circulo Frutero and Agrupación de Exportadores, María Dolores Agustí, ''Juan Bautista Soler y Martí, representante del comercio naranjero en Burriana (1879-1936)'', [in:] Rosa Monlleó Peris [ed.], ''Castello Al Segle XX'', Castellon 2006, {{ISBN|9788480215640}}, p. 248. The traditional Valencian agricultural specialty was silk, but silk blight and growing competition pushed Valencian silk out of many markets in mid-19th century. Following unsuccessful reformatting to vineyards, it was the oranges, until late 18th century considered decorative plants, which became iconic Valencian products. As living standards rose and transport network improved, Valencian oranges became a commercial success with exports especially to Britain, France and Germany, see Julia Hudson-Richards, ''The Orange Proletariat: Social Relations in the Pais Valenciano, 1860--1939'' [PhD thesis University of Arizona], Phoenix 2008, {{ISBN|054968333X}}, 9780549683339, pp. 22-25</ref> Chicharro kept lobbying for their cause in Madrid also during the decades to come.<ref>he was reported as active in 1928, see ''El Imparcial'' 21.07.28, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0001026056&page=16 here] and in 1931, see ''Heraldo de Madrid'' 22.01.31, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000963575&page=14 here]</ref> In recognition of his merits, the city of Burriana named Chicharro its hijo adoptivo;<ref>Rios 2008</ref> upon his return from Madrid he was greeted with arches of triumph and venerating celebrations.<ref>''Biografia sucinta de D. Jaime Chicharro'', p. 2</ref> [[File:IOTT.18.77.JPG|thumbnail|oranges from [[Burriana]]]] Though initially one of the most outspoken de Mella supporters, Chicharro did not integrate fully in the [[Mellismo|Mellista]] group; some speak even of “chicharrismo”,<ref>Andrés Martín 2000, p. 162</ref> others dubbed him “mauro-ciervista”.<ref>Andrés Martín 2000, pp. 200-1</ref> While de Mella was firm on his Traditionalist principles and opted for a grand conservative party built upon them, Chicharro started to lean towards the vision of [[Víctor Pradera Larumbe|Victor Pradera]], embracing a more loose Right-wing alliance held together by a lowest common denominator.<ref>which was also reflected by the fact that in the Cortes he sided with the ciervistas, not the mauristas, Andrés Martín 2000, p. 182</ref> In the early 1920s he effectively left the Mellistas; some scholars consider him paradigmatic for many rebellious Carlists who joined de Mella in 1919, but soon abandoned him to pursue their own goals and to amalgamate in other Right-wing groupings.<ref>Andrés Martín 2000, p. 201</ref>
==Catholic conservative== [[File:Bundesarchiv Bild 102-09414, Primo de Rivera.jpg|thumbnail|160px|left|[[Primo de Rivera]]]] During [[Spanish general election, 1923|electoral campaign of 1923]] Chicharro was considered a favourite.<ref>''La Acción'' 26.03.23, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0003611636&page=5 here]</ref> It is not clear to what extent he ruined his chances himself: during one of electoral meetings in the very city of Burriana he was challenged by a local workers’ leader. Chicharro resolved to a stick and engaged in a brawl, resulting in his victim treated in hospital for head wounds and an administrative action taken against the assailant.<ref>''La Epoca'' 07.02.23, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000971195&page=3 here], ''Heraldo de Madrid'' 07.02.23, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000801691&page=1 here], ''El Sol'' 07.02.23, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000267737&page=2 here]</ref> ''Diario de Castellón'', the newspaper he founded and owned, failed to mobilize enough support and produced merely significant financial losses.<ref>''Biografia sucinta de D. Jaime Chicharro'', p. 2</ref> Eventually Chicharro and an albista counter-candidate recorded almost the same score; the latter was declared victorious following behind-the-scene dealings.<ref>''Biografia sucinta de D. Jaime Chicharro'', p. 2</ref>
In 1924 Chicharro was active setting up the local Castellon branch of [[Spanish Patriotic Union|Union Patriotica]]<ref>Raul González Devís, ''Católico y autoritarios: la dictadura de Primo de Rivera en las comarcas castellonenses'', [in:] Carlos Navajas Zubeldía, Diego Iturriaga Barco (eds.), ''Novísima: II Congreso Internacional de Historia de Nuestro Tiempo'', Logroño 2010, {{ISBN|9788469365571}}, p. 239</ref> and soon became its provincial jefe.<ref>González Devís 2010, p. 241</ref> In the new partido unico he championed the Catholic-based branch and got increasingly alienated by what he perceived as marginalization of the Catholic groupings; other local upetistas accused him of building the local structures chiefly around his former Traditionalist supporters.<ref>Chicharro was attacked by “elementos de derecha”, which proves that it was possible to be more Right-wing than himself, González Devís 2010, p. 241</ref> The conflict climaxed in 1925, when Chicharro in protest resigned from the provincial presidency.<ref>González Devís 2010, p. 241 (see also the footnote)</ref>
In 1925 the Chicharros left [[Levante, Spain|Levante]] and moved to Madrid; it is not clear whether the change was anyhow related to political tension or was rather due to financial issues, as reported by some sources;<ref>''Biografia sucinta de D. Jaime Chicharro'', p. 2; nothing is known about the fate of Chicharro’s landholdings, though he must have felt financial pressure by rapid growth of his family, children born almost every year</ref> In the capital he started to practice as a lawyer<ref>''ABC'' 12.07.28, available [http://hemeroteca.abc.es/nav/Navigate.exe/hemeroteca/madrid/abc/1928/07/12/024.html here]</ref> and apparently became fairly successful, as in the early 1930s he grew to member of Junta de Gobierno of the Madrid Congregacion de los Abogados.<ref>''ABC'' 12.02.33, available [http://hemeroteca.abc.es/nav/Navigate.exe/hemeroteca/sevilla/abc.sevilla/1933/02/12/028.html here]</ref> [[File:Madrid. La Cibeles square.jpg|thumbnail|160px|ayuntamiento of Madrid]] In 1927 Chicharro commenced his career as municipal official, appointed one of 64 new councilors of the Madrid [[ayuntamiento]].<ref>''La Voz'' 16.12.27, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000846146&page=12 here], ''ABC'' 20.12.27, available [http://hemeroteca.abc.es/nav/Navigate.exe/hemeroteca/madrid/abc/1927/12/20/021.html here]</ref> In 1928 he grew to teniente de alcalde<ref>''La Construccion Moderna'' 15.07.28, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0002014454&page=1 here]</ref> responsible for the [[Chamberi|Chamberí]] district; appointed member of Junta municipal de Primera enseñanza he specialized in education issues,<ref>''La Voz'' 23.12.27, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000846334&page=4 here]</ref> dealing also with culture<ref>organising Juegos Florales, ''El Siglo Futuro'' 08.03.27, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000430418&page=3 here]</ref> and science.<ref>he supported pre-historical studies, Anuario de prehistoria madrileña 1930, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0004949421&page=291 here]</ref> Chicharro resumed contacts with Vázquez de Mella;<ref>de Mella greeted Chicharro with his own photo signed “A mi entrañable amigo el heroico Chicharro”, ''La Correspondencia militar'' 29.11.29, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0002250152&page=4 here], see also ''ABC'' 20.12.27, available [http://hemeroteca.abc.es/nav/Navigate.exe/hemeroteca/madrid/abc/1927/12/20/021.html here]</ref> only weeks after his death, in March 1928, he arranged for a commemorative plaque to be mounted on the Escuela Normal de Maestros wall<ref>''ABC'' 25.03.27, available [http://hemeroteca.abc.es/nav/Navigate.exe/hemeroteca/madrid/abc/1928/03/25/027.html here]</ref> and looked after his library.<ref>''El Sol'' 22.11.29, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000410303&page=1 here]</ref> In 1930 the press already referred to him as former [[:es:Teniente de alcalde|teniente de alcalde]], but it is not clear when he ceased.<ref>''La Voz'' 26.03.30, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000886537&page=2 here] </ref>
During the last years of the monarchy Chicharro seemed politically disoriented. Though in the press plebiscite he was voted one of three best possible representatives of Castellon province in [[:es:Asamblea Nacional Consultiva|Asamblea Nacional]],<ref>''La Correspondencia de España'' 17.09.27, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0002220512&page=3 here]</ref> he was not appointed its member. He remained active in Catholic groupings like Acción social, giving lectures and contributing as organizer and manager. As friend of Lamamié he maintained links with his Acción Castellana, set up in 1930, and was drawn closer to another of his organizations, [[Federación Católico-Agraria Salmantina]].<ref>''ABC'' 26.01.27, available [http://hemeroteca.abc.es/nav/Navigate.exe/hemeroteca/madrid/abc/1927/01/26/023.html here]</ref> He remained in the circle of [[Francesc Cambó]], leader of the [[Catalans|Catalan]] conservative [[Regionalist League|Lliga Regionalista]].<ref>''ABC'' 17.02.31, available [http://hemeroteca.abc.es/nav/Navigate.exe/hemeroteca/madrid/abc/1931/02/17/031.html here]</ref> Last but not least, he retained his Carlist contacts with the former mellistas,<ref>''Nota biográfica sobre Jaime Chicharro y Sánchez-Guio (1889-1934)'', Rios 2008</ref> now headed by the new leader, Victor Pradera.
==Reconciled Carlist== [[File:Fitxer Proclamació de la República Plaça Sant Jaume. Fotògraf Josep Maria Sagarra, 1931.jpg|thumbnail|left|Republic declared]] During the local elections of April 1931 Chicharro was overwhelmed by the republican tide and as an independent conservative candidate<ref>''La Voz'' 06.04.31, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000922880&page=4 here]</ref> he failed to get voted into the Madrid ayuntamiento.<ref>''Heraldo de Madrid'' 13.04.31, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000970313&page=7 here]</ref> After proclamation of the [[Second Spanish Republic|Republic]] he decided to take part in the [[Spanish general election, 1931|June 1931 elections]] to the Cortes from Castellón, still supported by ''Diario de Castellón'', officially the voice of [[Federación Castellonense de Sindicatos Agrícolas]].<ref>the newspaper retained an ultraconservative line, usually classified as a rightist or forming part of catolicismo agrario, see catolicos y autoritarios González Devís 2010, p. 241, ''Cronicas de Castellon'' service, available [http://80.59.153.180:85/cronicas/sxx.htm here]</ref> Chicharro was invited to join the [[Republicanism in Spain|Republicans]]; according to one source he boldly refused,<ref>quoted saying “si veinte años hubiera República en España, veinte años y un dia sería monárquico por tradición e ideales”, referred after ''Biografia sucinta de D. Jaime Chicharro'', p. 2</ref> but according to the press he was running as "derecha republicana".<ref>''La Voz'' 29.06.31, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000931439&page=7 here],</ref> The result was rather poor – some call it humiliating<ref>Martin Blinkhorn, ''Carlism and Crisis in Spain 1931-1939'', Cambridge 1975, {{ISBN|9780521207294}}, pp. 123, 333</ref> - since he arrived 11th with some 11 thousand votes out of 96,000 cast in the province.<ref>''La Voz'' 29.06.31, ''ABC'' 04.07.31, available [http://hemeroteca.abc.es/nav/Navigate.exe/hemeroteca/madrid/abc/1931/07/04/035.html here]</ref>
In late 1931 Chicharro started to attend Traditionalist meetings,<ref>''El Siglo Futuro'' 28.11.31, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000491659&page=2 here]</ref> gradually re-joining followers of the Carlist king and entering their new organization, [[:es:Comunión Tradicionalista|Comunión Tradicionalista]]. Though not counting among national leaders, in the press he emerged as one of the most-quoted Carlist speakers of the first half of 1932, extremely active touring the country and delivering public addresses. In January 1932 he already gave lecture about collaboration and Carlism;<ref>''El Siglo Futuro'' 15.01.32, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000493591&page=1 here]</ref> in February he presented a broad foreign policy program including control of [[Gibraltar]],<ref>''La Voz de las Patatas'' 24.04.16 available [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9TCN56ZUSD0 here]</ref> federation with [[Portugal]] and confederation with Latin American states,<ref>''El Siglo Futuro'' 16.02.32, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000494909&page=1 here]</ref> in March he labeled the proposed universal suffrage as unjust and lambasted the Republican government for overspending and highly inflated budget.<ref>''El Siglo Futuro'' 30.03.32, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000496640&page=1 here]</ref> The same month he triggered riots in [[Soria]] by proclaiming that he had no intention of surrendering an iota of his wealth without a fight.<ref>Blinkhorn 1975, p. 80</ref> In April he got his car stolen from the Madrid street.<ref>''La Correspondencia'' 10.04.32, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0002279642&page=2 here]</ref> A number of meetings with him taking part were suspended when already ongoing for fear of unrest.<ref>''ABC'' 14.01.34, available [http://hemeroteca.abc.es/nav/Navigate.exe/hemeroteca/madrid/abc/1934/01/14/046.html here], ''El Sol'' 28.06.32, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000476948&page=4 here]</ref> Late 1932 he started to write first-page newspaper pieces himself.<ref>''El Siglo Futuro'' 30.10.32, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000503063&page=1 here], ''El Siglo Futuro'' 09.11.32, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000503834&page=1 here]</ref> [[File:JoséSanjurjo.jpg|thumbnail|160px|José Sanjurjo]] In 1932 Chicharro got engaged in conspiracy of [[José Sanjurjo]], though no details are known.<ref>''Nota biográfica sobre Jaime Chicharro y Sánchez-Guio (1889-1934)''</ref> Following the disastrously failed coup he was identified as one of the culprits<ref>''El Siglo Futuro'' 17.06.32, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000499762&page=6 here]</ref> and became subject of the expropriation, designed to boost the floundering Agrarian Reform.<ref>Blinkhorn 1975, p. 92; it might not be unrelated that some sources claim he died „almost in poverty”, ''Emotivo homenaje a D. Jaime Chicharro en su pueblo natal, Torralba de Calatrava''</ref> Later that year two of his sons were detained and administrated exile in the [[Spanish Sahara]] outpost of [[Villa Cisneros]], which would soon turn into the Carlist hotbed.<ref>Blinkhorn 1975, p. 96</ref> Continuing with his tours across the country<ref>see e.g. ''El Siglo Futuro'' 10.04.33, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000509644&page=1 here], ''El Siglo Futuro'' 17.04.33, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000509898&page=1 here]</ref> later in 1933 he defended some of the Sanjuriada conspirators in court,<ref>''Heraldo de Madrid'' 04.05.33, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0001026694&page=15 here]</ref> though he was himself closely watched by the security<ref>''Heraldo de Madrid'' 01.03.33, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0001022249&page=9 here]</ref> and in May he faced trial for inflammatory speak.<ref>''El Siglo Futuro'' 25.05.33, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000511277&page=1 here]</ref>
==Last months== [[File:Flag of Cross of Burgundy.svg|thumbnail|left|Carlist standard]] In 1933 Chicharro was active mixing with the [[Alfonsism|Alfonsist]] monarchists in the Tradicionalistas y Renovación Española alliance; by the local Castellon Liaison Committee he was agreed to [[Electoral Carlism (Second Republic)|represent it in the forthcoming elections]].<ref>''ABC'' 28.10.33, available [http://hemeroteca.abc.es/nav/Navigate.exe/hemeroteca/madrid/abc/1933/10/28/019.html here], ''El Siglo Futuro'' 13.11.33, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000517860&page=3 here]</ref> This gained him hostility among new radical Carlist activists like [[Jaime del Burgo Torres|Jaime del Burgo]], who despised fraternization with caciques and debris of the Alfonsine monarchy. Moreover, for the Carlist youth the landowners like Lamamié and Chicharro became marked men as privileged section of politically dominant potentates, who are "obstructing the Agrarian Reform by the feudal egoism of the odious grandees of grain".<ref>Blinkhorn 1975, p. 172</ref> Though indeed within Carlism Chicharro formed the most reactionary faction, conservatism did not render him averse to new radical social movements.<ref>Blinkhorn 1975, p. 113</ref> Discussing [[Benito Mussolini]] and [[Adolf Hitler]] he declared that Traditionalism, “though not one and the same thing, is very sympathetic towards them, as they are waging war against [[Judaism]], [[freemasonry]] and [[Marxism]], building an organized corporative state. What is inacceptable to us is the state's overwhelming sovereignty and dominance. For us the family comes first, followed by municipality, region and state, which is the last element in this chain”.<ref>''ABC'' 14.03.33, available [http://hemeroteca.abc.es/nav/Navigate.exe/hemeroteca/sevilla/abc.sevilla/1933/03/14/019.html here]</ref>
Riding the wave of soaring rightist sympathies, in 1933 Chicharro was elected to the Madrid ayuntamiento from the Chamberí district.<ref>''Nota biográfica sobre Jaime Chicharro y Sánchez-Guio (1889-1934)''</ref> However, running on the Carlist ticket [[Spanish general election, 1933|to the Cortes]] from Castellón he narrowly lost,<ref>Ramon Puig, ''El Bienni Reformador a les comarques septentrionals de Castelló (1931-1933)'', [in:] Rosa Monlleó Peris [ed.], ''Castello Al Segle XX'', Castellon 2006, {{ISBN|9788480215640}}, p. 378, ''El Sol'' 05.12.33, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000515030&page=6 here]</ref> though initially he was reported by the press as victorious<ref>''El Siglo Futuro'' 22.11.33, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000518244&page=1 here]</ref> and his fellow Traditionalist [[Juan Granell Pascual]] was indeed elected.<ref>''Nota biográfica sobre Jaime Chicharro y Sánchez-Guio (1889-1934)''</ref> At that time he was already seriously ill.<ref>Agustí 2006, p. 249</ref> Having been generally of rather poor health, as a [[chain-smoker]] Chicharro developed grave respiratory problems.<ref>''La familia Chicharro dona a Buuriana'' [sic!]'' una librería que perteneció al artífice de la construcción del Puerto'', [in:] ''Diario digital de Castellon'' 01.11.13, available [http://www.castelloninformacion.com/familia-chicharro-libreria-burriana/ here]</ref> Though as late as 1932 he was still hailed by the press as “ilustrado joven”,<ref>''El Siglo Futuro'' 16.02.32, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000494909&page=1 here]</ref> in August 1933 he was placed in the [[tuberculosis]]-treatment Real Sanatorio de Guadarrama,<ref>''El Siglo Futuro'' 22.08.33, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000514534&page=1 here]</ref> where he died early 1934.<ref>Rios 2008</ref> His funeral and related commemorative homage feasts staged across Spain helped to mobilize support and demonstrated growing dynamics of Carlism.<ref>''El Siglo Futuro'' 13.01.34, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000520424&page=1 here], ''El Siglo Futuro'' 23.01.34, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000520757&page=2 here], ''El Siglo Futuro'' 05.03.34, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000522414&page=3 here]; the widow received a letter from the Carlist king Alfonso Carlos, ''El Siglo Futuro'' 25.01.34, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000520844&page=1 here]</ref> As the widow and 13 half-orphaned children were in financial dire straits, Comunión Tradicionalista launched a public fund-raising campaign intended to assist them.<ref>''El Siglo Futuro'' 01.03.34, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000522272&page=3 here]</ref>
==See also== * [[Carlism]] * [[Mellismo]] * [[José María Lamamié de Clairac]] * [[Juan Vázquez de Mella]] * [[Restoration (Spain)]] * [[Miguel Primo de Rivera]] * [[Second Spanish Republic]] * [[:es:Puerto de Burriana|Puerto de Burriana]]
==Footnotes== {{Reflist|3}}
==Further reading== * Juan Ramón de Andrés Martín, ''El cisma mellista. Historia de una ambición política'', Madrid 2000, {{ISBN|9788487863820}} * ''Biografia sucinta de D. Jaime Chicharro'', [in:] ''Buris-Ana. Boletín de la Agrupación Burrianense de Cultura'' 77 (1958), pp. 2, 13 * Martin Blinkhorn, ''Carlism and Crisis in Spain 1931-1939'', Cambridge 1975, {{ISBN|9780521207294}} * Pascual Fandos Mingarro, ''Biografía de Jaime Chicharro,'' Madrid 1961 * Raul González Devís, ''Católico y autoritarios: la dictadura de Primo de Rivera en las comarcas castellonenses'', [in:] Carlos Navajas Zubeldía, Diego Iturriaga Barco (eds.), ''Novísima: II Congreso Internacional de Historia de Nuestro Tiempo'', Logroño 2010, {{ISBN|9788469365571}}, pp. 235–244 * Gerard Llansola, ''Estructura organizativa i participació electoral del carlisme castellonenc en la decadéncia de la Restauració (1914-1918)'', [in:] Rosa Monlleó Peris [ed.], ''Castello Al Segle XX'', Castellon 2006, {{ISBN|9788480215640}}, pp. 207–236
==External links== [[File:J.Chicarro.JPG|thumbnail|monument to Chicharro in Burriana]] * [https://cedborriana.wordpress.com/2014/03/08/nota-biografica-sobre-jaime-chicharro-y-sanchez-guio-1889-1934/ Chicharro at CED Burriana website] * [http://www.congreso.es/portal/page/portal/Congreso/Congreso/SDocum/ArchCon/SDHistoDipu/SDIndHistDip?_piref73_1340024_73_1340023_1340023.next_page=/wc/servidorCGI&CMD=VERLST&BASE=DIPH&FMT=DIPHXLDA.fmt&DOCS=1-25&DOCORDER=FIFO&OPDEF=Y&QUERY=%2825840%29.NDIP. Historical Index of Deputies] * [http://memoriablau.foros.ws/t1881/chicharro-lamamie-de-clairac-antonio-caido/ Chicharro's offspring discussed at a Francoist forum] * [http://www.elperiodic.com/burriana/reportajes/4613_paseo-cementerio-parte.html a passage at the Castellon cemetery] * [http://www.burriana.es/agrupacio_borrianenca/pdf/Boletin_145.pdf homage to Chicharro by Torralba de Calatrava] * [http://gw.geneanet.org/sanchiz?lang=en;p=jose;n=chicharro+martin+del+moral Chicharro family at geneanet] * [http://mayores.uji.es/wiki/index.php?title=Naranjas:_cuando_no_exist%C3%ADa_el_puerto_en_Burriana history of the Burriana harbor] * [http://www.burriana.es/agrupacio_borrianenca/pdf/Boletin_51especial.pdf homage Buris-Ana issue] * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=tNLJwuZBDCQ old Burriana on video] * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?t=52&v=xSbnQOoDtms Chicharro's youngest son in commercial movie] * [http://www.alertadigital.com/2013/02/28/juan-antonio-chicharro-general-de-division-la-patria-vale-mas-que-la-democracia/ ''La patria vale más que la democracia'' by Chicharro's grandson] * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=uhK1ER3B4Hg contemporary Carlist propaganda video]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Chicharro Sanchez-Guio, Jaime}} [[Category:1889 births]] [[Category:1934 deaths]] [[Category:Corporatism]] [[Category:Spanish businesspeople]] [[Category:Carlists]] [[Category:Members of the Congress of Deputies]] [[Category:Popular Action (Spain) politicians]] [[Category:Spanish anti-communists]] [[Category:Spanish lawyers]] [[Category:Spanish monarchists]] [[Category:Spanish Roman Catholics]] [[Category:Landowners]] [[Category:University of Deusto]]

revision.comment: formatting, adding a link
revision.text:
A '''jobsworth''' is a person who uses their job description in a deliberately uncooperative way, or who seemingly delights in acting in an obstructive or unhelpful manner. The term can also be applied to those who uphold petty rules even at the expense of humanity or [[common sense]].
"Jobsworth" is a [[British English|British]] [[colloquial]]<ref name="OED" /><ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.macmillandictionary.com/dictionary/british/jobsworth | title=jobsworth – definition | work=Macmillan Dictionary | publisher = [[Macmillan Publishers]] | accessdate=30 January 2011 }}</ref> word derived from the phrase "I can't do that, it's more than my job's worth", meaning taking the initiative and performing an action that is beyond what the person feels is in their job description. The ''[[Oxford English Dictionary]]'' defines it as "A person in authority (esp. a minor official) who insists on adhering to rules and regulations or bureaucratic procedures even at the expense of common sense."<ref name="OED">2nd Edition, Oxford University Press</ref> [[Jonathon Green]] similarly defines "jobsworth" as "a minor [[wikt:factotum|factotum]] whose only status comes from enforcing otherwise petty regulations".<ref>{{cite book | title=The Macmillan Dictionary of Contemporary Slang | year=1995 | isbn=0-333-63407-1 | last=Green | first=Jonathon | publisher=[[Macmillan Publishers|Macmillan]] | coauthor= | authorlink=Jonathon Green}}</ref>
An example of the phrase which gave rise to the term occurs in the 1965 [[Beatles]] movie ''[[Help! (film)|Help!]]'', when [[Roy Kinnear]]'s character, the assistant scientist Algernon, exclaims "Well it's more than my job's worth to stop him when he's like this, he's out to rule the world...if he can get a government grant."
Another early use was by UK [[Folk music|folk]]-singer [[Jeremy Taylor (singer)|Jeremy Taylor]], in a song he wrote in the late 1960s: {{poemquote |text=Jobsworth, Jobsworth, It's more than me job's worth, I don't care, rain or snow, whatever you want the answer's no, I can keep you waiting for hours in the queue, and if you don't like it you know what you can do.}}
The term became widespread in [[vernacular]] English through its use in the popular 1970s [[BBC]] [[television]] programme ''[[That's Life!]]'' which featured [[Esther Rantzen]] covering various [[human interest]] and [[Consumerism|consumer]] topics. A "Jobsworth of the Week" commissionaire's hat was awarded each week to "a startling tale of going by the book".<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/597889.stm BBC News: "Your job's worth more than you are"].</ref>
The term remains in use, particularly in the UK, to characterise inflexible employees, petty rule-following and excessive administration.<ref>[https://publications.parliament.uk/pa/cm199596/cmhansrd/vo960501/debtext/60501-10.htm House of Commons Hansard Debates for 1 May 1996 (pt 10)] "There seems to be here an element of what might qualify for Esther Rantzen's "jobsworth" award. I would certainly like to look at it more closely. I will therefore follow up the matters that my hon. Friend has raised today, and I hope to be able to write to him in due course."</ref>
The slang expression "Little [[Hitler]]" is also used in Britain with a similar meaning.<ref>[https://www.telegraph.co.uk/travel/citybreaks/cities-of-culture/11394950/A-bossy-little-Hitler-is-still-making-waves-80-years-on.html "A bossy 'little Hitler’ is still making waves 80 years on"], The Telegraph</ref><ref>[http://www.bristolpost.co.uk/Bus-driver-conducted-like-little-Hitler-claims/story-19493612-detail/story.html "Bus driver conducted himself like a little Hitler, claims angry pensioner"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150714161314/http://www.bristolpost.co.uk/Bus-driver-conducted-like-little-Hitler-claims/story-19493612-detail/story.html |date=2015-07-14 }}, Bristol Post</ref><ref> [http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/204685.stm "Police dog trainer was a 'fat little Hitler' "], BBC</ref>
==See also== {{Wiktionary}} * [[Apparatchik]] * [[Clientelism]] * [[Computer says no]] * [[Malicious compliance]] * [[Work-to-rule]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fz44_Sp0K8A Jeremy Taylor performing ''Jobsworth'']

revision.text:
{{Infobox person | name = Jörg Dräger | image = Jörg_Dräger_2017.jpg | caption = Jörg Dräger (2017) | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1968|01|01}} | birth_place = [[Darmstadt]], [[Hesse]], [[Germany]] | nationality = [[Germany|German]] | alma_mater = {{ublist|[[University of Hamburg]]|[[Cornell University]]}} | occupation = Member of the [[Bertelsmann Stiftung]] Executive Board | known_for = Senator in the [[Government of Hamburg|Hamburg state government]] | website = {{URL|www.joergdraeger.de}} }}
'''Jörg Dräger''' (born January 1, 1968, in [[Darmstadt]]) is a [[Germany|German]] [[physicist]], [[politician]] and [[Management|manager]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Zukunft entscheidet sich im Klassenzimmer|date={{date|2011-08-29|mdy}}|language=de|author=Bernhard Hänel|newspaper=Neue Westfälische}}</ref><ref name=":2" /> From 2001 to 2008 he served as a senator in the [[Government of Hamburg|Hamburg state government]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Wege aus der Bildungskrise|date={{date|2011-08-29|mdy}}|language=de|author=Elisabeth Jessen|newspaper=Hamburger Abendblatt}}</ref> Since 2008 he has been a member of the [[Bertelsmann Stiftung]] Executive Board where he is responsible for the areas of education and integration.<ref>{{cite news|title=Hamburgs Wissenschaftssenator wechselt zu Bertelsmann|date={{date|2008-03-05|mdy}}|language=de|newspaper=Der Tagesspiegel}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.manager-magazin.de/unternehmen/karriere/a-539338.html|title=Bertelsmann: Dräger geht zur Stiftung|date={{date|2008-03-04|mdy}}|website=Manager Magazin|language=de|access-date={{date|2017-06-30|mdy}}}}</ref> He is considered a leading education expert<ref>{{cite news|title=Das wird ein Angriff auf die Eliten|date={{date|2015-09-27|mdy}}|language=de|author=Jörn Lauterbach|newspaper=[[Welt am Sonntag]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.waz.de/mediacampus/fuer-lehrer/unterrichtshilfen/das-abitur-wird-zum-normalfall-id210015443.html|title=Bildungsexperte Dräger: Das Abitur wird zum Normalfall|date={{date|2017-03-22|mdy}}|website=Westdeutsche Allgemeine Zeitung|language=de|access-date={{date|2017-06-30|mdy}}}}</ref> and is the author of numerous books on education policy,<ref>{{cite news|title=Wieder ein Schulbuch: Spät, aber wichtig|date={{date|2011-08-31|mdy}}|language=de|author=Michael Okrob|newspaper=Die Tageszeitung}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Debatte über das Lernen der Zukunft|date={{date|2016-04-01|mdy}}|language=de|newspaper=[[Die Welt]]}}</ref> including the impacts of digitization.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.zeit.de/2015/39/digitalisierung-bildung-internet-computer-lehrplan/komplettansicht|title=Digitalisierung: Humboldt gegen Orwell|date={{date|2015-10-08|mdy}}|website=[[Die Zeit]]|language=de|access-date={{date|2017-07-05|mdy}}|author=Jörg Dräger, Ralph Müller-Eiselt}}</ref>
== Life == Dräger completed his secondary education ([[Abitur]]) in 1987 at the Christianeum in Hamburg before doing community service in lieu of military service ([[Zivildienst]]).<ref>{{cite news|title=Ich brauche kein Lob|date={{date|2004-08-31|mdy}}|language=de|author=Renate Pinzke|newspaper=Hamburger Morgenpost}}</ref><ref name=":0">{{cite web|url=http://www.munzinger.de/document/00000023909|title=Jörg Dräger|date={{date|2008-09-09|mdy}}|website=Internationales Biographisches Archiv|publisher=Munzinger|language=de|access-date={{date|2017-06-30|mdy}}}}</ref> He then attended the [[University of Hamburg]], studying physics with a minor in business.<ref name=":2">{{cite news|title=Reformer mit kühlem Kopf|date={{date|2005-08-21|mdy}}|language=de|author=Florian Hanauer|newspaper=Welt am Sonntag}}</ref> After receiving his undergraduate degree ([[Vordiplom]]) he transferred to [[Cornell University]] in [[Ithaca, New York|Ithaca]], New York, where he was awarded a [[Master of Science]] in [[theoretical physics]] in 1993.<ref name=":1">{{cite news|title=Bildung ist die Basis|date={{date|2008-07-02|mdy}}|language=de|newspaper=Neue Westfälische}}</ref> Three years later he received a [[Doctor of Philosophy|PhD]] for his work in the area of mathematical crystallography.<ref name=":0" /> While studying and completing his doctorate he worked as a research assistant.<ref name=":1" />
Dräger is married and has two children.<ref>{{cite news|title=Dräger-Nachwuchs|date={{date|2005-06-09|mdy}}|language=de|newspaper=Hamburger Abendblatt}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Guter Unterricht nimmt alle mit|date={{date|2012-01-20|mdy}}|language=de|author=Bernd Eyermann|newspaper=Bonner General-Anzeiger}}</ref>
== Career == In 1996, he joined [[Roland Berger (company)|Roland Berger Strategy Consultants]] in [[Frankfurt|Frankfurt am Main]] as a corporate consultant.<ref>{{cite book|title=Hochschulen, Studienreform und Arbeitsmärkte: Voraussetzungen erfolgreicher Beschäftigungs- und Hochschulpolitik|year=2003|publisher=W. Bertelsmann Verlag|isbn=3-7639-3168-6|location=Bielefeld|page=286|editor=Norbert Bensel}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Unis: Wer baut aus, wer baut ab?|date={{date|2002-03-21|mdy}}|language=de|author=Peter Meyer, Christoph Rind|newspaper=Hamburger Abendblatt}}</ref> He then returned to Hamburg in 1999 to lead the newly established [[Northern Institute of Technology Management|Northern Institute of Technology]] as its CEO.<ref name=":0" /><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.welt.de/print-wams/article118176/Der-Laptop-Senator.html|title=Der Laptop-Senator|date={{date|2003-01-26|mdy}}|website=Welt am Sonntag|language=de|access-date={{date|2017-06-30|mdy}}|author=Nicola Sieverling}}</ref> The institute is one of the first public-private partnerships in the area of German higher education and is known for its interdisciplinary approach.<ref>{{cite news|title=Ausruhen gibt es hier nicht|date={{date|1999-08-15|mdy}}|language=de|author=Wolfgang Ehemann|newspaper=Welt am Sonntag}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Die Besten der Besten studieren jetzt in Harburg|date={{date|1999-08-17|mdy}}|language=de|author=Deborah Knür|newspaper=Die Welt}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Northern Institute of Technology: Wirtschaft zieht voll mit|date={{date|1999-12-17|mdy}}|language=de|newspaper=Hamburger Abendblatt}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.zeit.de/2000/36/Jenseits_der_Technik/komplettansicht|title=Jenseits der Technik|date={{date|2000-08-31|mdy}}|website=Die Zeit|language=de|access-date={{date|2017-06-30|mdy}}|author=Petra Kipphoff}}</ref>
=== Public Office === In 2001, Dräger was appointed senator of science and research in Hamburg's state government led by [[Ole von Beust]], a position he held as a political independent.<ref>{{cite news|title=An die Arbeit, Herr Senator!|date={{date|2001-11-20|mdy}}|language=de|author=Christoph Rind|newspaper=Hamburger Abendblatt}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.zeit.de/2004/44/C-Dr_9ager/komplettansicht|title=Der Quereinsteiger|date={{date|2004-10-21|mdy}}|access-date={{date|2017-06-30|mdy}}|language=de|author=Arnfrid Schenk|website=Die Zeit}}</ref> He called for the introduction of tuition fees and more competition among higher education institutions in order to secure the institutions' long-term funding.<ref>{{cite news|title=Gebühren und mehr Wettbewerb|date={{date|2001-11-13|mdy}}|language=de|author=Christoph Rind|newspaper=Hamburger Abendblatt}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Drägers Uni-Modell|date={{date|2001-10-24|mdy}}|language=de|author=Kaija Kutter|newspaper=Die Tageszeitung}}</ref> These recommendations were greeted with criticism, especially by student representatives.<ref>{{cite news|title=Unerwünschter Auftritt|date={{date|2001-11-15|mdy}}|edition=Hamburg|language=de|author=Kaija Kutter|newspaper=Die Tageszeitung}}</ref>
After early elections in 2004, Dräger was appointed senator of science and health in the second von Beust government.<ref name=":0" /><ref>{{cite news|title=Das sind Oles neue Senatoren|date={{date|2004-03-16|mdy}}|language=de|newspaper=Hamburger Morgenpost}}</ref> Continuing to advocate for reform, he succeeded in introducing [[Tuition payments|tuition fees]].<ref>{{cite news|title=An der Problemlage hat sich nichts geändert|date={{date|2004-03-25|mdy}}|language=de|author=Ira von Mellenthin|newspaper=Die Welt}}</ref> His goal was a fundamental reform of Hamburg's university system.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.zeit.de/2003/07/B-Uni_Kasten/komplettansicht|title=Blaupause für deutsche Universitäten|date={{date|2003-02-06|mdy}}|access-date={{date|2017-06-30|mdy}}|language=de|author=Martin Spiewak|website=Die Zeit}}</ref> He promoted the establishment of new institutions and the consolidation of existing ones as a way of modernizing Hamburg's higher education structures and making them more flexible.<ref name=":0" /> In retrospect these measures have proven controversial:<ref>{{cite news|title=Umkrempeln um jeden Preis|date={{date|2006-01-16|mdy}}|language=de|newspaper=Parlament}}</ref> While supporters praised his expertise and determination, critics opposed cutbacks made in the humanities, among other changes.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.zeit.de/2005/13/P-Dr_8ager/komplettansicht|title=Tortenschlacht um den Überzeugungstäter|date={{date|2005-03-23|mdy}}|access-date={{date|2017-06-30|mdy}}|language=de|author=Martin Spiewak|website=Die Zeit}}</ref> In 2008, Dräger placed last in the ranking of ministers published by the German Association of University Professors and Lecturers; one year later he again placed sixth.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.spiegel.de/lebenundlernen/uni/minister-ranking-die-professoren-keilen-aus-a-536868.html|title=Die Professoren keilen aus|date={{date|2008-02-21|mdy}}|website=[[Spiegel Online]]|language=de|access-date={{date|2017-06-30|mdy}}|author=Jochen Leffers}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.spiegel.de/lebenundlernen/uni/minister-ranking-ein-bisschen-spass-muss-sein-a-604116.html|title=Ein bisschen Spaß muss sein|date={{date|2009-01-28|mdy}}|website=Spiegel Online|language=de|access-date={{date|2017-06-30|mdy}}|author=Jochen Leffers}}</ref>
In 2006, he turned over his responsibilities in the area of health to Senator [[Birgit Schnieber-Jastram]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Neue Senatorin für Gesundheit in Hamburg|date={{date|2006-03-24|mdy}}|language=de|newspaper=Ärzte Zeitung}}</ref> Following elections in 2008 he announced that he would not serve another term.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.spiegel.de/lebenundlernen/uni/hamburgs-wissenschaftssenator-joerg-draeger-verlaesst-die-politik-a-539257.html|title=Jörg Dräger verlässt die Politik|date={{date|2008-03-04|mdy}}|website=Spiegel Online|language=de|access-date={{date|2017-06-30|mdy}}}}</ref> His announcement was met with regret by a number of public figures, including former Hamburg Mayor [[Klaus von Dohnányi|Klaus von Dohnanyi]], who wrote in a commentary in the [[Hamburger Abendblatt]] newspaper that the city had lost presumably its "most effective science senator since 1945."<ref>{{cite news|title=Wegweisende Entscheidungen|date={{date|2008-03-05|mdy}}|language=de|newspaper=Hamburger Abendblatt}}</ref> Other members of the media, conversely, were relieved that the "bulldozer in the three-piece suit" ([[Die Tageszeitung|taz]]) was leaving politics.<ref>{{cite news|title=Bulldozer im Dreiteiler: Jörg Dräger, Wissenschaftsenator auf Abruf|date={{date|2008-03-05|mdy}}|language=de|newspaper=Die Tageszeitung}}</ref>
=== Bertelsmann Stiftung === In 2008, Dräger became a member of the [[Bertelsmann Stiftung]] Executive Board, where he is responsible for the areas of education and integration.<ref>{{cite news|title=Senator Dräger wechselt zu Bertelsmann|date={{date|2008-03-05|mdy}}|edition=Hamburg|language=de|author=Insa Gall|newspaper=Die Welt}}</ref><ref name=":1"/> In addition, he joined Frank Ziegele as a co-executive director of the nonprofit CHE Centre for Higher Education.<ref>{{cite news|title=Der stolze Schlachter der heiligen Kühe|date={{date|2008-06-21|mdy}}|language=de|author=Wolf Schmidt|newspaper=Die Tageszeitung}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Ein radikaler Reformer|date={{date|2008-06-23|mdy}}|language=de|newspaper=Der Tagesspiegel}}</ref> In both positions Dräger has advocated for a number of reforms, including more autonomous colleges and universities.<ref>{{cite news|title=Rankings ausbauen, Autonomie stärken|date={{date|2008-04-01|mdy}}|language=de|author=Dorothee Fricke|newspaper=Junge Karriere}}</ref> He has called for providing schools in troubled neighborhoods with better equipment and resources, and ensuring that educational systems in rural areas adapt to reflect demographic change.<ref>{{cite news|title=Ein Sofortprogramm für Brennpunktschulen ist überfällig!|date={{date|2010-12-08|mdy}}|language=de|author=Jeannette Goddar|newspaper=[[Frankfurter Rundschau]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Investieren statt reparieren|date={{date|2013-02-20|mdy}}|language=de|newspaper=Westfalen-Blatt}}</ref> He is in favor of [[all-day school]]s and views digital media as a helpful tool for improving education.<ref>{{cite news|title=Ganztagsschule wird Normalität|date={{date|2014-01-30|mdy}}|language=de|author=Michael Nichau|newspaper=Westfalen-Blatt}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Digitale Medien sind Hilfsmittel|date={{date|2017-06-22|mdy}}|language=de|newspaper=Neue Westfälische (Zeitung für das Lübbecker Land)}}</ref>
Dräger serves as the deputy chair of the Board of Trustees of the Expert Council of the German Foundations on Integration and Migration.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.svr-migration.de/sachverstaendigenrat/wir-ueber-uns/kuratorium/|title=Kuratorium|publisher=Sachverständigenrat deutscher Stiftungen für Integration und Migration|language=de|access-date={{date|2017-06-30|mdy}}}}</ref> He has called for increased immigration from non-EU countries to ensure Germany does not lose out in the international competition for skilled workers.<ref>{{cite news|title=Willkommen im Kanzleramt|date={{date|2013-05-29|mdy}}|language=de|author=Daniel Bax|newspaper=Die Tageszeitung}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Ausländer rein!|date={{date|2014-09-01|mdy}}|language=de|newspaper=Handelsblatt|author=Barbara Gillmann}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tagesspiegel.de/meinung/gastbeitrag-punkte-fuer-deutschland/6357064.html|title=Punkte für Deutschland|date={{date|2012-03-22|mdy}}|website=Der Tagesspiegel|language=de|access-date={{date|2017-07-04|mdy}}|author=Jörg Dräger}}</ref>
Dräger advises young entrepreneurs at the nonprofit Founders Foundation and teaches public management at the [[Hertie School of Governance]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Bertelsmann gibt Millionen für Firmengründer in OWL|date={{date|2016-02-17|mdy}}|language=de|author=Martin Krause|newspaper=Neue Westfälische}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.hertie-school.org/en/research/faculty-and-researchers/profile/person/draeger/|title=Jörg Dräger|publisher=Hertie School of Governance|language=de|access-date={{date|2017-06-30|mdy}}}}</ref>
==Other activities== * [[Jacobs University Bremen]], Member of the Board of Governors (since 2018)<ref>[https://www.jacobs-university.de/governance Governance] [[Jacobs University Bremen]].</ref>
== Publications == * {{cite book|author1=Jörg Dräger|author2=Robert H. Silsbee|title=Simulations for Solid State Physics. An Interactive Resource for Students and Teachers.|publisher=[[Cambridge University Press]]|location=Cambridge|year=1997|isbn=978-0-521-59094-5}} * {{cite book|language=de|author=Jörg Dräger|title=Dichter, Denker, Schulversager: Gute Schulen sind machbar – Wege aus der Bildungskrise|publisher=[[Deutsche Verlags-Anstalt]]|location=Munich|year=2011|isbn=978-3-421-04529-4}} * {{cite book|language=de|author1=Jörg Dräger|author2=Christina Tillmann|author3=Frank Frick|title=Wie politische Ideen Wirklichkeit werden – Ein Lehr- und Praxisbuch|publisher=Nomos Verlag|location=Baden-Baden|year=2014|isbn=978-3-8487-1613-5}} * {{cite book|author1=Jörg Dräger|author2=Ralph Müller-Eiselt|language=de|title=Die digitale Bildungsrevolution: Der radikale Wandel des Lernens und wie wir ihn gestalten können|publisher=Deutsche Verlags-Anstalt|location=Munich|year=2015|isbn=978-3-421-04709-0}}
== References == {{Reflist|30em}}
== External links == {{Commonscat|Jörg Dräger}} * {{Official website|www.joergdraeger.de}} of Jörg Dräger * [https://www.bertelsmann-stiftung.de/en/about-us/who-we-are/organization/management-board/dr-joerg-draeger/ Vita] on the Bertelsmann Stiftung official website
{{Authority control}}

revision.comment: Disambiguating links to [[Emirati]] (link changed to [[Emiratis]]) using [[User:Qwertyytrewqqwerty/DisamAssist|DisamAssist]].
revision.text:
{{Infobox politician | name = Salmeen, Khaled | image = | birth_date = {{birth year and age|1974}} | birth_place = [[Abu Dhabi]], [[United Arab Emirates]] | occupation = Chairman, [[Abu Dhabi Terminals]] (ADT), senior strategic and commercial advisor to the board of [[Abu Dhabi Ports Company]] | alma_mater = [[Colorado School of Mines]] }} '''Khaled Salmeen''' (Arabic: خالد سالمين) (born 1974) is chairman of [[Abu Dhabi Terminals]] (ADT), and a leading advisor to [[Abu Dhabi Ports]] in the [[emirate of Abu Dhabi]].<ref>{{cite news|author= |url=http://www.thebusinessyear.com/vip_interview/2545/khaled-salmeen-al-kawari|title=VIP INTERVIEW: Khaled Salmeen Al Kawari|publisher=The Business Year|date=November 2013 |accessdate=2014-02-19}}</ref> An [[Emiratis|Emirati]] national, Salmeen has spearheaded and led a number of major infrastructure projects in the emirate. For five years, in the role of CEO and managing director of [[Khalifa Industrial Zone Abu Dhabi]] ([[Kizad]]), Salmeen played a central role in helping to develop the emirate's industrial and manufacturing economy<ref>{{cite news|author= |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hH1IQf5Gnnw|title=Abu Dhabi Quality Forum Khaled Salmeen Al Kawari|publisher=Abu Dhabi Quality Forum on YouTube|date=2013-05-16}}</ref> - one of the main goals set out by the Abu Dhabi government's Abu Dhabi Economic Vision 2030 to diversify the local economy away from oil and gas.<ref>{{cite news|author= |url=http://www.oxfordbusinessgroup.com/news/major-player-obg-talks-khaled-salmeen-ceo-and-managing-director-kizad|title=Major player: OBG talks to Khaled Salmeen, CEO and Managing Director, Kizad|publisher=Oxford Business Group|date=June 2013 |accessdate=2014-02-19}}</ref>
Before taking up his position at Kizad in 2009, Salmeen project managed the development of [[Masdar]]'s hydrogen power plant as well as specializing in carbon capture and storage before going on to serve two years as chief operation officer at [[Abu Dhabi]]'s leading district cooling company, Tabreed, from 2007.<ref>{{cite news|author= |url=http://www.constructionweekonline.com/article-6610-tabreed-chief-quits/|title=Tabreed chief quits|publisher=Construction Week|date=2009-10-11 |accessdate=2014-02-19}}</ref>
== Education == Salmeen holds a B.Sc. in Engineering from [[Colorado School of Mines]] in the United States and a [[Project Management Professional]] (PMP) from the [[Project Management Institute]] (PMI) and [[Harvard Business School]].<ref>{{cite news|author= |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=HKm2QsXPkBk|title=France 24 (Arabic) sits down with Kizad's CEO Khaled Salmeen |publisher=France 24 Arabic}}</ref>
==See also== * [[Energy law]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{Asia-business-bio-stub}}

revision.text:
The '''Lion of St. Mark''' is an award given each year at the [[Cannes Lions]] International Festival of Creativity for a lifetime of services to creativity in communications.
It was instituted in 2011. The trophy is modelled on the [[Lion of St. Mark|lion statue]] in [[St Mark’s Square]], [[Venice]], where the first [[Cannes Lions]] festival was held in 1954.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.campaignlive.co.uk/article/history-advertising-20-cannes-lion/1076691|title=The History of Advertising 20 - A Cannes Lion|website=Campaignlive.co.uk|accessdate=13 December 2017}}</ref>
==Winners== * 2011, [[John Hegarty (advertising executive)|Sir John Hegarty]]<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.campaignlive.co.uk/article/cannes-lions-honours-sir-john-hegarty-services-advertising/1071396|title=Cannes Lions honours Sir John Hegarty for services to advertising|website=Campaignlive.co.uk|accessdate=13 December 2017}}</ref> * 2012, [[Dan Wieden]] <ref>{{cite web|title=Video: Dan Wieden Collecting his Lion of St. Mark|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jujF22S-i2U|publisher=Cannes International Festival of Creativity}}</ref> * 2013, [[Lee Clow]] <ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.adweek.com/brand-marketing/cannes-grants-lee-clow-2013-lion-st-mark-148847/}}</ref> * 2014, [[Joe Pytka]]<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.campaignlive.co.uk/article/joe-pytka-collect-lion-st-mark-cannes/1294228|title=Joe Pytka to collect Lion of St Mark at Cannes|website=Campaignlive.co.uk|accessdate=13 December 2017}}</ref> * 2015, [[Bob Greenberg]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.adweek.com/brand-marketing/cannes-honors-rgas-bob-greenberg-2015-lion-st-mark-163943/|title=Cannes Honors R/GA's Bob Greenberg With 2015 Lion of St. Mark|website=Adweek.com|accessdate=13 December 2017}}</ref> * 2016, [[Marcello Serpa]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.campaignindia.in/article/cannes-lions-2016-the-language-has-to-be-local-marcello-serpa/427278|title=Cannes Lions 2016: 'The language has to be local'|author=Marcello Serpa|website=Campaignindia.com|accessdate=13 December 2017}}</ref> * 2017, [[David Droga]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.adweek.com/agencies/david-droga-will-receive-the-cannes-lions-lifetime-achievement-award-the-lion-of-st-mark/|title=David Droga Will Receive the Cannes Lions' Lifetime Achievement Award, the Lion of St. Mark|website=Adweek.com|accessdate=13 December 2017}}</ref> * 2018, [[Piyush Pandey]] and [[Prasoon Pandey]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.livemint.com/Consumer/utjcrZYoau60kcsDXyOKcI/Cannes-to-honour-Ogilvys-Piyush-and-Prasoon-Pandey-with-lif.html|title=Cannes to honour Ogilvy’s Piyush and Prasoon Pandey with lifetime achievement award|first=Saumya|last=Tewari|date=13 December 2017|website=Livemint.com|accessdate=13 December 2017}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
[[Category:Advertising awards]] [[Category:Awards established in 2011]]

revision.text:
{{For|other Italian Americans|List of Italian Americans}} {{dynamic list}}
To be included in this '''list of Italian-American business people''', individuals must have a Wikipedia article showing they are Italian-American business people, or must have other published references showing they are Italian-American business people and are notable.
==Senior executives== *[[Gil Amelio]], former CEO of National Semiconductor and Apple *[[William Amelio]], president and CEO of Lenovo Group Limited *[[Mark Attanasio]], owner of the Milwaukee Brewers *[[Richard Belluzzo]], computer industry executive at HP, SGI, Microsoft, Quantum *[[John Brunetti]], CEO of [[Hialeah Park Race Track]] *[[Bob Castellini]], owner of the Cincinnati Reds *[[Samuel DiPiazza]], CEO of [[PricewaterhouseCoopers]] *[[Nick Donofrio]], Executive Vice President of Innovation and Technology at the [[IBM]] Corporation *[[Richard Grasso]] (1946–), former chairman and CEO of the [[New York Stock Exchange]] *[[Lee Iacocca]] (1924–), former chairman of the [[Chrysler Corporation]] *[[Angelo Mozilo]], founder and CEO of [[Countrywide Financial]] *[[Robert Nardelli]], former chairman and CEO of [[Home Depot]] and [[Chrysler]] *[[Frank Nuovo]], head of design at [[Vertu]] *[[Paul Otellini]] (1950–), [[Intel]] Corporation's fifth [[Chief Executive Officer]] *[[Samuel J. Palmisano]] (1951–), chairman and CEO of [[IBM]] *[[Patricia Russo]] (1952–), CEO of [[Lucent Technologies]] *[[Peter F. Secchia]], former chairman and CEO of Universal Forest Products
==Entrepreneurs== *[[Robert Benedetto]], founder of Benedetto Guitars, Inc. *[[Steve Bisciotti]] (1960–), billionaire founder of the [[Allegis Group]], owner of the [[Baltimore Ravens]] *[[Hector Boyardee]], famous for his [[Chef Boyardee]] brand of food products *[[Domenico Canale]] (1843–1919), founder of D. Canale & Co., major distributor of food and beverages *[[Pat Croce]] (1954–), former owner of the [[Philadelphia 76ers]] basketball team *[[Nicholas D'Agostino, Sr.]] (1910–1996), co-founder of [[D'Agostino Supermarkets]] *[[Edward J. DeBartolo, Jr.]] (1946–), billionaire, former owner of the [[San Francisco 49ers]] * [[Chris Deering]] (1947–), executive and marketer for [[Sony PlayStation]] and other video games<ref>[http://www.mcvuk.com/news/read/mcv-legends-chris-deering-2/01305, "MCV LEGENDS - Chris Deering"], MCVUK.com, (Retrieved 12 November 2015)</ref> *[[Fred DeLuca]], founder of [[Subway (restaurant)|Subway]] Sandwich *[[Giorgio DeLuca]], founder of [[Dean & DeLuca]] *[[Frank Fertitta III]], American casino executive and sports promoter, [[Ultimate Fighting Championship]] *[[Lorenzo Fertitta]], American casino executive and sports promoter, [[Ultimate Fighting Championship]] * [[Bill Gallo]], founder of Columbia Grain Trading Inc. which he developed into the No. 1 supplier of soybeans to China *[[Domingo Ghirardelli]] (1817–1894), founder of [[Ghirardelli Chocolate Company]] *[[Tom Golisano]] (1941–), billionaire founder of [[Paychex]], former owner of the [[Buffalo Sabres]], three-time candidate for [[Governor of New York]] *[[Arthur Edward Imperatore, Sr.]] (1925–), businessman from [[New Jersey]], founder and president of [[NY Waterway]] ferry service *[[Kenneth Langone]] (1935–), billionaire founder of [[The Home Depot]] *[[Gennaro Lombardi]], opened the first US pizzeria in 1905, Lombardi's *[[Lelio Marino]] (1935–2004), co-founder of construction company [[Modern Continental]] *[[Roger Marino]], founder of [[EMC Corporation]] *[[Vincent Marotta]], founder of [[Jarden Corporation]] *[[Robert Mondavi]] (1913–2008), leading vineyard operator in California's Napa Valley *[[Amedeo Obici]] (1877–1947), founder of the [[Planters|Planters Peanut Company]] in 1906 *[[Mario Peruzzi]] (1875–1955), co-founder of [[Planters|Planters Peanut Company]] in 1906 *[[Almerindo Portfolio]] (1877–1966), President of Bank of Sicily (USA), and Treasurer of New York City *[[Anthony T. Rossi]] (1900–1993), Italian immigrant who founded Tropicana Products * [[Henry Salvatori]] (1901–1997), Italian immigrant geophysicist, businessman, philanthropist, and political activist who founded [[Western Geophysical]]. *[[Jay Sarno]] (1922–1984), Las Vegas business entrepreneur who owned several high-profile hotels *[[Andrew Viterbi]] (1935–), Italian immigrant founder of [[Qualcomm]]
==Finance== *[[Mario Gabelli]] (1942–), stock investor, investment adviser and financial analyst *[[Amadeo Giannini]] (1870–1949), founder of [[Bank of Italy (USA)|Bank of Italy]], which later became [[Bank of America]], the largest bank in the United States *[[Frank Quattrone]] (1955–), investment banker who led dozens of major IPOs during the 1990s tech boom *[[Lewis Ranieri]] (1947–), pioneer of [[Mortgage-backed security|mortgage-backed securities]]
==Publishing== *[[George T. Delacorte, Jr.]] (1894–1991), founder of [[Dell Publishing]] *[[Bob Guccione]] (1930–2010), founder and former publisher of [[Penthouse Magazine]] *[[Leonard Riggio]] (1941–), owner of [[Barnes & Noble]] *[[Louis Rossetto]] (1949–), founder and former publisher of [[Wired Magazine]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.ffiac.com/famous_a-c.htm List of famous Italian-Americans]
[[Category:American people of Italian descent|*Business people]] [[Category:Lists of American people of Italian descent|Business people]] [[Category:American businesspeople by ethnicity|Italian Americans]] [[Category:Lists of businesspeople|Italian American]]
