{{Use Indian English|date=June 2015}} {{Use dmy dates|date=June 2015}} {{Infobox company | name = Tech Mahindra Ltd. | logo = [[File:Tech Mahindra New Logo.svg|200px]] | type = [[public company|Public]] | traded_as = {{Unbulleted list|{{BSE|532755}}|{{NSE|TECHM}}}} | area_served = Worldwide | key_people = {{Unbulleted list|[[Anand Mahindra]] {{Small|(Chairman & Founder)}}|[[Vineet Nayyar]] {{Small|(VC)}}|[[CP Gurnani]] {{Small|(CEO)}}}} | industry = [[IT service management|IT services]], [[Information technology consulting|IT consulting]] | services = [[IT]], [[business consulting]] and [[outsourcing]] | revenue = {{profit}} [[US$]]4.77 billion (2018)<ref name=2018res/> | net_income = {{profit}} [[US$]]588 million (2018)<ref name=2018res/> | num_employees = 113,550+ (2018 Q1)<ref name=2018res>{{Cite web|url=https://www.techmahindra.com/sites/resourceCenter/Financial%20Reports/Q4-FY18-Factsheet.pdf|title=Tech Mahindra Limited Consolidated Fact Sheet Data|publisher=Tech Mahindra}}</ref> | parent = [[Mahindra Group]] | founded = {{Start date and age|1986}} | location = [[Pune]], [[India]]<ref>[http://www.deccanchronicle.com/130626/news-businesstech/article/satyam-history-mahindra-group-merges-satyam-tech-mahindra Satyam is history: Mahindra Group merges Satyam with Tech Mahindra] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160115033608/http://www.deccanchronicle.com/130626/news-businesstech/article/satyam-history-mahindra-group-merges-satyam-tech-mahindra |date=15 January 2016 }}</ref> | homepage = {{URL|http://www.techmahindra.com/}} }}
'''Tech Mahindra Limited'''<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.instafinancials.com/company/tech-mahindra-limited/L64200MH1986PLC041370 |title=Tech Mahindra Limited |website=instafinancials.com |date= |accessdate=2018-11-25}}</ref> is an [[India]]n<nowiki/> [[Multinational corporation|multinational]] provider of [[information technology]] (IT), networking technology [[solution]]s and [[Business process outsourcing|Business Process Outsourcing]] (BPO) to various industry verticals and horizontals. [[Anand Mahindra]] is the Chairman of Tech Mahindra, which is headquartered at [[Pune]] and has its registered office in [[Mumbai]].
Part of the [[Mahindra Group]], Tech Mahindra is a {{USD}}4.7 billion company<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.techmahindra.com/company/default.aspx|title=Tech Mahindra|website=techmahindra.com|publisher=TechMahindra|accessdate=January 1, 2018}}</ref> with over 113,550 employees across 90 countries.<ref name=2018res/> Tech Mahindra was ranked #5 in India's software services (IT) firms and overall #111 in [[Fortune India 500]] list for 2012.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://financeshop.capitalmarket.com/compendium/rankingcompendium.htm|title= Ranking of Top 500 Companies}}</ref> Tech Mahindra, on 25 June 2013, announced the completion of a merger with [[Mahindra Satyam]].<ref>{{Cite news| url=http://www.thehindu.com/business/Industry/185-swap-for-tech-mahindra-mahindra-satyam-merger/article4849296.ece | location=Chennai, India | work=The Hindu | title=1:8.5 swap for Tech Mahindra, Mahindra Satyam merger | date=June 25, 2013}}</ref>
Tech Mahindra has 926 active clients as of March 2018.<ref name=2018res/>
==History== ===Foundation=== [[Mahindra & Mahindra]] started a joint venture with [[British Telecom]] in 1986 as a technology outsourcing firm. British Telecom initially had around 30 percent stake in the Tech Mahindra company. In December 2010, British Telecom sold 5.5 per cent of its stake in Tech Mahindra to Mahindra & Mahindra for Rs 451 crore.<ref>{{cite web|title=BT Group to exit from Tech Mahindra, directors resign|url=http://articles.economictimes.indiatimes.com/2011-12-24/news/30554758_1_bt-group-tech-mahindra-techm|publisher=Economic Times|accessdate=4 July 2015|date=24 December 2011}}</ref> In August 2012, British Telecom sold 14.1 per cent of its stake to institutional investors for about Rs 1,395 crore. In December 2012, British Telecom sold its remaining 9.1 per cent (11.6 million shares) shareholding to institutional investors for a total gross cash proceeds of Rs 1,011.4 crore. This sale marked the exit of British Telecom from Tech Mahindra.<ref>{{cite web|title=BT exits Tech Mahindra|url=http://www.thehindu.com/business/companies/bt-exits-tech-mahindra/article4191751.ece|publisher=The Hindu|accessdate=4 July 2015|date=12 December 2012}}</ref>
===Acquisition of Satyam Computer Services Ltd.=== After the [[Satyam scandal]] of 2008-09 Tech Mahindra bid for [[Satyam Computer Services]], and emerged as a top bidder with an offer of Rs 58.90 a share for a 31 per cent stake in the company, beating a strong rival [[Larsen & Toubro]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ibnlive.in.com/news/tech-mahindra-wins-satyam-bid--full-coverage/90124-7.html|title=Tech Mahindra wins Satyam Computer bid|work=IBNLive}}</ref> After evaluating the bids, the government-appointed board of Satyam Computer announced on 13 April 2009: "its Board of Directors has selected Venturbay Consultants Private Limited, a subsidiary controlled by Tech Mahindra Limited as the highest bidder to acquire a controlling stake in the Company, subject to the approval of the Hon'ble Company Law Board." Through a subsidiary, it has emerged victorious in [[Mahindra Satyam|Satyam]] sell-off, a company probably two times its size in number of people. This was one of the largest merger deals in India's tech industry.
===Merger with Mahindra Satyam=== [[Image:Anand Mahindra (1).jpg|thumb|right|Mahindra Group V-C [[Anand Mahindra]]]] Tech Mahindra announced its [[Tech Mahindra-Mahindra Satyam merger|merger]] with [[Mahindra Satyam]] on March 21, 2012, after the boards of the two companies gave their approval, to create a 2.5 billion $ IT Company<ref>{{cite web|url=http://articles.economictimes.indiatimes.com/2011-06-21/news/29683399_1_tech-mahindra-mahindra-satyam-mahindra-satyam-tech-mahindra-sixth-largest-software-exporter/|title=Rising wages can harm Indian IT companies: Vineet Nayyar, Vice-Chairman, Tech Mahindra|work=timesofindia-economictimes}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.livemint.com/2012/03/21094345/Tech-Mahindra-Satyam-get-nod.html|title=Tech Mahindra, Satyam get nod to merge|publisher=}}</ref> The two firms had received the go-ahead for the merger from the [[Bombay Stock Exchange]] and the [[National Stock Exchange of India|National Stock Exchange]].<ref>[http://www.thehindubusinessline.com/industry-and-economy/info-tech/article3304195.ece/ Mahindra Satyam-TechM to take 150 top leaders to Bangkok] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140315133139/http://www.thehindubusinessline.com/industry-and-economy/info-tech/article3304195.ece/ |date=15 March 2014 }}</ref> On June 11, 2013, Andhra Pradesh High Court gave its approval for the merger of Mahindra Satyam with Tech Mahindra, after the Bombay high court had already given its approval.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2013-06-11/software-services/39898413_1_mahindra-satyam-tech-mahindra-merger | work=The Times Of India | title=Mahindra Satyam, Tech Mahindra merger gets AP High Court's nod — The Times of India}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| url=http://economictimes.indiatimes.com/tech/ites/andhra-pradesh-high-court-clears-merger-of-mahindra-satyam-with-tech-mahindra/articleshow/20538518.cms | work=The Times Of India | title=Andhra Pradesh High Court clears merger of Mahindra Satyam with Tech Mahindra | date=June 11, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.thehindu.com/todays-paper/tp-national/tp-andhrapradesh/mahindra-satyam-waits-for-court-order-for-merger/article4722955.ece | location=Chennai, India | work=The Hindu | title=Mahindra Satyam waits for Court order for merger | date=May 17, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.deccanchronicle.com/130612/news-businesstech/article/decks-cleared-end-satyam |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2013-06-12 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131003031915/http://www.deccanchronicle.com/130612/news-businesstech/article/decks-cleared-end-satyam |archivedate=3 October 2013 |df=dmy }}</ref> Vineet Nayyar said that technical approvals from the Registrar of Companies in Andhra Pradesh and Maharashtra are required which will be done in two to four weeks, and within eight weeks, the new merged entity would be in place. The new organisation would be led by [[Anand Mahindra]] as Chairman, [[Vineet Nayyar]] as Vice Chairman and [[C. P. Gurnani]] as the CEO and Managing Director.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://indiatoday.intoday.in/story/m-satyam-tech-mahindra-hope-to-merge-in-four-weeks/1/279629.html|title=M-Satyam, Tech Mahindra hope to merge in four weeks|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.moneycontrol.com/news/business/will-complete-tech-mah-satyam-merger8-weeks-nayyar-_896218.html|title=Will complete Tech Mah, Satyam merger in 8 weeks: Nayyar|date=11 June 2013|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.thehindu.com/business/Industry/high-court-clears-merger-of-mahindra-satyam-with-tech-mahindra/article4803837.ece | location=Chennai, India | work=The Hindu | title=MSat-Tech Mahindra merger gets court nod | date=June 11, 2013}}</ref> On June 25, 2013, Tech Mahindra announced the completion of its merger with Mahindra Satyam to create the nation's fifth largest software services company with a turnover of USD 2.7 billion.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://zeenews.india.com/business/news/companies/mahindra-satyam-merges-with-tech-mahindra_78656.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2013-06-25 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150619224313/http://zeenews.india.com/business/news/companies/mahindra-satyam-merges-with-tech-mahindra_78656.html |archivedate=19 June 2015 |df=dmy }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.moneycontrol.com/news/business/tech-mahindra-satyam-computer-complete-merger_905059.html|title=Tech Mahindra, Satyam Computer complete merger|date=25 June 2013|publisher=}}</ref> Tech Mahindra got the approval from the registrar of companies for the merger at 11:45 pm on June 24, 2013. July 5, 2013 has been determined as record date on which the Satyam Computer Services ('Mahindra Satyam') shares will be swapped for Tech Mahindra shares under the approved scheme.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.deccanchronicle.com/130626/news-businesstech/article/satyam-history-mahindra-group-merges-satyam-tech-mahindra |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2013-06-26 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160115033608/http://www.deccanchronicle.com/130626/news-businesstech/article/satyam-history-mahindra-group-merges-satyam-tech-mahindra |archivedate=15 January 2016 |df=dmy }}</ref> [[Mahindra Satyam]] (Satyam Computer Services), was suspended from trading with effect from July 4, 2013, following the merger.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.moneycontrol.com/news/market-news/tradingmahindra-satyam-to-be-suspendedjuly-4_908200.html|title=Trading in Mahindra Satyam to be suspended from July 4|date=29 June 2013|publisher=}}</ref> Tech Mahindra completed share swap and allocated its shares to the shareholders of Satyam Computer Services on July 12, 2013.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.business-standard.com/article/companies/satyam-is-no-more-to-live-on-as-part-of-tech-mahindra-113071400336_1.html|title=Satyam is no more; to live on as part of Tech Mahindra|author=Press Trust of India|date=14 July 2013|publisher=}}</ref> The stock exchanges have accorded their approval for trading the new shares effective July 12, 2013. Tech Mahindra posted net profit of Rs 686 crore for the first quarter ended June 30, 2013, up 27% compared to the corresponding quarter last year.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rediff.com/business/report/tech-mahindra-completes-share-swap-issued-capital-goes-up/20130712.htm|title=Tech Mahindra completes share swap, issued capital goes up|date=12 July 2013|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/business/india-business/Tech-Mahindra-completes-share-swap/articleshow/21044763.cms | work=The Times Of India | title=Tech Mahindra completes share swap — The Times of India}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.business-standard.com/article/companies/tech-mahindra-q1-net-up-27-y-o-y-113081200500_1.html|title=Tech Mahindra Q1 net up|author=BS Reporter|date=13 August 2013|publisher=}}</ref> By March 2016, Tech Mahindra's post-tax earnings had surged past that of M&M.
==Timeline== * 1986 - Created as a joint venture of [[Mahindra & Mahindra]] and [[British Telecommunications]] (later BT Group).<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/bcd214ae-f1f6-11e1-8973-00144feabdc0.html|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121002110511/http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/bcd214ae-f1f6-11e1-8973-00144feabdc0.html|archive-date=2 October 2012|title=BT set to reduce stake in Tech Mahindra|date= 29 Aug 2012|author=Daniel Thomas|quote=BT founded Tech Mahindra as a joint venture with Mahindra & Mahindra, the Indian vehicle group, in 1986.}}</ref> * 1993 - Incorporation of MBT International Inc., the first overseas subsidiary * 1994 - Awarded ISO 9001 certification by [[BVQI]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.techmahindra.com/company/corporate_history.aspx|title=Corporate History - Tech Mahindra|publisher=}}</ref> * 1995 - Established UK branch office * 2001 - Incorporated MBT GmbH, Germany incorporated. Re-certified to [ISO 9001:1994] by BVQI{{Citation needed|date=October 2011}} * 2002 - Assessed at Level 2 of SEI CMM by KPMG. Incorporated MBT Software Technologies Pte. Limited, Singapore * 2005 - Merged MBT with Axes Technologies (India) Private Limited, including its US and Singapore subsidiaries. Assessed at Level 3 of SEI CMMI by KPMG * 2006 - Name changed to Tech Mahindra Limited. Assessed at Level 4 of SEI People-CMM (P-CMM) by QAI India. Raised Rs46.5 million ($1 million) from an IPO to build a new facility in Pune, to house about 9,000 staff. Formed a JV with Motorola Inc. under the name CanvasM. * 2007 - Acquired iPolicy Networks Private Limited. Launched the [[Tech Mahindra Foundation]] to help underprivileged people. Assessed at Level 5 of SEI CMMI by KPMG * 2009 - Tech M wins bid for fraud-hit [[Satyam Computer Services]] at Rs 58.90 per share outdoing Larsen & Toubro, which bid at Rs 45.90. Rebrands the company to Mahindra Satyam. * 2012 - Acquires Hutchison Global Services for $87.1 million * 2012 - Buys 51% stake in [[Comviva]] * 2012 - Tech Mahindra acquires vCustomer BPO for $27 million * 2013 - Tech Mahindra acquires Sweden-based Type Approval Lab. The lab was part of Sony Mobile Communication's internal test function and after acquisition it became the first European test lab of Tech Mahindra.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://articles.economictimes.indiatimes.com/2013-04-24/news/38790530_1_comviva-hutchison-global-services-tech-mahindra |title=Tech Mahindra acquires Sweden-based Type Approval Lab |publisher=The Economics Times |date= |accessdate=2012-04-24}}</ref> * 2013 - On June 25, Tech Mahindra and [[Mahindra Satyam]] merging process completed and the name of the parent company was retained for the merged entity<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.business-standard.com/article/companies/tech-mahindra-goes-for-growth-by-acquisition-113101500020_1.html|title=Tech Mahindra goes for growth by acquisition|author=Clifford Alvares|date=15 October 2013|publisher=}}</ref> * 2014 - Tech Mahindra acquires Lightbridge Communications Corporation (LCC), the largest independent telecom services company in the world with local presence in over 50 countries. * 2015 - Tech Mahindra acquires SOFGEN Holdings, a 450-employee Swiss IT firm serving the financial services industry<ref>{{cite web|url=http://articles.economictimes.indiatimes.com/2015-01-09/news/57883595_1_tech-mahindra-lightbridge-communications-gurnani|title=?Tech Mahindra to acquire Swiss firm SOFGEN Holdings|work=timesofindia-economictimes}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.techmahindra.com/media/press_releases/Tech_Mahindra_Augments_Its_Core_Banking_Expertise.aspx|title=Tech Mahindra Augments Its Core Banking Expertise, To acquire SOFGEN Holdings Limited|publisher=}}</ref> * 2015 - Tech Mahindra purchases a controlling stake in [[Pininfarina]] S.p.A., an Italian brand in automotive and industrial design<ref>{{cite web|url=http://articles.economictimes.indiatimes.com/2015-12-14/news/69033382_1_tech-mahindra-debt-restructuring-design|title=Tech Mahindra set to acquire Italian car design company Pininfarina|work=timesofindia-economictimes}}</ref> * 2015 - Tech Mahindra announces the launch of its Automation Framework AQT (Automation, Quality, Time)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.business-standard.com/article/companies/tech-mahindra-aims-10-productivity-improvement-with-new-automation-platform-115122200882_1.html|title=Tech Mahindra rolls out automation tool to boost productivity|author=Bibhu Ranjan Mishra|date=23 December 2015|publisher=}}</ref> * 2016 - Tech Mahindra said it would buy financial technology firm [[Target Group]] to boost its platform business process-as-a-service offering in the banking sector<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.techmahindra.com/media/press_releases/Tech-Mahindra-to-acquire-Target-Group-to-augment-Platform-BPaaS-offerings-in-BFSI.aspx|title=Tech Mahindra to acquire Target Group - to augment Platform BPaaS offerings in BFSI|author=Risov Chakrabortty|date=25 November 2016|publisher=}}</ref> * 2017 - Tech Mahindra and Midad Holdings, a part of diversified business conglomerate Al Fozan Group today announced the launch of a joint venture, Tech Mahindra Arabia Ltd.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Rath|first1=Abhishek|url=http://www.techmahindra.com/media/press_releases/Tech-Mahindra-launches-Saudi-JV-with-Al-Fozan-Group.aspx|title=Tech Mahindra launches Saudi JV with Al Fozan Group|website=techmahindra.com|accessdate=20 June 2017}}</ref> * 2017 - On the basis of a global partnership agreement signed, Tech Mahindra will market Huawei's enterprise products and services across 44 countries including India.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Rath|first1=Abhishek|url=http://www.techmahindra.com/media/press_releases/TechMahindra-to-Take-HuaweiEnterpriseProducts-To-Global-Markets.aspx|title=Tech Mahindra to Take Huawei Enterprise Products To Global Markets|website=techmahindra.com|accessdate=20 June 2017}}</ref> * 2017 - Tech Mahindra announced that it has signed a definitive agreement to acquire CJS Solutions Group LLC, a US-based healthcare Information Technology consulting company which does business as (DBA) “The HCI Group.”<ref>{{cite wlast1=Rath|first1=Abhishek|url=http://www.techmahindra.com/media/press_releases/TechMahindra-acquire-US-based-healthcare-ITservices-consultingfirm.aspx|title=Tech Mahindra to acquire US-based healthcare IT services & consulting firm|website=techmahindra.com|accessdate=20 June 2017}}</ref>
==Tech Mahindra offices== Tech Mahindra has offices in more than 60 countries.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.techmahindra.com/Contact%20Us/locations.aspx |title=Tech Mahindra > Location Details |date= |accessdate=2012-10-01}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.techmahindra.com/Contact%20Us/locations.aspx |title=Tech Mahindra |date= |accessdate=2012-10-01}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.techmahindra.com/contacts/techmahindra_contact.aspx |title=Contact Details & offices are in Asia, Africa, Americas, Europe & Australia |publisher=Tech Mahindra |date= |accessdate=2012-10-01}}</ref>
* India: [[Bangalore]], [[Trivandrum]], [[Bhubaneswar]], [[Chandigarh]], [[Chennai]], [[Gandhinagar]], [[Gurgaon]], [[Hyderabad]], [[Kolkata]], [[Mumbai]], [[Noida]], [[Nagpur]], [[Pune]] and [[Visakhapatnam]] [[Ahmedabad.]] * Asia Pacific: [[China]], [[Hong Kong]], [[Indonesia]], [[Japan]], [[Malaysia]], [[Philippines]], [[Singapore]], [[South Korea]], [[Taiwan]], [[Thailand]] and [[Vietnam]] *Americas: [[Argentina]], [[Brazil]], [[Canada]], [[Bolivia]], [[Colombia]], [[Costa Rica]], [[Ecuador]], [[Guatemala]], [[Mexico]], [[Panama]], [[Peru]], and [[United States of America]] *Australia: [[Australia]] and [[New Zealand]] *Europe: [[Austria]], [[Belgium]], [[Bulgaria]], [[Czech Republic]], [[Denmark]], [[Finland]], [[France]], [[Germany]], [[Hungary]], [[Ireland]], [[Italy]], [[Luxembourg]], [[Netherlands]], [[Norway]], [[Romania]], [[Spain]], [[Sweden]], [[Switzerland]] and [[United Kingdom]] *Africa: [[Chad]], [[Republic of the Congo]], [[Democratic Republic of the Congo]], [[Gabon]], [[Ghana]], [[Kenya]], [[Malawi]], [[Nigeria]], [[Rwanda]], [[South Africa]], [[Uganda]] and [[Zambia]] *Middle East: [[Bahrain]], [[Israel]], [[Oman]], [[Qatar]], [[Saudi Arabia]], [[Turkey]] and [[United Arab Emirates]]
<gallery> File:Satyam hyd.jpg|Tech Mahindra Campus, HITEC City File:Satyam first building.JPG|Tech Mahindra Technology Center at [[Bahadurpally]], Hyderabad File:Satyam Tech Center.JPG|Tech Mahindra Development Center File:Satyam Campus.JPG|Tech Mahindra, Hyderabad File:Satyam campus in Visakhapatnam.jpg|Tech Mahindra Development Centre [[Visakhapatnam]] </gallery>

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=December 2015}}{{animal testing}} '''Cosmetic testing on animals''' is a type of [[animal testing]] used to test the safety and [[hypoallergenic]] properties of products for use by humans. Due to the harm done to the animal subjects, this testing is opposed by [[animal rights ]] activists and others. Cosmetic animal testing is banned in the [[European Union]], [[India]], [[Israel]],<ref name="WorldPost"/><ref name="HSUS"/> and [[Norway]].<ref name="US Bill"/>
==Definition== Using animal testing in the development of [[cosmetics]] may involve testing either a finished product or the individual ingredients of a finished product on animals, often [[rabbit]]s, as well as [[mice]], [[rat]]s, and other animals. Cosmetics can be defined as products applied to the body in various ways in order to enhance the body's appearance or to cleanse the body. This includes all hair products, makeup, nail products and soaps.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.fda.gov/Cosmetics/GuidanceRegulation/LawsRegulations/ucm074201.htm|title=Laws & Regulations - Is It a Cosmetic, a Drug, or Both? (Or Is It Soap?)|first=Center for Food Safety and Applied|last=Nutrition|date=|website=www.fda.gov|accessdate=2 April 2018}}</ref>
The United States [[Food and Drug Administration]] (FDA) continues to endorse animal testing methods.<ref name="aavs.org"/>
Re-using existing test data obtained from previous animal testing is generally not considered to be cosmetic testing on animals; however, the acceptability of this to opponents of testing is inversely proportional to how recent the data is.<ref>{{cite web|title=Kunde oder Vertriebspartner werden|url=http://www.vegas-germany.de/|website=VEGAS Cosmetics|language=de-DE|date=16 June 2015}}</ref>
==Methods== Methods of testing cosmetics on animals include many different tests that are categorized differently based on which areas the cosmetics will be used for. One new ingredient in any cosmetic product used in these tests could lead to the deaths of at least 1,400 animals <ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.nst.com.my/lifestyle/flair/2017/09/276688/cruelty-free-cosmetics |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2018-02-08 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180209063147/https://www.nst.com.my/lifestyle/flair/2017/09/276688/cruelty-free-cosmetics |archivedate=9 February 2018 |df=dmy-all }}. </ref>
Dermal penetration: Rats are mostly used in this method that analyzes moment of a chemical, and the penetration of the chemical in the bloodstream. Dermal penetration is a method that creates a better understanding of skin absorption.<ref name="aavs.org"/>
Skin sensitisation: This is a method that determines if a chemical causes an allergic reaction. The chemical adjuvant is injected to boost the immune system. In the past it was performed on guinea pigs, and applied on a shaved patch of skin. Substances are assessed based on appearance of skin.<ref name="aavs.org"/>
Acute toxicity: This test is used to determine danger of exposure to a chemical by mouth, skin, or inflammation. Rats and mice are injected in lethal dose 50% (LD50). This test can cause animal convulsions, loss of motor function, and seizures.<ref name="aavs.org">{{cite web|url=http://aavs.org/animals-science/how-animals-are-used/testing/|title=Testing|work=American Anti-Vivisection Society}}</ref>
[[Draize test]]: This is a method of testing that may cause irritation or corrosion to the skin or eye on animals, dermal sensitization, airway sensitization, endocrine disruption, and {{LD50}} (which refers to the lethal dose which kills 50% of the treated animals).
Skin corrosivity or irritation: This method of test assesses the potential of a substance causing irreversible damage to the skin. It is typically performed on rabbits and involves putting chemicals on a shaved patch of skin. This determines the level of damage to the skin that includes itching, inflammation, swelling, etc.<ref name="aavs.org"/>
==Alternatives== Cosmetics manufacturers who do not test on animals may now use ''in vitro'' screens to test for endpoints which can determine potential risk to humans with a very high sensitivity and specificity. Companies such as CeeTox in the USA, recently acquired by Cyprotex, specialize in such testing and organizations like the Center for Alternatives to Animal Testing (CAAT), PETA and many other organizations advocate the use of ''in vitro'' and other non-animal tests in the development of consumer products. By using safe ingredients from a list of 5,000 which have already been tested in conjunction with modern methods of cosmetics testing, the need for tests using animals are negated.<ref name="Aus"/>
EpiSkin™, EpiDerm™ and SkinEthic are each composed of artificial human skin as an option for alternative testing. Artificial skin can imitate the reaction actual human skin will have to a product and the chemicals it contains and can be altered to mimic different skin types and ages. For example, using UV light on EpiSkin can cause it to resemble older skin and adding melanocytes will turn the skin a darker color. This helped create a spectrum of different skin colors that are then used to compare the results of sunblock on a different variety of people.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Merali|first=Zeeya|date=July 28, 2007|title=New Scientist|url=|journal=Human skin to replace animal tests|volume=195|pages=14-14|via=|doi=10.1016/s0262-4079(07)61866-1}}</ref> To address potential issues with other parts of the human body, research companies such as NOTOX have developed a synthetic model of the human liver, which is the main organ to detox the body, in order to test harmful ingredients and chemicals to see if the liver can detox those elements.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Mone|first=Gregory|date=April 2014|title=New Models in Cosmetics Replacing Animal Testing|url=|journal=Communications of the ACM|volume=57|pages=20–21|doi=10.1145/2581925}}</ref> Research companies can also use body parts and organs taken from animals slaughtered for the [[meat industry]] to perform tests such as the Bovine Corneal Opacity and Permeability Test and Isolated Chicken Eye Test.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Alternatives to Animal Tests : The Humane Society of the United States|url = http://m.humanesociety.org/issues/cosmetic_testing/facts/alternatives_animal_tests.html?credit=web_id329654370|website = m.humanesociety.org|access-date = 2016-02-12}}</ref>
==History== In 1937, a mistake was made that ended up changing the pharmaceutical industry drastically. A company created a medicine “to treat streptococcal infections”, and without any scientific research the medicine was out on shelves.<ref name="medicaldaily.com">Scutti, Susan. "Animal Testing: A Long, Unpretty History." Medical Daily, 27 June 2013,www.medicaldaily.com/animal-testing-long-unpretty-history-247217.</ref> This medicine turned out to be extremely poisonous to people, leading to large poisoning outbreaks followed by over 100 deaths.<ref name="medicaldaily.com"/> This epidemic led to a law being passed in 1938, called the U.S. Food, Drug, and Cosmetics Act, enforcing more rigorous guidelines on cosmetic products.<ref>Scutti,Susan. "Animal Testing: A Long, Unpretty History." Medical Daily, 27 June 2013,www.medicaldaily.com/animal-testing-long-unpretty-history-247217.</ref> After this law was passed companies looked to animals to test their products, in turn, creating the first encounters of cosmetic animal testing.
== Non-profit organizations == [[Image:NoAnimalTesting.png|right|thumb|This "Leaping Bunny" indicates that cosmetic products with this logo have not been tested on animals.]] *'''Cruelty Free International: '''Cruelty Free International and its partners manage the certification of all the companies across the world looking to be cruelty free. Companies producing beauty and household products which do not test their products on animals for any market can request membership of ''The Leaping Bunny Program'', which allows that company to feature [[Cruelty Free International]]'s Leaping Bunny logo on their products. This program sets global standard of operations and sales. Companies headquartered internationally can obtain certification from Cruelty Free International.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.crueltyfreeinternational.org/what-we-do/corporate-partnerships/corporate-faqs|title=Frequently asked questions by companies - Cruelty Free International|publisher=}}</ref> Companies headquartered in the United States and Canada can obtain certification from The Coalition for Consumer Information on Cosmetics (CCIC)<ref>[http://www.crueltyfreeinternational.org/en/around-the-world/usa About Cruelty Free International] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131216190348/http://www.crueltyfreeinternational.org/en/around-the-world/usa |date=16 December 2013 }}. Cruelty Free International, d.d.</ref> In 2013, over 500 companies were certified.<ref>[http://www.leapingbunny.org/press12.php Leaping Bunny Welcomes Wen® Hair and Body Care by Chaz Dean as Cruelty-Free]. Leapingbunny.org, d.d.</ref> However, some company's certifications were revoked after it was discovered they continued to test on animals in Asia.<ref>[http://www.eluxemagazine.com/magazine/cruelty-in-china/]. Eluxe Magazine, d.d.</ref> *'''Humane Society International:''' This is a global animal protection organization that works to help all animals—including animals in laboratories.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hsi.org/about/|title=About Us : Humane Society International|author=|date=|website=www.hsi.org|accessdate=2 April 2018}}</ref>
==Procedures of animal testing== {{See also|The Three Rs (animals)}} There is a strategy used in animal testing laboratories titled the 'Three R's:' Reduction, refinement, and replacement' (Doke, "Alternatives to Animal Testing: A Review"). *'''Reduction:''' This approach is built upon the ethics to have a minimal number of animal subjects being tested on for current and later tests. *'''Refinement:''' This suggests that the planned distress and pain caused to an animal subject to be as little as possible. This approach focuses on making a home for the animals before entering testing grounds in order to elongate the life of laboratory animals. Discomfort to animals causes an imbalance in hormonal levels which create fluctuating results during testing. *'''Replacement:''' This provides the opportunity to study the response of cellular models, but in other words, replacement searches for alternatives that could be done rather than testing on animal subjects.{{citation needed|date=December 2015}}
==Legal requirements and status== {{update section|date=December 2015}} Due to the strong public backlash against cosmetic testing on animals, most cosmetic manufacturers say their products are not tested on animals. However, they are still required by trading standards and [[consumer protection]] laws in most countries to show their products are not toxic and not dangerous to public health, and that the ingredients are not dangerous in large quantities, such as when in transport or in the manufacturing plant. In some countries, it is possible to meet these requirements without any further tests on animals. In other countries, it may require animal testing to meet legal requirements. The United States and Japan are frequently criticized for their insistence on stringent safety measures, which often requires animal testing. Some retailers distinguish themselves in the marketplace by their stance on animal testing.
=== Legal requirements in Japan ===
Although Japanese law doesn’t require non-medicated cosmetics to be tested on animals, it doesn’t prohibit it either, leaving the decision to individual companies.<ref name="hsi.org">{{cite web|title=Be Cruelty-Free Campaign Backed by Global Stars, Launches in Tokyo to End Cosmetics Animal Testing in Japan (March 17, 2014)|url=http://www.hsi.org/news/press_releases/2014/03/japan-bcf-campaign-launch-031714.html|website=Humane Society International|accessdate=12 May 2015}}</ref> Animal testing is required mainly when the product contains newly-developed tar colors, ultraviolet ray protective ingredients or preservatives, and when the amount of any ingredient regulated in terms of how much can be added is increased.<ref>{{cite web|title=Development of Cosmetics -- Toward Abolishment of Animal Testing (February 2015)|url=http://www.japanfs.org/en/news/archives/news_id035188.html|website=JFS: Japan for Sustainability|accessdate=12 May 2015}}</ref>
Japanese Brands such as Shiseido and Mandom have ended much, but not all, of their animal testing. However, most other leading cosmetics companies in Japan still test on animals.<ref name="hsi.org"/><ref>{{cite web|title=Initiatives in Response to Animal Testing and Alternative Methods|url=https://www.shiseidogroup.com/csr/challenge/experiment/|website=Shiseido Group|accessdate=12 May 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Approach to alternative to animal experiments|url=http://www.mandom.co.jp/english/eco/src/society_animal.html|website=Mandom|accessdate=12 May 2015}}</ref>
=== Jurisdictions with bans ===
==== Brazil, São Paulo ==== [[São Paulo]] in Brazil, banned cosmetic animal testing in 2014.<ref name="Sao Paulo">{{cite news|title=São Paulo Bans Animal Testing|url=http://www.petmd.com/news/care-safety/sao-paulo-bans-animal-testing-31269|publisher=AFP News|date=24 January 2014}}</ref>
==== European Union ==== The European Union (EU) followed suit, after it agreed to phase in a near-total ban on the sale of animal-tested cosmetics throughout the EU from 2009, and to ban cosmetics-related animal testing.<ref name="Euro">{{cite news|title=EU extends ban on animal-tested cosmetics|url=http://www.euronews.com/2013/03/11/eu-extends-ban-on-animal-tested-cosmetics/|date=11 March 2013|publisher=EuroNews}}</ref> Animal testing is regulated in [[EC Regulation 1223/2009 on cosmetics#Restrictions for hazardous ingredients and animal testing|EC Regulation 1223/2009 on cosmetics]]. Imported cosmetics ingredients tested on animals were phased out for EU consumer markets in 2013 by the ban,<ref name="Euro"/> but can still be sold to outside of the EU.<ref name="Rhiannon"/> Norway banned cosmetics animal testing the same time as the EU.<ref>{{cite news|title=Norway ban animal testing of cosmetics|url=http://www.theoslotimes.com/norway-ban-animal-testing-of-cosmetics/|work=The Oslo Times|date=12 March 2013|author=Aryan|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140318075255/http://www.theoslotimes.com/norway-ban-animal-testing-of-cosmetics/|archivedate=18 March 2014|df=dmy-all}}</ref> In May 2018 the European Parliament voted for the EU and its Member States to work towards a UN convention against the use of animal testing for cosmetics.<ref>{{cite news|title=Foster: "Cosmetic testing on animals must be banned worldwide”|url=http://conservativeeurope.com/news/foster-cosmetic-testing-on-animals-must-be-banned-worldwide|work=Conservatives in the European Parliament|date=3 May 2018|author=Jacqueline Foster}}</ref>
==== India ==== In early 2014, India announced a ban on testing cosmetics on animals in the country, thereby becoming the second country in Asia to do so.<ref name="India">{{cite news|title=Govt bans cosmetic companies from testing on animals|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/mumbai/Govt-bans-cosmetic-companies-from-testing-on-animals/articleshow/29225017.cms|date=23 Jan 2014|author=Mukherjee, Rupali|work=The Times of India}}</ref> Later India banned import of cosmetics tested on animals in November 2014.<ref name="Mohan 2014">{{cite web | last=Mohan | first=Vishwa | title=India bans import of cosmetics tested on animals |work=The Times of India | date=14 October 2014 | url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/india/India-bans-import-of-cosmetics-tested-on-animals/articleshow/44814398.cms | accessdate=1 December 2015}}</ref>
==== Israel ==== Israel banned "the import and marketing of cosmetics, toiletries or detergents that were tested on animals" in 2013.<ref name="Israel">{{cite news|title=Import ban on animal-tested products goes into effect|url=http://www.timesofisrael.com/import-ban-on-animal-tested-products-goes-into-effect/|work=The Times of Israel|date=1 January 2013}}</ref>
==== New Zealand ==== In 2015, New Zealand also banned animal testing.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.radionz.co.nz/news/political/270097/mps-unanimously-support-animal-testing-ban|title=MPs unanimously support animal testing ban|date=31 March 2015|work=Radio New Zealand}}</ref>
==== Turkey ==== Turkey "banned any animal testing for cosmetic products that have already been introduced to the market." <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dailysabah.com/nation/2015/07/27/animal-testing-for-cosmetics-banned-in-turkey|title=Animal testing for cosmetics banned in Turkey|date=27 July 2015|work=DailySabah}}</ref>
==== UK ==== Animal testing on cosmetics or their ingredients was banned in the UK in 1998.<ref>{{cite web|title=Animal Research Regulations in the UK |url=http://speakingofresearch.com/facts/animal-research-regulations-in-the-uk/ |accessdate=10 September 2015}}</ref>
=== Jurisdictions where prohibitions are considered ===
==== Association of Southeast Asian Nations ==== The [[Association of Southeast Asian Nations]] (ASEAN) is potentially "making strides toward ending cosmetics testing on animals."<ref name="US Bill"/>
==== Australia ==== In Australia, the ''End Cruel Cosmetics Bill'' was introduced to Parliament in March 2014, which would ban local testing, which generally doesn't happen there, and importation of cosmetics tested on animals.<ref name="Aus"/> In 2016 a bill was passed to ban the sale of cosmetics tested on animals, which will come into effect in July 2017.<ref>http://www.heraldsun.com.au/news/cosmetics-tested-on-animals-to-be-banned-in-australia/news-story/a6362ab50a6146af5c83e60c8e40d93e</ref>
==== Brazil ==== Brazil's legislation will vote on a nationwide animal testing for cosmetics ban by the end of March 2014.<ref name="HSUS"/>
==== United States ==== In March 2014, the ''Humane Cosmetics Act'' was introduced to the U.S. congress which would ban cosmetic testing on animals and eventually would ban the sale of cosmetics tested on animals.<ref name="US Bill"/> The bill did not advance.
==== South Korea ==== South Korea is also potentially "making strides toward ending cosmetics testing on animals."<ref name="US Bill"/>
==== Taiwan ==== In 2015, Taiwan launched a bill proposing a ban on cosmetic testing on animals.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cosmeticsandtoiletries.com/testing/animalalt/Taiwan-Proposes-Animal-Testing-Ban-for-Cosmetics-303286171.html|title=Taiwan Proposes Animal Testing Ban for Cosmetics|publisher=}}</ref> It passed in 2016 and goes into effect in 2019.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hsi.org/news/press_releases/2016/10/taiwan-bans-cosmetics-animal-testing-072116.html|title=Taiwan bans cosmetics animal testing|publisher=Humane Society International}}</ref>
=== Other statuses ===
==== China ==== China passed a law on 30 June 2014 to eliminate the requirement for animal testing of cosmetics. Though domestically-produced ordinary cosmetic goods do not require testing, animal testing is still mandated by law for Chinese-made "cosmeceuticals" (cosmetic goods which make a functional claim) which are available for sale in China. Cosmetics intended solely for export are exempt from the animal testing requirement.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ethicalelephant.com/understanding-china-animal-testing-laws/|title=Understanding China's Animal Testing Laws 2015|author=|date=9 September 2015|website=ethicalelephant.com|accessdate=2 April 2018}}</ref>
==== Russia ==== In 2013, the Russian Ministry of Health stated "Toxicological testing is performed by means of testing for skin allergic reaction or test on [[mucous tissue]]/eye area (with use of lab animals) or by use of alternative general toxicology methods (IN VITRO). In this manner the technical regulations include measures which provide an alternative to animal testing".<ref name="Russia">{{cite web|title=Cruelty Free International wins Russian commitment on non-animal testing|url=http://www.crueltyfreeinternational.org/en/a/Cruelty-Free-International-wins-Russian-commitment-on-non-animal-testing|accessdate=12 May 2015|archivedate=18 May 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150518073423/http://www.crueltyfreeinternational.org/en/a/Cruelty-Free-International-wins-Russian-commitment-on-non-animal-testing|df=dmy-all}}</ref> <!--===UK position=== Although the British Home Office stopped giving licences to test finished cosmetic products in 1998, compounds that have both cosmetic and medical uses, such as those in the "anti-wrinkle" preparations Zyderm, Restylane and [[Botox]], are still bound by the regulations requiring animal testing. According to activists, a raid on a laboratory in 2004 revealed that the {{LD50}} test is still used on every batch of Botox (a [[toxin]] that, when administered intravenously, is lethal to humans) to establish potency.<ref>{{cite news |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120918114852/http://menmedia.co.uk/manchestereveningnews/news/s/156/156795_animal_rights_man_faces_jail_over_lab_raid.html |url=http://menmedia.co.uk/manchestereveningnews/news/s/156/156795_animal_rights_man_faces_jail_over_lab_raid.html |archivedate=18 September 2012 |title=Animal rights man faces jail over lab raid |date=29 April 2005 |work=[[Manchester Evening News]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060217084038/http://www.animalaid.org.uk/news/2004/0401boto.htm |url=http://www.animalaid.org.uk/news/2004/0401boto.htm |archivedate=17 February 2006 |publisher=Animal Aid |title=Boycott Botox! – Cosmetic scandal exposed |date=January 2004 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070929132044/http://www.sarconline.co.uk/modules.php?op=modload&name=News&file=article&sid=129&mode=thread&order=0&thold=0&POSTNUKESID=f070fc85519cfcb46ad4f3d2d92abb1c |url=http://www.sarconline.co.uk/modules.php?op=modload&name=News&file=article&sid=129&mode=thread&order=0&thold=0&POSTNUKESID=f070fc85519cfcb46ad4f3d2d92abb1c |archivedate=29 September 2007 |title=Keith Mann Sentanced <nowiki>[sic]</nowiki> – Press response |publisher=Southern Animal Rights Coalition }}</ref>-->
== Brands that do not test on animals == {{Refimprove section|date=April 2016|reason=References below are for the yearly revenue only, not for the actual confirmation the said companies do or don't perform animal testing.}} {| class="wikitable" !Company !Market !Products !Yearly Revenue |- |The Body Shop |The Body Shop |Cosmetics, Personal Care | |- |SATU laboratory |SATU laboratory |Cosmetics, Personal Care | |- |Urban Decay |Cosmetics |3.7 billion (2015) | |- |LUSH |LUSH |Cosmetics, personal care |350 million (2014)<ref>{{Cite web|title = Lush|url = http://www.retail-merchandiser.com/index.php/reports/retail-reports/94-lush-2|website = Retail Merchandiser|access-date = 2016-02-12}}</ref> |- |Colgate-Palmolive |Tom's of Maine<ref>{{Cite web|title = Tom's of Maine founder reinvents for-profit sustainability in his second company|url = http://www.mainebiz.biz/article/20141201/CURRENTEDITION/311259995/tom's-of-maine-founder-reinvents-for-profit-sustainability-in-his-second-company|website = Mainebiz|access-date = 2016-02-12|language = en-US}}</ref> |Toiletries, personal care |1 million (2014) |- |John Paul Mitchell systems |Paul Mitchell |Hair products, personal care |600 Million (1999) |-
|[[NYX Cosmetics|NYX]] |Cosmetics |3.7 billion (2014) | |- |Hain Celestial |Alba Botanica |Personal care, cosmetics |2.7 million (2014) |- |Hain Celestial |Avalon Organics |Personal care, home goods |2.7 million (2014) |}
== Brands that do test on animals == {{Unreferenced section|date=April 2016}} {| class="wikitable" !Company !Market !Yearly Revenue !Product !Industry !Animal Testing !Market Segment |- |Avon Products, Inc |Avon |US $9.855 billion (2013) |Cosmetics, perfumes, clothing, toys |Fashion |Yes |Mass Market |- |Chanel SAS |Chanel |6.7 billion (2014) |Perfume, Haute, Couture, Ready-to-wear, Accessories |Fashion |Yes |Luxury |- |Coty, Inc |OPI |$7 billion (2015) |Nail Polish |Beauty |Yes |Value for Money |- |Johnson & Johnson |Neutrogena |$6 billion USD (2005) |Cleansers, Cosmetics, Hair Product |Consumer Packaged
Goods |Yes |Value for money |- |LVMH Moet Hennessy-Louis Vuitton |Sephore |$4 billion (2013) |Cosmetics |Beauty |Yes |Value for money |- |Mary Kay holding Corporation |Mary Kay |US $2.9 Billion (2011) |Cosmetics, sunscreen |Cosmetics and personal care products |Yes |Value for money |- |Procter & Gamble |Covergirl |$57 million |Cosmetics |Fashion |Yes |Mass |}
==See also== *[[Animal testing on invertebrates]] *[[Animal testing on non-human primates]] *[[Animal testing on rodents]] *[[Cosmetics]]
== Notes == {{reflist|refs= <ref name="WorldPost">{{cite news|title=India Joins the EU and Israel in Surpassing the US in Cruelty-Free Cosmetics Testing Policy|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/monica-engebretson/cruelty-free-cosmetics-testing_b_3605460.html|date=16 March 2014|author=Engebretson, Monica|publisher=The World Post}}</ref> <ref name="HSUS">{{cite press release|title=Animal Attraction: Federal Bill to End Cosmetics Testing on Animals Introduced in Congress|url=http://www.khou.com/community/blogs/animal-attraction/Animal-Attraction---249254631.html|date=10 March 2014|author=Fox, Stacy|publisher=Humane Society of the United States|archive-date=2014-03-11|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140311022116/http://www.khou.com/community/blogs/animal-attraction/Animal-Attraction---249254631.html|dead-url=yes}}</ref> <ref name="US Bill">{{cite press release|title=Cruelty Free International Applauds Congressman Jim Moran for Bill to End Cosmetics Testing on Animals in the United States|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2014/03/05/bc-cfi-idUSnPnpHM6w1+98+PRN20140305|date=5 March 2014|author=|publisher=|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140318031816/https://www.reuters.com/article/2014/03/05/bc-cfi-idUSnPnpHM6w1%2B98%2BPRN20140305|archivedate=18 March 2014|df=dmy-all}}</ref> <ref name="Aus">{{cite news|title=Australia urged to follow EU ban on animal testing; Greens to move bill in Senate this week|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2014-03-17/greens-call-for-australia-to-follow-eu-ban-on-animal-testing/5326200|publisher=Australian Broadcasting Corporation News|date=17 March 2014|author=Bainbridge, Amy}}</ref> <ref name="Rhiannon">{{citation|title=OPINION: Greens Senator Lee Rhiannon’s End Cruel Cosmetics Bill 2014 answers the public’s growing opposition to animals testing |url=http://www.couriermail.com.au/news/opinion/opinion-greens-senator-lee-rhiannons-end-cruel-cosmetics-bill-2014-answers-the-publics-growing-opposition-to-animals-testing/story-fnihsr9v-1226859483356|publisher=Courier-Mail|date=20 March 2014|author=Fynes-Clinton}}</ref> |https://www.peta.org=}}

revision.comment: /* World’s top tourism destinations */
revision.text:
{{About|travel||tourism (disambiguation)|and|tourist (disambiguation)}} {{Use dmy dates|date=May 2018}} [[File:1 times square night 2013.jpg|thumb|[[Times Square]] is the hub of the [[Broadway theatre]] [[Theater District, Manhattan|district]] and a major cultural venue in [[Midtown Manhattan]], [[New York City]]. The [[pedestrian]] [[intersection (road)|intersection]] also has one of the highest annual attendance rates of any tourist attraction in the world, estimated at 60 million.{{cite web|url=https://ny.curbed.com/2016/12/19/14005846/new-york-city-tourism-2016-record|title=More tourists visited NYC in 2016 than ever before|author=Rachel Sugar|publisher=Vox Media|date=19 December 2016|accessdate=24 April 2018}}]] [[File:Tourist taking photographs and video at archaelogical site.jpg|thumb|A tourist taking photographs and [[video]] at an [[archaeological site]]]] [[File:Urban backpacking.jpg|thumb| upright=1.0| [[Backpacking (travel)|Backpacking]] tourists in [[Vienna]]]] '''Tourism''' is [[travel]] for pleasure or business; also the theory and practice of touring, the business of attracting, accommodating, and entertaining tourists, and the business of operating tours.{{OED|tourism}} Tourism may be international, or within the traveller's country. The [[World Tourism Organization]] defines tourism more generally, in terms which go "beyond the common perception of tourism as being limited to holiday activity only", as people "traveling to and staying in places outside their usual environment for not more than one consecutive year for leisure and not less than 24 hours, business and other purposes".{{cite web|year=1995 |url=http://pub.unwto.org/WebRoot/Store/Shops/Infoshop/Products/1034/1034-1.pdf |title=UNWTO technical manual: Collection of Tourism Expenditure Statistics |page=10 |publisher=World Tourism Organization |access-date=26 March 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100922120940/http://pub.unwto.org/WebRoot/Store/Shops/Infoshop/Products/1034/1034-1.pdf |archivedate=22 September 2010 |df= }} Tourism can be domestic or international, and international tourism has both incoming and outgoing implications on a country's [[balance of payments]]. Today, tourism is a major source of income for many countries, and affects the economy of both the source and host countries, in some cases being of vital importance.{{Cite web|url=http://journal.georgetown.edu/the-growing-importance-of-tourism-in-the-global-economy-and-international-affairs/|title=The Growing Importance of Tourism in the Global Economy and International Affairs {{!}}|website=journal.georgetown.edu|language=en-US|access-date=9 April 2017}} Tourism suffered as a result of a strong economic slowdown of the [[late-2000s recession]], between the second half of 2008 and the end of 2009, and the outbreak of the [[2009 flu pandemic|H1N1 influenza virus]], but slowly recovered. International tourism receipts (the travel item in the [[balance of payments]]) grew to {{USD|1.03}} trillion ({{euro|740}} billion) in 2011, corresponding to an increase in [[Real versus nominal value (economics)|real terms]] of 3.8% from 2010. International tourist arrivals surpassed the milestone of 1 billion tourists globally for the first time in 2012, [[emerging markets]] such as [[China]], [[Russia]], and [[Brazil]] had significantly increased their spending over the previous decade.{{cite web|url=http://media.unwto.org/en/press-release/2013-04-04/china-new-number-one-tourism-source-market-world |title=China – the new number one tourism source market in the world|publisher=[[World Tourism Organization]]|date=4 April 2013|accessdate=9 April 2013}} The [[ITB Berlin]] is the world's leading tourism [[trade fair]].{{cite web|title=ITB Berlin: The World's Leading Travel Trade Show|url=http://www.expodatabase.com/tradeshow/itb-berlin-the-worlds-leading-travel-trade-show-908.html|website=www.expodatabase.com|publisher=M+A Expo Database|accessdate=13 September 2016}} Global tourism accounts for ca. 8% of global [[greenhouse gas]] emissions.Lenzen et al. (2018), https://www.nature.com/articles/s41558-018-0141-x ==Etymology== [[File:Vysoké Tatry r.1922.jpg|thumb|1922 postcard of tourists in the [[High Tatras]], [[Slovakia]].]] The word ''tourist'' was used in 1772{{cite journal|last1=Griffiths|first1=Ralph|authorlink1=Ralph Griffiths|author2=Griffiths, G. E. |title=Pennant's Tour in Scotland in 1769|journal=[[Monthly Review (London)|The Monthly Review, Or, Literary Journal]]|year=1772|volume=46|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=xS8oAAAAYAAJ&vq=tourist&dq=tourist&pg=PA150|accessdate=23 December 2011|location=London|page=150}} and ''tourism'' in 1811.{{cite web|url=http://www.etymonline.com/index.php?allowed_in_frame=0&search=tour&searchmode=none|title=tour (n.)|first1=Douglas|last1=Harper|authorlink1=Douglas Harper|work=[[Online Etymology Dictionary]]|accessdate=23 December 2011}} It is formed from the word ''tour'', which is derived from Old English ''turian'', from Old French ''torner'', from Latin ''tornare''; 'to turn on a lathe,' which is itself from Ancient Greek ''tornos'' (τόρνος); 'lathe'.{{Cite web|url=http://etymonline.com/index.php?term=turn&allowed_in_frame=0|title=Online Etymology Dictionary|website=etymonline.com|access-date=2 June 2016}} ==Significance of tourism== [[File:Ahlbeck Strandkörbe 2013.JPG|thumb|[[Strandkorb]] chairs on [[Usedom|Usedom Island]], Germany. Not only does the service sector grow thanks to tourism, but also local [[Craft|manufacturers]] (like those producing the strandkorb chairs), [[retail]]ers, the [[Real estate development|real-estate sector]] and the general [[City marketing|image of a location]] can benefit.]] [[File:Drawienski Park Narodowy - ruiny Wegorni.jpg|thumb|[[Drawa National Park]] in Poland, famous for its [[canoe]]ing routes.]] Tourism has become an important, even vital, source of income for many regions and even entire countries. The ''Manila Declaration on World Tourism of 1980'' recognized its importance as "an activity essential to the life of nations because of its direct effects on the social, cultural, educational, and economic sectors of national societies and on their international relations."{{cite conference |url= http://www.univeur.org/cuebc/downloads/PDF%20carte/65.%20Manila.PDF |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20121120180003/http://www.univeur.org/CMS/UserFiles/65.%20Manila.PDF |archivedate= 20 November 2012 |title= Manila Declaration on World Tourism |date= 10 October 1980|pages= 1–4|location= [[Manila]], [[Philippines]] |conference= World Tourism Conference}} Tourism brings large amounts of income into a local economy in the form of payment for [[goods and services]] needed by tourists, accounting {{as of | 2011 | lc = on}} for 30% of the world's [[trade]] in services, and for 6% of overall [[export]]s of goods and services. It also generates opportunities for [[employment]] in the [[Tertiary sector of the economy|service sector of the economy]] associated with tourism.{{cite web|url= http://mkt.unwto.org/sites/all/files/docpdf/unwtohighlights12enlr_1.pdf |title= 2012 Tourism Highlights |publisher= UNWTO |accessdate= 17 June 2012 |date= June 2012 |deadurl= yes |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20120709215809/http://mkt.unwto.org/sites/all/files/docpdf/unwtohighlights12enlr_1.pdf |archivedate= 9 July 2012 |df= }} The hospitality industries which benefit from tourism include [[transport |transportation services]] (such as [[airline]]s, [[cruise ship]]s, [[train]]s and [[taxicab]]s); [[hospitality service]]s (such as [[lodging|accommodations]], including [[hotel]]s and [[resort]]s); and entertainment venues (such as [[amusement park]]s, [[restaurant]]s, [[casino]]s, [[shopping mall]]s, [[music venue]]s, and [[theatre|theaters]]). This is in addition to goods bought by tourists, including [[souvenir]]s. On the flip-side, tourism can degrade people and sour relationships between host and guest. {{cite book | last1 = Smith | first1 = Melanie K. | title = Issues in Cultural Tourism Studies | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=YT_uqD4G94sC | series = Tourism / Routledge | location = London | publisher = Routledge | publication-date = 2003 | page = 50 | isbn = 9780415256384 | access-date = 2018-05-30 | quote = The globalisation of tourism has partially exacerbated the relationships of inequality and subservience that are so commonplace in host-guest encounters. It is not simply enough for local people to accept their role as servants, guides or companions to a range of ever-changing tourists. They are also confronted increasingly by the luxurious global products of Western indulgence which remain far from their reach, rather like the thirsty Tantalus in his elusive pool of water. | year = 2003 }} ==Definitions== In 1936, the [[League of Nations]] defined a ''foreign tourist'' as "someone traveling abroad for at least twenty-four hours". Its successor, the [[United Nations]], amended this definition in 1945, by including a maximum stay of six months.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/?id=9dvK2ajv7zIC&lpg=PA10&dq=league%20of%20nations%20tourism%201936&pg=PA6#v=onepage&q=league%20of%20nations%20tourism%201936|title=Global Tourism|last=Theobald|first=William F.|publisher=[[Butterworth–Heinemann]]|year=1998|isbn=978-0-7506-4022-0|edition= 2nd|location=Oxford [England]|pages=6–7|oclc=40330075}} In 1941, Hunziker and Kraft defined tourism as "the sum of the phenomena and relationships arising from the travel and stay of non-residents, insofar as they do not lead to [[Permanent residency|permanent residence]] and are not connected with any earning activity."{{cite book|title=Grundriß Der Allgemeinen Fremdenverkehrslehre|last1=Hunziker |first1=W|authorlink1=Walter Hunziker|last2=Krapf|first2=K|oclc=180109383|publisher=Polygr. Verl|language=German|location=Zurich|year=1942}}{{cite book|title=Tourismus-management: Tourismus-marketing Und Fremdenverkehrsplanung|year=1998|publisher=[u.a.] de Gruyter |isbn=978-3-11-015185-5|last1=Spode|first1=Hasso |authorlink1=Hasso Spode|editor1-first= Günther|editor1-last= Haedrich|location=Berlin|oclc=243881885|language=German|chapter=Geschichte der Tourismuswissenschaft}} In 1976, the Tourism Society of England's definition was: "Tourism is the temporary, short-term movement of people to [[tourist destination|destinations]] outside the places where they normally live and work and their activities during the stay at each destination. It includes movements for all purposes."{{cite book|last=Beaver|first=Allan|title=A Dictionary of Travel and Tourism Terminology|year=2002|publisher=CAB International|isbn=978-0-85199-582-3|page=313|location=Wallingford |oclc=301675778}} In 1981, the International Association of Scientific Experts in Tourism defined tourism in terms of particular activities chosen and undertaken outside the home.{{cite web|title=The AIEST, its character and aims|url=http://www.aiest.org/org/idt/idt_aiest.nsf/en/index.html|author=International Association of Scientific Experts in Tourism|accessdate=29 March 2008|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111126143828/http://www.aiest.org/org/idt/idt_aiest.nsf/en/index.html|archivedate=26 November 2011|df=dmy-all}} In 1994, the [[United Nations]] identified three forms of tourism in its ''Recommendations on Tourism Statistics'':{{cite journal|last=|first=|date=|year=1994|title=Recommendations on Tourism Statistics|url=https://unstats.un.org/unsd/newsletter/unsd_workshops/tourism/st_esa_stat_ser_M_83.pdf|journal=|series=M|location=New York|volume=|issue=83|page=5|pages=|work=Statistical Papers|accessdate=12 July 2010}} * Domestic tourism, involving residents of the given country traveling only within this country * Inbound tourism, involving non-residents traveling in the given country * Outbound tourism, involving residents traveling in another country The terms ''tourism'' and ''travel'' are sometimes used interchangeably. In this context, travel has a similar definition to tourism, but implies a more purposeful journey. The terms ''tourism'' and ''tourist'' are sometimes used pejoratively, to imply a shallow interest in the cultures or locations visited. By contrast, ''traveler'' is often used as a sign of distinction. The sociology of tourism has studied the cultural values underpinning these distinctions and their implications for class relations.{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books/about/Tourists_at_the_Taj.html?id=YjLxR2H-YCYC|title=Tourists at the Taj: Performance and Meaning at a Symbolic Site|last=Edensor|first=Tim|date=1 January 1998|publisher=Psychology Press|year=|isbn=9780415167123|location=|pages=|language=en}} ==World tourism statistics and rankings== ===Total volume of cross-border tourist travel=== International tourist arrivals reached 1.035 billion in 2012, up from over 996 million in 2011, and 952 million in 2010.{{cite journal|url=http://dtxtq4w60xqpw.cloudfront.net/sites/all/files/pdf/unwto_barom13_01_jan_excerpt_0.pdf |title=UNWTO World Tourism Barometer |journal=UNWTO World Tourism Barometer |date=January 2013 |volume=11 |issue=1 |accessdate=9 April 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130228162347/http://dtxtq4w60xqpw.cloudfront.net/sites/all/files/pdf/unwto_barom13_01_jan_excerpt_0.pdf |archivedate=28 February 2013 |df= }} In 2011 and 2012, international [[Travel behavior|travel demand]] continued to recover from the losses resulting from the [[late-2000s recession]], where tourism suffered a strong slowdown from the second half of 2008 through the end of 2009. After a 5% increase in the first half of 2008, growth in international tourist arrivals moved into negative territory in the second half of 2008, and ended up only 2% for the year, compared to a 7% increase in 2007.{{cite journal|url=http://www.unwto.org/facts/eng/pdf/barometer/UNWTO_Barom09_1_en.pdf|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131017212434/http://www2.unwto.org/facts/eng/pdf/barometer/UNWTO_Barom09_1_en.pdf|dead-url=yes|archive-date=17 October 2013|title=International tourism challenged by deteriorating global economy|journal=UNWTO World Tourism Barometer|date=January 2009|volume=7|issue=1|accessdate=17 November 2011}} The negative trend intensified during 2009, exacerbated in some countries due to the outbreak of the [[2009 flu pandemic|H1N1 influenza virus]], resulting in a worldwide decline of 4.2% in 2009 to 880 million international tourists arrivals, and a 5.7% decline in international tourism receipts.{{cite journal|url=http://www.unwto.org/facts/eng/pdf/barometer/UNWTO_Barom10_update_august_en.pdf|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131017203915/http://www2.unwto.org/facts/eng/pdf/barometer/UNWTO_Barom10_update_august_en.pdf|dead-url=yes|archive-date=17 October 2013|title=UNWTO World Tourism Barometer Interim Update|journal=UNWTO World Tourism Barometer|date=August 2010|accessdate=17 November 2011}} ===World’s top tourism destinations=== {{Main|World Tourism rankings}} The [[World Tourism Organization]] reports the following ten destinations as the most visited in terms of the number of international travelers in 2017. {| class="wikitable sortable" style="margin:1em auto 1em auto;" ! Rank ! Country ! [[World Tourism Organization|UNWTO]]
